headline: How Do You Think About the Question of When Life Begins? Tell Us.
abstract: Underlying the debate in America over abortion is a big, difficult question.
lead_paragraph: In the months since the Supreme Court overturned Roe vs. Wade, politicians and activists have attempted to squeeze concrete answers from an eternal question of human existence: When does life begin? This question goes far beyond politics, law and science into the heart of human experience.

headline: When Does Life Begin?
abstract: The question is at the heart of the human experience — and the nation’s abortion debate. An exploration through science, theology and philosophy.
lead_paragraph: The question is at the heart of the human experience — and the nation’s abortion debate. An exploration through science, theology and philosophy.

headline: T.C.U. Upends Michigan in Wild Playoff Semifinal
abstract: Texas Christian returned two interceptions for touchdowns, just part of a zany back-and-forth upset of Michigan, 51-45, which put the Horned Frogs in the national championship game.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Sonny Dykes is not the ideal of the jut-jawed football coach. He opens his program up, instead of building walls around it. He freely acknowledges there were times when he was a younger coach — several, in fact — that the pressure of winning games became suffocating.

headline: In Bucha, a Final Rampage Served as a Coda to a Month of Atrocities
abstract: Hours before Russian troops began withdrawing from the suburban town, a Russian soldier left a trail of blood and devastated lives in a last paroxysm of violence.
lead_paragraph: BUCHA, Ukraine — On one of the last nights of the Russian occupation of Bucha, a lone Russian soldier, drunk or high, went out looking for wine. He forced a 75-year-old resident at gunpoint along the street and made him bang on the doors of private homes.

headline: Georgia Downs Ohio State in Semifinal on Last-Minute Touchdown
abstract: Georgia scored in the final minute of the game, and Ohio State missed a field goal in the first minute of 2023.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Georgia Bulldogs appeared very nearly finished, just as they had looked for much of Saturday night.

headline: The First Afterlife of Pope Benedict XVI
abstract: Pope Benedict’s legacy will be felt across decades or even centuries.
lead_paragraph: The first pope to resign was Celestine V, born Pietro Da Morrone, who was living the life of a pious hermit when he was elevated to the papacy in 1294, in his 80s, to break a two-year deadlock in the College of Cardinals. Feeling overmastered by the job, he soon resigned in the expectation that he could return to his monastic existence. Instead, he was imprisoned by his successor, Boniface VIII, who feared that some rival faction might make Celestine an antipope.

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘Today Girl’ to TV Icon, Walters Traversed News and Celebrity
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 1, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “She rattled a lot of cages before women were even allowed into the zoo.”

headline: No Corrections: Jan. 1, 2023
abstract: No corrections  appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 1, 2023
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about investors who find roboadvisers’ financial advice lacking misstated the title of Brian Ream of CLA and referred incorrectly to CLA’s operations. Mr. Ream is a principal, not an adviser and manag­ing partner, and CLA is a wealth advisory, not management, firm.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: How Should You Be? Try Taking Suggestions.
abstract: More than offering prescriptions, suggestions — good or bad — about how we should live broaden our worldview and put us in touch with our desires.
lead_paragraph: Some chapters of life attract advice. After a breakup, friends who are typically silent about your romances might urge you to get back on dating apps and block your ex on social media. Starting a family gives rise to opinions about prenatal vitamins and stroller brands; interviewing for a new job might prompt advice about salary negotiations and work-life balance.

headline: ‘Suddenly, It Appeared as Though the Bus Was Going to Be Able to Move’
abstract: Small talk on the M15, an autograph at Yankee Stadium and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Veterans Trickle Through a Special New York Court Known Only to a Few
abstract: No one knows how many are helped or how much Veterans Treatment Courts in New York cost. Supporters say it gives defendants who were in the armed forces a second chance.
lead_paragraph: Edward Hernandez sat on a bench in a Lower Manhattan courthouse, waiting for his case to be called.

headline: Eric Adams Said He Wanted to ‘Get Stuff Done.’ Did He?
abstract: In his first year as mayor, he focused his attention on fighting crime. But critics say he is not moving quickly enough to address New York City’s other urgent challenges.
lead_paragraph: The message, arriving as New Yorkers were growing more concerned about crime, was simple: Eric Adams, a former police captain, was the only candidate for mayor in 2021 who could rein in a sense of disorder that had seeped into the city during the pandemic.

headline: Strife in the Schools: Education Dept. Logs Record Number of Discrimination Complaints
abstract: Some of the highest-profile complaints show how America’s culture wars are affecting the nation’s children.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Education Department’s Office for Civil Rights logged a record number of discrimination complaints in the past year, the latest indicator of how the social and political strife roiling the country is reverberating in the nation’s schools.

headline: ‘OK, Mexico, Save Me’: After China, This Is Where Globalization May Lead
abstract: As American companies seek to limit their exposure to the pitfalls of making goods in China, some are moving production to Mexico.
lead_paragraph: As American companies recalibrate the risks of relying on Chinese factories to make their goods, some are shifting business to a country far closer to home: Mexico.

headline: Police Officers Injured in Machete Attack Near Times Square
abstract: The police say a 19-year-old man struck two officers before the police opened fire, hitting him in the shoulder.
lead_paragraph: The police shot a machete-wielding man who attacked three officers on Saturday night near Times Square, injuring him and creating a chaotic scene just hours before the ball dropped to mark New Year’s Day in New York City, the authorities said.

headline: North Korea Vows to Escalate Nuclear Threat Against the South
abstract: Kim Jong-un told a Workers’ Party meeting that his country must mass-produce nuclear missiles that could hit South Korea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, vowed to expand his country’s nuclear capabilities against rival South Korea​ “exponentially,”​ indicating that he would escalate his military brinkmanship in the new year ​despite sanctions from abroad and economic woes​ at home​.

headline: Week 17 N.F.L. Playoff Picture Preview: A Team-by-Team Guide
abstract: Some games are much more important than others.
lead_paragraph: Some games are much more important than others.

headline: ‘Terrorist’ — to Whom?
abstract: V.V. Ganeshananthan’s novel “Brotherless Night” reveals the moral nuances of violence, ever belied by black-and-white terminology.
lead_paragraph: The word “terrorist,” or some variation thereof, shows up six times on the opening page of V.V. Ganeshananthan’s “Brotherless Night.” To be bludgeoned this way by such a poisoned piece of political taxonomy is to be reminded that for those fortunate enough to wield it, “terrorist” is a word that cleanses nuance: It suggests that there are good and bad people, and the bad ones are irredeemable enough to warrant a fixed label.

headline: Your 2023 Guide to Low-Down-Payment Mortgages
abstract: Facing high interest rates and home prices, some buyers have only a small down payment to offer. But they still have plenty of options.
lead_paragraph: It’s a perennial question for would-be home buyers: How can I possibly come up with such a huge down payment?

headline: A New Puzzle Turns Earth Into a Rubik’s Cube, but More Complex
abstract: Continental Drift is one of Henry Segerman’s latest efforts to make mathematics “real.”
lead_paragraph: Another orbit around the sun and here we are again: back where we started but spun about — changed, perhaps deranged.

headline: U.S. Pours Money Into Chips, but Even Soaring Spending Has Limits
abstract: Amid a tech cold war with China, U.S. companies have pledged nearly $200 billion for chip manufacturing projects since early 2020. But the investments are not a silver bullet.
lead_paragraph: In September, the chip giant Intel gathered officials at a patch of land near Columbus, Ohio, where it pledged to invest at least $20 billion in two new factories to make semiconductors.

headline: 10 Things Our Critics Are Looking Forward to in 2023
abstract: “Succession” returns, the Spider-Verse spawns a sequel, Kelela hits the road and Michael B. Jordan makes his directing debut with “Creed III.”
lead_paragraph: While there are no sure bets in television, and plenty of once-great shows have fallen into bland disarray, I am counting the days until “Succession” comes back for its fourth season. (HBO says it will air in the spring.) Oh, I can hear the jangly piano theme now, and just knowing that the bereft and broken Roys, their gorgeously cruel dialogue and endless, joyless quests for power will soon be back on my screen fills me with elation. God, I hope Kendall sings in front of an audience again, and Greg stammers his way into failing up somehow, and Gerri and Roman’s erotic entanglement deepens and Shiv continues her reign of ecru terror. Logan will be grumbly! Connor will be a dingus! Tom will be in hapless agony! And I will be so, so happy, reveling in the show’s mastery of tension, its push-pull of crumbling and coalescing.

headline: How Central Ohio Got People to Eat Their Leftovers
abstract: The average U.S. household wastes nearly a third of the food it buys. This community is nudging its residents to change their habits.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Savage was scrambling to pull something together for dinner. Deep in the back of her fridge, she found a container of stuffed peppers. Very old stuffed peppers. She groaned, then did what millions of Americans do every day, without a second thought: She scraped the rotten food into the garbage.

headline: The Week in Business: Southwest’s Holiday Meltdown
abstract: The cost cutting continues at Twitter. The S&P 500 had a bad 2022, and it’s not clear if 2023 will be better. The Labor Department will report jobs numbers for December.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of travelers were stranded in airports across the country over the holidays as Southwest Airlines canceled more than 2,900 flights on Monday and roughly 5,000 over Tuesday and Wednesday, more than 60 percent of its schedule. The disruptions were the result of staffing shortages and longstanding technological problems compounded by a fierce winter storm. Many customers said Southwest had done little or nothing to get them to their destinations. The airline’s chief executive of 10 months, Bob Jordan, apologized, and the company said it had called on over 1,000 corporate employees to manually schedule crews for new flights. But Southwest’s reputation is in tatters, and the scale of the chaos — which one industry analyst called “the worst round of cancellations for any single airline” in recent memory — has prompted the Department of Transportation to announce that it would look into whether Southwest was meeting its obligations to customers.

headline: A Happier New Year
abstract: Develop stronger relationships in 2023.
lead_paragraph: For over 80 years, researchers at Harvard have studied what makes for a good life. They found one surefire, scientifically proven predictor of happiness: developing warmer relationships.

headline: Dionne Warwick Is Ready for an Encore
abstract: A conversation with the five-time Grammy-winning singer who is the subject of a new career-spanning documentary, “Dionne Warwick: Don’t Make Me Over.”
lead_paragraph: Dionne Warwick refuses to stay put. At 82, the five-time Grammy-winning artist is making stops in Hawaii and Vancouver on her One Last Time tour — she won’t say whether it’s truly her last — tweeting (or “twoting,” as she calls it) to her more than half a million followers, and making appearances on “S.N.L.” and on movie soundtracks like Jordan Peele’s “Nope.” When she retires, she said, she’ll move to Brazil.

headline: Robert Caro Relaxes by Listening to People Drum in Central Park
abstract: The biographer and subject of the documentary “Turn Every Page” talks about his loyalty to the Giants and the Knicks, Zooming with classmates and falling under the spell of Captain Hornblower.
lead_paragraph: When the filmmaker Lizzie Gottlieb approached Robert Caro about a documentary on the relationship between him and his editor, Robert Gottlieb, Caro didn’t want to do it. He nonetheless found it insulting when Robert, Lizzie’s father, didn’t want to do it either.

headline: Ex-Nurse Recorded Himself Sexually Assaulting Patients, Police Say
abstract: Christopher P. Lambros, 61, was charged with sexual assault after recording videos of himself assaulting unconscious female patients at a Colorado hospital, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A former nurse at a Colorado hospital has been charged with sexually abusing female patients while they were unconscious and with recording the assaults on video, the police said.

headline: Putin Has a New Year’s Message. So Do His Critics, From Jail.
abstract: Seasonal greetings from imprisoned opponents offered counterprogramming of a sort to the traditional end-of-year speech from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
lead_paragraph: There are now so many jailed opponents of President Vladimir V. Putin and his full-scale invasion of Ukraine that a new tradition has emerged in Russia: New Year’s greetings from political prisoners.

headline: Don’t Honor Those With a Nazi History
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay about U.S. institutions that honor former Nazis. Also: Wearing masks; inaccessible historic houses.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Rabbi Haim Druckman, a Leader of Religious Zionism, Dies at 90
abstract: An influential educator, he was a strong advocate of creating Jewish settlements in the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Rabbi Haim Druckman, a prominent spiritual leader of Israel’s Religious Zionist movement, lifelong educator, founder of the Jewish settlement project and politician, died here on Dec. 25. He was 90.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Good morning. Welcome to 2023! How’s the noggin?
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Welcome to 2023! How’s the noggin?

headline: Why India and China Are Fighting in the Himalayas
abstract: The countries share a volatile disputed border that is not marked on a map.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On a freezing December day on a remote Himalayan mountain ridge, Indian and Chinese soldiers fought with sticks, stones, clubs and bare fists. Scores were bloodied and injured. The incident, according to the Indian authorities, occurred on Dec. 9, when about 300 soldiers from the People’s Liberation Army of China attempted to occupy Yangtse, a mountainous border post on the disputed India-China border in the Tawang area in northeastern India.

headline: Forget the Beach Bod. Try These Soul Resolutions Instead.
abstract: New Year’s habits that are good for the soul.
lead_paragraph: I never know how to think about New Year’s resolutions or whether to make them. On one hand, I am drawn to the idea of new beginnings. I love the intentionality and thoughtfulness that are required to make a resolution. They force me to reflect on what I long for, what the good life might consist of and how to get there, which is a good exercise for all of us at any time.

headline: There Has Never Been a Better Time to Be Short
abstract: Short people don’t just save resources; as resources become scarcer owing to overpopulation and global warming, they may also be best suited for long-term survival.
lead_paragraph: From where I stand — at five feet even — being tall is a widely held fantasy of superiority that long ago should have been retired.

headline: Putin Has No Red Lines
abstract: There are better ways to think about strategy.
lead_paragraph: “What are Putin’s red lines?”

headline: Lula Becomes Brazil’s President, With Bolsonaro in Florida
abstract: Brazil inaugurates its new president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, on Sunday. Facing investigations, former President Jair Bolsonaro has taken refuge in Orlando.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the election protests at Brazil’s National Congress.

headline: Retiring Congress Members See Rough Roads Ahead. They Won’t Miss the Gridlock.
abstract: Departing longtime lawmakers perceive little prospect of orderly business in a divided Congress. They’re taking with them decades of experience in the day-to-day work of keeping the government running.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seated in his rapidly emptying office, Senator Richard M. Burr, Republican of North Carolina, ticked through the frustrations that had piled up in recent years: party leaders devaluing committee work, an institution reluctant to embrace new ideas and unnamed colleagues unwilling to collaborate or brush up on the details of legislation.

headline: Review: The Met Opera Found an Audience for ‘Fedora.’ For Now.
abstract: Worries about the company’s future were momentarily stilled at a festive gala premiere on New Year’s Eve.
lead_paragraph: The mood was festive, the audience large and enthusiastic, for the gala premiere on New Year’s Eve of a rare new production of Umberto Giordano’s lovably preposterous potboiler “Fedora” at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: As His Life of Fantasy Comes Into Focus, George Santos Goes to Washington
abstract: Mr. Santos, under scrutiny for lies about his background, is set to be sworn into Congress on Tuesday even as records, colleagues and friends divulge more about his past.
lead_paragraph: In two years, George Santos went from being a little-known also-ran to a beacon of the Republican Party’s unexpected resurgence in a deep-blue state.

headline: In a Small Arkansas City, Crime, Dread and an Emergency Curfew
abstract: A gun death on Christmas Eve crystallized the fear and frustration over violence that had been building in Eudora, Ark., a city of 1,700, for months.
lead_paragraph: EUDORA, Ark. — In the small city planted in a seemingly endless spread of flat Arkansas farmland, the sense of danger had been building. There had been shootings, home invasions, teenagers without driver’s licenses going on joy rides that ended in crashes. The police had been run ragged.

headline: Idaho Murder Suspect Had Been a Student of the Criminal Mind
abstract: The arrest of a graduate student in the murder of four University of Idaho students eased fears but raised a troubling new question: What was the motive?
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Idaho — About two weeks before four University of Idaho students were found stabbed to death in a home near campus, Bryan Kohberger was sitting in a criminology class at a college just a short drive away, leaning into a conversation about forensics, D.N.A. and other evidence prosecutors use to win convictions.

headline: Russian Airstrikes Leave Ukrainians Few Options but to Endure
abstract: Ten months into the war, Ukraine has turned the tide in ground combat, but its cities are still facing relentless waves of missiles and exploding drones.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Fed up with huddling for safety in their corridors and bathrooms during Russia’s aerial attacks, residents of one neighborhood in Kyiv took a different approach in the first moments of New Year’s Day.

headline: A Toxic Stew on Cape Cod: Human Waste and Warming Water
abstract: Climate change is contributing to electric-green algae blooms. Massachusetts wants a cleanup of the antiquated septic systems feeding the mess, but it could cost billions.
lead_paragraph: MASHPEE, Mass. — Ashley K. Fisher walked to the edge of the boat, pulled on a pair of thick black waders, and jumped into the river to search for the dead.

headline: Jan. 4: Earth will be at its closest point to the sun
abstract: Even as the Northern Hemisphere experiences winter’s chill, our planet on Wednesday will be at perihelion, the closest it gets to the sun during its elliptical orbit. Learn more about planetary orbits and the search for life around the galaxy.
lead_paragraph: Even as the Northern Hemisphere experiences winter’s chill, our planet on Wednesday will be at perihelion, the closest it gets to the sun during its elliptical orbit. Learn more about planetary orbits and the search for life around the galaxy.

headline: Jan. 3-4: The Quadrantid meteor shower will peak
abstract: The year starts with the Quadrantid meteor shower, named after Quadrans Muralis, an archaic constellation that modern astronomers lump in with the constellation known as Boötes. It can be one of the strongest showers of the year, though poor winter weather and a short window for peak viewing often mean that it can fall short of its potential.
lead_paragraph: The year starts with the Quadrantid meteor shower, named after Quadrans Muralis, an archaic constellation that modern astronomers lump in with the constellation known as Boötes. It can be one of the strongest showers of the year, though poor winter weather and a short window for peak viewing often mean that it can fall short of its potential.

headline: How to watch meteor showers
abstract: 2023 should be a good year for meteor lovers.
lead_paragraph: On any given night, far from bright city lights, there’s a chance that you’ll see a beautiful streak shoot across the sky as a meteor flies overhead. But on special dates scattered throughout the year, skywatchers can catch a multitude of flares as meteor showers burst in the darkness.

headline: At Inauguration, Hochul Vows to Make New York Safer and More Affordable
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul, the first woman to be sworn in for a full term as New York State governor, appealed for unity.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — Kathy Hochul became the first woman to be sworn in to a full term as governor of New York on Sunday, a landmark moment that she said she would seize to lead a state confronting fears over crime and a crisis of affordability.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: The Impact of a U.S. Chip-Making Boom
abstract: Also, North Korea threatens nuclear escalation and Ukraine reinforces its resilience amid a deadly assault.

headline: Edith Pearlman, Writer Who Won Acclaim Late in Life, Dies at 86
abstract: A short story writer for four decades, her own tale was a rare Cinderella story in publishing, centering on a septuagenarian and a young editor.

headline: Jeremiah Green, Drummer for Modest Mouse, Dies at 45
abstract: Mr. Green was a founder of the group, an indie band that rose to mainstream success. He was also one of its most enduring members.
lead_paragraph: Jeremiah Green, a drummer who co-founded and then became a stalwart member of Modest Mouse, an indie rock band that rose to mainstream fame, died on Saturday in the small coastal city of Sequim, Wash. He was 45.

headline: What We Learned From Week 17 in the N.F.L.
abstract: Quarterback problems doomed the Jets and Commanders, while Tampa Bay won the woeful N.F.C. South with a banner day from Mike Evans in a victory over Carolina.
lead_paragraph: With just two weeks left in the season, it’s time to put up or shut up. Some teams were ready on Sunday; others were not. The disappointing Buccaneers rose to the challenge, coming back to beat the Panthers and wrest the division title from them. The Jets and Commanders, by contrast, lost games that dashed their playoff hopes.

headline: Kerfuffle
abstract: Seth Bisen-Hersh’s debut puzzle was meant to be.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Brazil’s Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva Is Sworn In as President
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of supporters filled the central esplanade in Brazil’s capital, as President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva waved to onlookers from his motorcade on the way to his inauguration ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of supporters filled the central esplanade in Brazil’s capital, as President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva waved to onlookers from his motorcade on the way to his inauguration ceremony.

headline: Anita Pointer, Frequent Lead Singer of Famed Sister Act, Dies at 74
abstract: She was the lead vocalist on all three of the Pointer Sisters’ Top 40 hits in the group’s early years, and she helped define its pop sound in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Anita Pointer, the sweet and occasionally sultry lead vocalist on many hits of her family band the Pointer Sisters in the 1970s and ’80s, died on Saturday at home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 74.

headline: California Scrambles to Recover From Storm Before the Next One Hits
abstract: A weather event known as an atmospheric river dumped snow and rain across the state, causing flooding and landslides and killing one.
lead_paragraph: After days of pounding rain, winds and snow, Californians woke up to sunny skies and waterlogged streets on New Year’s Day, scrambling to recover during a brief intermission before the next rainstorms that are forecast to hit the region later this week.

headline: California Town Rattled by Earthquake a Second Time
abstract: Rio Dell was still recovering from a 6.4-magnitude quake that hit on Dec. 20, when it was jolted again on New Year’s Day.
lead_paragraph: RIO DELL, Calif — The first jolt came days before Christmas, in the middle of the night, shaking residents awake, toppling walls and cracking roads. The town was still recovering from that 6.4-magnitude earthquake when they got another, this time on a sunny, otherwise quiet New Year’s Day.

headline: How Strong Are Your Relationships?
abstract: Relationships with friends, family, coworkers and even casual acquaintances play a crucial role in your well-being. Find out how robust your social ties are.
lead_paragraph: Relationships with friends, family, coworkers and even casual acquaintances play a crucial role in your well-being. Find out how robust your social ties are.

headline: Day 1: Take Stock of Your Relationships
abstract: Today, you will identify the areas of your life in which you would like to be more connected.
lead_paragraph: In 1938, researchers at Harvard set out to learn what makes a person thrive.

headline: The Man Who Made Spain the Magic Capital of the World
abstract: Inside the mind of Juan Tamariz, the godfather of close-up card magic.
lead_paragraph: Going out to dinner with Juan Tamariz in Madrid is a little like accompanying a cartoon character on a journey to the real world. As I walked with the 80-year-old magician on side streets off the city center’s main drag, the Calle Gran Vía, heads turned left and right. Tamariz has been a professional magician for 52 years, and in that time, he has managed the singular feat of becoming both a household name in his home country and a living legend in magic everywhere. He is referred to by magicians all over the world, and waiters all over Madrid, as Maestro. David Blaine has called him “the greatest and most influential card magician alive.” But in Spain, Tamariz is an icon, less like Blaine or David Copperfield and more like Kermit the Frog.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Lula is now the president of Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, widely known as Lula, took the reins of the Brazilian government yesterday in an elaborate inauguration, complete with a motorcade, a music festival and hundreds of thousands of supporters filling the central esplanade of Brasília, the capital. It caps a stunning political comeback for the man who was once Brazil’s most popular president.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Finding Your Roots’ and ‘Mayfair Witches’
abstract: Henry Louis Gates Jr.’s genealogy series returns on PBS. And a TV adaptation of an Anne Rice trilogy debuts on AMC.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Jan. 2-8. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Climate Activists Find a Way to Get Germany’s Attention: Stop Traffic
abstract: Extreme tactics have pushed the climate crisis to the top of the public discourse but also stirred debate over whether the activists are going too far.
lead_paragraph: The radical climate activists tried hunger strikes. They glued themselves to famous paintings. They tried to disrupt a classical concert. They confronted lawmakers trying to enter Parliament. They even desecrated an official Christmas tree of the city of Berlin.

headline: My Uncle Taught Pelé Guitar: The Mourning Is Deeper in One City
abstract: While fans around the world grieve Pelé’s death, in Santos, Brazil, where he first made his mark, residents recall a friend and neighbor who never forgot them.
lead_paragraph: All around the world, fans have mourned the loss of Pelé, whose unrivaled mastery of the beautiful game catapulted him to a level of celebrity attained by few athletes.

headline: No Corrections: Jan. 2, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 2, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Mall Where Vendors and Shoppers Celebrate the Beauty in Every Body
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 2, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Sometimes it feels nice to not even feel special.”

headline: ‘Biofoul’ on Hull Strands Cruise Ship at Sea for 6 Days
abstract: An unidentified organism prompted Australia to block the vessel from docking, forcing passengers to skip a series of port stops.
lead_paragraph: A cruise through the glittering blue waters from Auckland to Sydney should have been a holiday-season highlight for passengers, many of whom had saved years for it.

headline: Iggy Pop Isn’t About to Whitewash His Past
abstract: “If I decided I was going to try to clean up everything I’ve ever done, that would make me Sisyphus.”
lead_paragraph: “If I decided I was going to try to clean up everything I’ve ever done, that would make me Sisyphus.”

headline: A Failed Speaker Vote for Kevin McCarthy Would Be a Historic Event
abstract: A small group of Republicans has promised to vote against Kevin McCarthy this week. They could throw the House into chaos not seen for a century.
lead_paragraph: News update: On Tuesday, Representative Kevin McCarthy of California fell short in his bid to become speaker of the House. The House is set to reconvene Wednesday to continue the election process.

headline: I Know What Savage Fear Really Lies at the Heart of the American Dream
abstract: It’s the fear of failure.
lead_paragraph: I wrote a book in praise of failure, which is like a fish praising water. I’ve been swimming in failure for as long as I can remember — even before that. Quite a lot of who we are, what we do and especially what we cannot do is determined well before we are born, by history, geography, the rise and fall of empires, that farcical god we call luck. I came into this world with failure in my blood and bones. Sometimes I wonder if there is anything else there.

headline: In the ‘Cozy Catastrophe’ Novel, the End of the World Is Not So Bad
abstract: Originally published in 1939, “The Hopkins Manuscript,” by the British writer R.C. Sherriff, inaugurated a genre of post-apocalyptic fiction in which a resourceful hero survives unthinkable cataclysm.
lead_paragraph: In “Billion Year Spree,” his influential 1973 study of science fiction, the writer Brian Aldiss identified a kind of post-apocalyptic novel that he called “the cozy catastrophe.” These were stories about the end of the world in which a resourceful survivor — usually a British man from the middle class — puts together a relatively comfortable life for himself in the ruins. Although the genre is often associated with the work of John Wyndham, especially “The Day of the Triffids” (1951), Aldiss traced it back to THE HOPKINS MANUSCRIPT (Scribner, 385 pp., paperback, $18), by R.C. Sherriff, which first appeared in 1939. Reissued this month, this wonderful novel should powerfully resonate with readers whose consciences are troubled by inequality and climate change. As Aldiss wrote, “The essence of cozy catastrophe is that the hero should have a pretty good time … while everyone else is dying off.”

headline: They Got an Apartment They Liked, but Had to Wait for the Happy Ending
abstract: A couple found a rental apartment in Manhattan on the first day they searched. But there were weeks of snags and delays before they actually moved in.
lead_paragraph: Emily Niekrasz and Garrett Muzikowski lived happily in a two-bedroom basement apartment in a rowhouse on Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C. Ms. Niekrasz had rented the 750-square-foot space for six years; Mr. Muzikowski had recently moved in. They felt settled and comfortable, and were surrounded by friends and family.

headline: One Indelible Scene: The Master Class in Ambiguity in ‘Tár’
abstract: Cate Blanchett’s character visits Juilliard to tackle the big questions about art, life and music-world rivalry.
lead_paragraph: When Lydia Tár arrives at the Juilliard School to teach a master class in conducting, we know her about as well as the students do. Like them, we are aware — about 20 minutes into the film that bears her name — of her fame and exalted status. They, of course, live in a fictional world in which her celebrity is established, to the extent that their own professional aspirations are shaped by her example. But now they have a chance to encounter her in person. It doesn’t go well.

headline: The Etiquette Guru Who Broke Up With a Boyfriend Over Text
abstract: Sara Jane Ho offers practical manners for a new, global world.
lead_paragraph: On the ninth day of filming Netflix’s “Mind Your Manners,” the show’s host, the Shanghai etiquette teacher Sara Jane Ho, dumped her on-again-off-again boyfriend of four years in a text message. Ms. Ho, a preternaturally poised 37-year-old who grew up on four continents and can eat a sunny-side-up egg without spilling a single drop of yolk, was in a car outside Sydney, Australia, in late 2021, on her way to perform a “Pygmalion”-style makeover for a party girl named Stephanie Osifo.

headline: Timeless Portraits of L.A.’s Arcades
abstract: Documenting video game parlors offered a French photographer a way to explore Los Angeles and its surrounding areas.
lead_paragraph: I’ll always remember the first time I stepped into Blipsy Bar on N. Western Avenue, in Los Angeles’s Koreatown. I felt like a teenager from the ’80s, here to escape the humdrum of the Hollywood crowds. I settled into the moody, retro atmosphere, watching people buy cheap drinks and looking nostalgically at the arcade games on offer: Ms. Pac-Man, Gun Fight, Track & Field, Paperboy.

headline: A Heavily Armed Man Caused Panic at a Supermarket. But Did He Break the Law?
abstract: In states with permissive gun laws, police and prosecutors have limited tools at their disposal when a heavily armed individual sows fear or panic in public.

headline: China’s Young Elite Clamber for Government Jobs. Some Come to Regret It.
abstract: With youth unemployment high, millions will take this month’s Civil Service exam. But for those who get jobs, the reality can be monotonous work that blurs the line with personal lives.
lead_paragraph: In Beijing and cities across China, as many as 2.6 million job applicants, including graduates from the country’s top universities, will report to testing centers in early January to face exceedingly long odds and compete for 37,100 entry-level government jobs.

headline: How Russia’s War on Ukraine Is Worsening Global Starvation
abstract: Moscow blocks most shipments from Ukraine, one of the world’s largest wheat producers, and its attacks on the country’s energy grid also disrupt the flow of food.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Hulking ships carrying Ukrainian wheat and other grains are backed up along the Bosporus here in Istanbul as they await inspections before moving on to ports around the world.

headline: Why China’s Economy Faces a Perilous Road to Recovery
abstract: Years of lockdowns took a brutal toll on businesses. Now, the rapid spread of Covid after a chaotic reopening has deprived them of workers and customers.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks after Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, tried to reinvigorate China’s stalled economy by abruptly abandoning his stringent pandemic restrictions, he struck an upbeat note in his annual New Year’s Eve address. “China’s economy has strong resilience, great potential and vitality,” he said.

headline: On the Streets of Dakar, a Kaleidoscope of Style
abstract: The capital of Senegal has become a fashion center. But photographing stylish people going about their day isn’t as easy as clicking a button.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The clash of cranes and bulldozers and the abundance of concrete and pipes as one walks through the streets signal where Dakar is headed and what it lacks. The atmosphere is not quite chaos. But it is quietly chaotic.

headline: 4 Dead in Helicopter Collision in Australia
abstract: The two craft crashed in midair in a tourist area on the Gold Coast, near a theme park. An investigation is underway, with a report expected to take weeks.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Four people died and eight others were injured in a midair collision of two helicopters on Monday in a tourist area in Queensland on the Gold Coast.

headline: The Question of Life Itself
abstract: How people regard the start of life is complicated, polarizing and worthy of exploration.
lead_paragraph: This past year, I’ve reported frequently on the topic of abortion when it intersects with my beat as the national religion correspondent for The Times. In the months since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, one question has come up over and over: When does life begin?

headline: Jeremy Renner Is in Critical Condition After Snow Plowing Accident
abstract: The actor, known for his role as Hawkeye in Marvel’s Avengers movies, had surgery, his representative said.
lead_paragraph: Update: Jeremy Renner was run over by a 7-ton snow plow, authorities said.

headline: ‘I Hold Him in My Heart’: Tens of Thousands Pay Respects to Benedict
abstract: The pope emeritus is lying in state in St. Peter’s Basilica, where some 65,000 mourners, including Roman Catholic faithful and tourists, had paid last respects by Monday evening.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people lined up outside St. Peter’s Basilica in Vatican City on Monday to pay last respects to Benedict XVI, the pope emeritus, who died on Saturday at age 95 and is now lying in state.

headline: Amid Fresh Wave of U.K. Strikes, Support for Many Walkouts Remains High
abstract: Public sympathy for striking nurses and other health workers is particularly strong, posing a challenge for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, who has promised to confront trade unions.
lead_paragraph: The winter holiday season across most of Britain ends on Tuesday, but the return to work for millions of Britons comes on the same day as yet another train strike, promising a commute as unpredictable as the country’s increasingly erratic rail network.

headline: Wordle Wrap-Up: Dec. 26 to Jan. 1
abstract: A recap of the Wordle answers for the past week.
lead_paragraph: Hi Wordlers! Welcome to Wordle Wrap-Up, a reminder of which words were answers this week. For stories, stats and brain teasers, sign up for the Gameplay newsletter. For a daily reminder to play Wordle, sign up for reminders.

headline: $3.5 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Mediterranean-style house in Los Angeles, a three-family building in San Francisco and a five-bedroom home with a guesthouse in Alamo.
lead_paragraph: This house is in Los Feliz, less than 10 minutes from the Griffith Observatory and the Greek Theatre, and close to the hiking trails that wind through Griffith Park. The Dresden, a restaurant and lounge that has been open since 1954, and other dining and shopping options are a 15-minute walk away, on Hillhurst and Vermont Avenues. Two Frank Lloyd Wright houses are also nearby: The Ennis House, a private residence, is a few blocks away, and the Aline Barnsdall Hollyhock House, open to the public, is a five-minute drive.

headline: Wes Bentley Was at Rock Bottom. Now He Is on ‘Yellowstone.’
abstract: Years of addiction and struggle followed his breakout role in “American Beauty.” He lived to tell the tale, and get a major role on TV’s biggest show.
lead_paragraph: It’s not easy being Jamie Dutton.

headline: Wax Cylinders Hold Audio From a Century Ago. The Library Is Listening.
abstract: The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts acquired a machine that transfers recordings from the fragile format. Then a batch of cylinders from a Met Opera librarian arrived.
lead_paragraph: The first recording, swathed in sheets of distortion, was nonetheless recognizable as a child’s voice — small, nervous, encouraged by his father — wishing a very Merry Christmas to whoever was listening.

headline: It’s Time to Say Goodbye to Lush Lawns
abstract: The environmental damage of lawns is far worse than most people imagine. Also: Migrant crisis; arms for Ukraine; FTX and political donations.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Lashana Lynch Challenges the ‘Strong Black Woman’ Cliché, Softly
abstract: She plays a ferocious warrior in “The Woman King,” but in her performance, vulnerability and humanity were what she sought to convey.
lead_paragraph: When Lashana Lynch learned that the filmmaker Gina Prince-Bythewood wanted to talk to her about a project, she was ready to say yes, whatever it was.

headline: This Land Becomes Their Land. New U.S. Citizens Hit a 15-Year High
abstract: Nearly one million immigrants became Americans in 2022 after the pandemic delayed the process and prevented hundreds of thousands of people from voting in the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: On a windswept morning last spring, Mom Leveille slipped into a flowing red dress and high-heeled sandals and headed to a ballpark in Brooklyn, her nerves jangled. A Cambodian refugee, Ms. Leveille had applied for U.S. citizenship nearly two years earlier, and, finally, the moment was nigh when she would take a permanent oath of allegiance to the country where her family had found safe haven.

headline: Dubai Suspends Alcohol Tax as Regional Competition Heats Up
abstract: Lower-cost liquor could help the emirate keep its edge over neighbors like Saudi Arabia and Qatar as the Middle East’s hub for leisure and business.
lead_paragraph: Dubai started the new year by suspending its 30 percent tax on alcohol, a move that could help the Gulf emirate attract more tourists and businesses amid growing regional competition.

headline: McCarthy’s Bid for Speaker Remains in Peril Even After Key Concessions
abstract: Representative Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California, is struggling to break through a wall of entrenched opposition from hard-right lawmakers even after agreeing to weaken his leadership power.
lead_paragraph: Follow for the latest on the battle to choose a speaker in the House of Representatives.

headline: Resolve to Eat All the Delicious Foods
abstract: A cooking trick from egg drop soup gives these velvety scrambled eggs the dreamy factor, canned beans make quick work of dinner, and more inspiration for the new year.
lead_paragraph: Happy New Year! Do you make New Year’s resolutions? I’ve made quite a few, some of which have even stuck. I resolved to run at least a mile every day in 2020, which I did for 366 days (I didn’t realize it was a leap year when I committed). I still manage to run about six times a week; my tipsy resolution blossomed into a clear-minded habit. Even when it’s 10 degrees out and I have to bundle in so many layers that my “run” resembles a kind of zippy waddle, I come back a calmer, happier person.

headline: A Chorus of Hopes for 2023
abstract: A mayor, a veteran and others share their visions for the coming year.
lead_paragraph: I outsourced my first newsletter of 2023. I asked a variety of people, from many walks of life, both from the United States and abroad, to share their hopes for the new year. The results were so fascinating that I’m thinking of making this into an annual feature. Here’s what people wrote (or, in one case, said).

headline: Dare to Survive
abstract: I came to document Tracy McCarter’s experiences in court because I wanted to see how the criminal justice system works.
lead_paragraph: In 2021 the New York City Mayor’s Office to End Domestic and Gender-Based Violence commissioned me to create a public art piece about the criminalization of survivors. I’ve dedicated my life as a photographer to documenting domestic violence.

headline: Ronald Feldman, Art Gallerist With an Eye for Politics, Dies at 84
abstract: A former lawyer, he showcased artists who tackled issues like women’s rights, the environment, totalitarianism and war.
lead_paragraph: Ronald Feldman, who for nearly 50 years oversaw one of New York’s most consistently political, forward-looking art galleries, died on Dec. 20 at his home in Chappaqua, N.Y. He was 84.

headline: To Buff a Balkan Leader’s Image, a Filmmaker Calls In Kevin Spacey
abstract: A director cast the beleaguered actor as Franjo Tudjman, the late Croatian leader, whom some call a patriot and others revile as an ethnonationalist zealot.
lead_paragraph: A hagiographic movie about the stiff former leader of a small Balkan country was never going to be a global box-office hit. But its director, a former water polo champion turned darling of right-wing Croatian cinema, found a novel way to generate some buzz: He cast Kevin Spacey as its star.

headline: A U.S.-made long-range rocket system has helped give Ukraine momentum in the war.
abstract: Washington delivered the first batch of truck-mounted, multiple-rocket launchers, known as HIMARS,
lead_paragraph: Since the earliest weeks of the war, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has pleaded to any government that would listen that his country was outgunned by Russia’s army. If Ukraine was going to survive, he said, it needed longer range weapons.

headline: Here Are the House Republicans to Watch if McCarthy’s Bid for Speaker Falters
abstract: Representative Kevin McCarthy has so far faced no viable challenger for the speakership. But if he is unable to secure the votes, an alternative could quickly emerge.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A big factor in Representative Kevin McCarthy’s favor as he labors to become speaker of the House is that no viable candidate has emerged to challenge him.

headline: Tesla Car Sales Grow Slower Than Expected, Amplifying Concerns
abstract: Wall Street has grown decidedly pessimistic about Tesla, fearful that Elon Musk, its chief executive, is too focused on Twitter.

headline: Islamic Extremism Drove Suspect in Times Square Attack, Official Says
abstract: Trevor Bickford, a 19-year-old from Maine, had recently become radicalized and traveled to New York to attack the police, according to a law enforcement official.
lead_paragraph: The man charged with attacking three police officers with a machete near Times Square on New Year’s Eve had traveled to New York from his home in Maine to injure the police in an act of Islamic extremism, a senior law enforcement official said on Monday.

headline: Biden Caps Two Years of Action on the Economy, With New Challenges Ahead
abstract: The president used a slim congressional majority to enact legislation that could reshape the American economy — if his administration can make the laws succeed.
lead_paragraph: ST. CROIX, V.I. — President Biden briefly interrupted a holiday island vacation last week to sign into law a $1.7 trillion government spending bill, capping a two-year rush of legislative activity that has the potential to reshape the American economy and place Mr. Biden among the most economically consequential presidents of the last century.

headline: Benedict’s Death Leaves Catholic Conservatives Bereft
abstract: Even after his resignation as pope, traditionalists invoked Benedict’s name and sought to draw him into internecine ideological wars. Now he is gone.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — As thousands of Roman Catholics flowed into St. Peter’s Basilica on Monday morning to see Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI lie in state and pay their last respects, bereft conservatives mourned the loss of a leader who championed the traditions, doctrines and church law and order they cherished.

headline: ‘Avatar’ and the Headache of High Frame Rate Filmmaking
abstract: Why do James Cameron and others experiment with this? Intended to eliminate blur, it is actually unnerving in scenes involving humans or real objects.
lead_paragraph: For all the praise lavished on how convincing, immersive and detailed Pandora looks in “Avatar: The Way of Water,” one aspect of the imagery is intensely distracting: the director James Cameron’s use of a high frame rate. If you saw the movie at a top-notch theater and noticed that certain moments had the glossy, almost hyper-real veneer of a soap opera, that is because he is employing a tool that no filmmaker has yet succeeded in making appealing at scale.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: A Major Ukrainian Strike
abstract: Also, China’s uncertain economic recovery.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine launched a major attack against a building housing Russian soldiers in the Donetsk region on New Year’s Day.

headline: To Find Happiness, Try Talking to Strangers
abstract: A new project by the Well desk is challenging readers to strengthen their relationships and form new ones.
lead_paragraph: The findings from the longest-running in-depth study on human happiness are decisive: Our interpersonal relationships are critical to our well-being. The study, from researchers at Harvard, found that strong social bonds make people happier and feel more fulfilled than money or I.Q. do.

headline: ‘Long Live the King:’ Brazil Lines Up to Honor Pelé
abstract: Thousands of Brazilians came out to pay their respects to an athlete that put their nation on the world stage.
lead_paragraph: At 6 a.m. on New Year’s Day, Antônio da Paz boarded a bus for the funeral of the soccer icon Pelé and rode the four hours to Santos, Brazil, where his idol was set to lie in state.

headline: A Lethal Start to 2023
abstract: Russia says 63 servicemen were killed in the Donbas, one of Moscow’s biggest losses in a strike.
lead_paragraph: Welcome back to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: California Storm Takes Aim at Midwest
abstract: California is still cleaning up from flooding and mudslides caused by a powerful storm system, that is now heading East.
lead_paragraph: California is still cleaning up from flooding and mudslides caused by a powerful storm system, that is now heading East.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Brazilian Authorities Will Revive Fraud Case Against George Santos
abstract: A 2008 court case had been suspended because Brazilian law enforcement officials could not find Mr. Santos.
lead_paragraph: When Representative-elect George Santos takes his seat in Congress on Tuesday, he will do so under the shadow of active investigations by federal and local prosecutors into potential criminal activity during his two congressional campaigns.

headline: Gangsta Boo, Memphis Rapper Formerly With Three 6 Mafia, Dies at 43
abstract: Born Lola Chantrelle Mitchell, she was one of the first female rappers to build off the gangster rap image and sound that took off in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Lola Chantrelle Mitchell, the Memphis rapper and former member of Three 6 Mafia who, as Gangsta Boo, helped define Southern rap with her confident flows and forged a path for other female artists, died on Sunday in Memphis. She was 43.

headline: Remote Florida Archipelago Closes After Hundreds of Migrants Arrive
abstract: Dry Tortugas National Park will close for “several days” so that authorities and medical workers can evaluate, care for and transport some 300 migrants, park officials said.
lead_paragraph: A remote archipelago and national park off the coast of Key West, Fla., was closed Monday after a group of around 300 migrants arrived by boat on the islands’ shores, park officials said.

headline: Deadly Strike on Russians in Ukraine Exposes Moscow’s Military Failings
abstract: A Ukrainian attack with U.S.-made rockets may have left hundreds of casualties, and pro-war Russians accused their military commanders of repeating fatal errors.
lead_paragraph: In one of their deadliest attacks yet on Russian forces, Ukrainians used American-made rockets to kill dozens — and perhaps hundreds — of Moscow’s troops in a New Year’s Day strike behind the lines, prompting outraged Russian war hawks to accuse their military of lethal incompetence.

headline: We’re Going to Miss Greed and Cynicism
abstract: We’ll be nostalgic for the days when the culture war was phony.
lead_paragraph: It’s 2023. What will the new year bring? The answer, of course, is that we don’t know. There are a fair number of what Donald Rumsfeld (remember him?) called “known unknowns” — for example, nobody really knows how hard it will be to reduce inflation or whether the U.S. economy will experience a recession. There are also unknown unknowns: Will we see another shock like Russia’s invasion of Ukraine?

headline: After Boycott from Law Schools, U.S. News & World Report Changes Ranking System
abstract: The magazine, which has been rating top schools for decades, said in a letter to deans that it is altering its methods to address their concerns.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure amid a boycott by top law schools, U.S. News & World Report told law school deans on Monday that it will make several changes in the next edition of its influential ratings.

headline: Trying to Trademark ‘Rigged Election,’ and Other Revelations From the Jan. 6 Transcripts
abstract: The Jan. 6 committee released a whirlwind of documents in its final days and wrapped up its work on Monday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top military officer saw the Jan. 6 attack as similar to the “Reichstag moment” that led to Nazi dictatorship. Aides for former President Donald J. Trump saw their future job opportunities slipping away, and predicted being “perpetually unemployed.” Mr. Trump himself saw the push to overturn the 2020 election as a financial opportunity, moving to trademark the phrase “Rigged Election.”

headline: Day 2: The Secret Power of the 8-Minute Phone Call
abstract: Even a brief chat has measurable effects on our well-being.
lead_paragraph: I just had an eight-minute call with my good friend Tina, whom I’ve known for over three decades. I could never seem to connect with her (she has a very demanding job) until I sent her a text last week proposing an eight-minute phone call.

headline: Damar Hamlin of Buffalo Bills in Critical Condition After Collapsing During N.F.L. Game
abstract: Hamlin, a 24-year-old safety, went into cardiac arrest after being hit, but his heartbeat was restored by medical personnel, the Bills said. The game against the Cincinnati Bengals was postponed.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Damar Hamlin, a 24-year-old safety in his second season with the Buffalo Bills, was in critical condition in a hospital after going into cardiac arrest during a Monday night game against the Cincinnati Bengals, the Bills said.

headline: Penn State Beats Utah, as the Rose Bowl Marks the End of an Era
abstract: The recent agreement to expand the College Football Playoff, to 12 teams from four, has threatened not just the Rose Bowl’s pre-eminent status among bowl games but also its relevance.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — For months, beginning with workouts in the dog days of summer, continuing through the first chill of autumn and into the fraught moments that November football always brings, college football teams with any ambition look toward a distant goal: the playoff.

headline: Q&A Session
abstract: Start-up your Tuesday with this puzzle by Margaret Seikel.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Pennsylvania Police Chief Killed and Officer Injured in Shooting
abstract: A man who was accused of shooting the officers later stole a vehicle, and he was fatally shot after an exchange of gunfire with the police.
lead_paragraph: A police chief was fatally shot and an officer was wounded outside Pittsburgh on Monday during the pursuit of a suspect wanted for a probation violation, Allegheny County authorities said.

headline: Fred White, Drummer for Earth, Wind & Fire, Dies at 67
abstract: He provided the beat on unforgettable hits like “September,” “Let’s Groove,” “Shining Star” and “Boogie Wonderland.”
lead_paragraph: Fred White, who as a drummer with Earth, Wind & Fire propelled some of the funkiest songs in pop history, helping to provide a soundtrack to the nation’s weddings, bar mitzvahs, high school reunions and any other function at which people of all ages dance, died on Sunday. He was 67.

headline: On His Way to the N.F.L., Damar Hamlin Was Determined to Give Back
abstract: Hamlin, a Buffalo Bills safety who went into cardiac arrest during a game Monday night, asserted himself as a leader in high school — and kept going back to help others after he graduated.
lead_paragraph: Inside the stone walls of Pittsburgh’s Central Catholic High School, where students at the all-boys school must stash their phones in lockers and ties and collared shirts are required, it is easy to forget that the adjustment to such a place would be challenging for some teenagers.

headline: In Romania, U.S. Troops Train Close to Russia’s War, in Signal to Moscow
abstract: The deployment to a NATO country near the conflict in Ukraine is seen as a model of deterrence for a U.S. military that has recently stepped back from direct fighting.
lead_paragraph: MIHAIL KOGALNICEANU AIR BASE, Romania — The soldiers of the U.S. Army’s 101st Airborne Division train, eat and sleep on a drab, sprawling post in southeast Romania, a mere seven-minute rocket flight from where Russia has stockpiled munitions in Crimea.

headline: A Laundry List of New Laws for the New Year
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul has issued a 12-page list of legislation that will take effect in 2023, including minimum wage raises and changes in how you can cast your ballot.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday, the first workday of the new year. We’ll look at a few things that changed over the weekend — besides the calendar.

headline: Quotation of the Day: How War in Ukraine Worsens Global Starvation
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 3, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “By attacking Ukraine, the breadbasket of the world, Putin is attacking the world’s poor.”

headline: Athletes and Fans Pray for Damar Hamlin After On-Field Collapse
abstract: Gov. Phil Murphy of New Jersey joined a chorus of voices on Twitter offering prayers for Hamlin. “We are all Buffalo Bills fans tonight,” Mr. Murphy said.
lead_paragraph: Athletes, public figures and fans alike took to social media on Monday to share prayers and concern for Buffalo Bills safety Damar Hamlin after he collapsed on the field during a game.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: A major strike on Russian troops.
lead_paragraph: In a deadly attack on New Year’s Day, Ukrainians used American-made long-range HIMARS rockets to kill dozens — and perhaps hundreds — of Moscow’s troops in the occupied city of Makiivka, in eastern Ukraine. The strike prompted outraged Russian war hawks to accuse their military of lethal incompetence.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 3, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Jan. 3, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about Brazil’s inauguration of its new president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, misstated the distance between Brazil’s capital, Brasília, and Orlando, Fla. It is roughly 6,000 kilometers (about 3,700 miles), not 6,000 miles.

headline: What These 11 Cops Think People Don’t Understand About Crime
abstract: Law enforcement agents speak with Times Opinion about what policing is like in America today.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement agents speak with Times Opinion about what policing is like in America today.

headline: I May Have Started a Rumor About K-Pop, and It May Be Ruining My Life
abstract: I wrote a book about Korean pop culture, and that’s when things started to get crazy.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean boy band BTS has been low-key ruining my life for years.

headline: Word of the Day: abjure
abstract: This word has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word abjure has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 15 in the book review “Courtly Love Can Be Deadly” by Tina Brown:

headline: Space and Astronomy: What to Expect in 2023
abstract: Solar eclipses, new rockets and new space telescopes are some of the ways that the year ahead will try to follow an exciting 2022 in orbit and beyond.
lead_paragraph: As years in space and astronomy go, 2022 is going to be a tough act to follow.

headline: Your 2023 Most-Anticipated List
abstract: What are you looking forward to this year?
lead_paragraph: What's coming up this year that you’re excited about? A trip you’re planning? A friend who is coming to visit? A class you’re taking? Something you plan to make? A TV show or movie that’s coming out soon? Anything at all can go on your list.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Trump-DeSantis Showdown Could Supercharge Latino Evangelicals’ Influence
abstract: In Florida, where Hispanic evangelicals carry outsize influence, many of their pastors view the budding 2024 rivalry as a sign of the potency of their unabashedly politicized Christianity.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida hasn’t announced he’s running for president yet. But among the right-leaning voting blocs that are pulling for him to enter the 2024 primary field are some of his biggest fans: Hispanic evangelical Christians.

headline: Legal Use of Hallucinogenic Mushrooms Begins in Oregon
abstract: On Jan. 1, Oregon became the first state to allow adult use of psilocybin “magic” mushrooms. Licensed guides will likely determine whether the program is a success.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The curriculum was set, the students were enrolled and Oregon officials had signed off on nearly every detail of training for the first class of “magic” mushroom facilitators seeking state certification.

headline: Wave of Job-Switching Has Employers on a Training Treadmill
abstract: The rise in turnover since the pandemic started has a cost in productivity: “It’s taking longer to get stuff out the door.”
lead_paragraph: One after another, employees at the New Hampshire manufacturer W.H. Bagshaw said goodbye.

headline: Hard-Line Israeli Minister Visits Volatile Jerusalem Holy Site
abstract: Itamar Ben-Gvir, the ultranationalist national security minister, toured the site just days after taking office, drawing a furious reaction from Palestinian leaders.
lead_paragraph: In one of his first acts as Israel’s minister of national security, the ultranationalist Itamar Ben-Gvir on Tuesday made a provocative visit to a Jerusalem holy site sacred to Jews and Muslims, defying threats of repercussions from the militant group Hamas and eliciting a furious reaction from the Palestinian leadership and condemnations from the Arab world.

headline: Lesson Plan: ‘How a Visual Language Evolves as Our World Does’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn how video technology and social media have given deaf people a new way to communicate and how it is transforming American Sign Language.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “How a Visual Language Evolves as Our World Does” by Amanda Morris Videos by Mohamed Sadek and Ege Soyuer

headline: At Least 51 Dead in the Philippines After Holiday Flooding
abstract: Heavy rains on Christmas Day killed dozens of people and left thousands displaced. For a deeply Catholic nation, the timing heightened the sense of tragedy.
lead_paragraph: Across the Philippines, the 2022 holiday season was meant to be a time for celebration and a relief after two Christmases tarnished by punishing coronavirus lockdowns. But on the southern Philippine island of Mindanao, families faced tragedy on Christmas Day when rains triggered flooding and landslides, killing at least 51 people and displacing thousands, the authorities said.

headline: Have You Made Any New Year’s Resolutions?
abstract: Do you find it easy or difficult to set goals and achieve them?
lead_paragraph: Are you using the New Year as a starting point for any changes you’d like to make to your life, routines or attitudes? If so, how will you motivate yourself to keep your resolutions? How do you expect your efforts to go this year?

headline: New Year, New (State) Rules
abstract: State laws take effect for bouncers in Tennessee, walkers in California, and governors in North Carolina. Here’s a roundup of several key changes across the nation.
lead_paragraph: Change is in the air, but unlike New Year’s resolutions, Americans will have to abide by new laws in 2023 that were passed by state legislatures and approved by governors, or ballot measures passed by voters.

headline: How a Bit of Awe Can Improve Your Health
abstract: Experts say wonder is an essential human emotion — and a salve for a turbulent mind.
lead_paragraph: Awe can mean many things. It can be witnessing a total solar eclipse. Or seeing your child take her first steps. Or hearing Lizzo perform live. But, while many of us know it when we feel it, awe is not easy to define.

headline: The Key to Success in College Is So Simple, It’s Almost Never Mentioned
abstract: Students must be willing to learn.
lead_paragraph: For Emily Zurek Small, college did what it’s supposed to do. Growing up in a small town in northeastern Pennsylvania, she had career and intellectual ambitions for which college is the clearest pathway. “I just kind of always wanted to learn,” she told me recently. “I wanted to be able to have intelligent conversations with people and know about the world.”

headline: House G.O.P. Paralyzed on Day 1 as Right Wing Blocks McCarthy Speakership
abstract: On the first day of the new Congress, Representative Kevin McCarthy fell short repeatedly in his bid to become speaker as a right-wing rebellion prompted a historic floor fight.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans were deadlocked on Tuesday over who would lead their new majority after Representative Kevin McCarthy of California lost three votes for the top job, as hard-right lawmakers in open revolt dealt their party leader a humiliating setback and prompted a historic struggle on the House floor.

headline: Who Are the Republicans Opposing McCarthy’s Speaker Bid?
abstract: The rebellion has been led by a small but vocal group of ultraconservative Republicans. But there are other, less-known defectors who could help scuttle the G.O.P. leader’s candidacy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some of the hard-right lawmakers opposing Representative Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California, for speaker have nursed grudges against him for years. Others have not even been sworn in to Congress yet.

headline: Heavy Snowfall and Tornadoes Wreak Havoc on Midwest and South
abstract: A “multi-hazard” storm that had already flooded the West Coast turned into a large winter storm system as it moved across the country.
lead_paragraph: A pounding stretch of rain, wind and snow continued its destructive path east through the Midwestern and Southern states on Tuesday, bringing heavy rain and snow to much of the central United States and tornadoes to the South after drenching California over the weekend.

headline: A Con Man Is Succeeding Me in Congress Today
abstract: Now we know that no one voted for the real George Santos.
lead_paragraph: Today is my last day as a member of Congress, and George Santos is about to be sworn in to take the seat I held for six years. He will take an oath to “bear true faith” to the Constitution and take this obligation without any “purpose of evasion.” I’ve lost track of how many evasions and lies Mr. Santos has told about himself, his finances and his history and relationship with our stretch of Long Island and northeastern Queens. When he is seated, it will diminish our Congress, our country and my constituents — soon his constituents. It saddens me that after 30 years of public service rooted in hard work and service to the people of this area, I’m being succeeded by a con man.

headline: Sabbath and the Art of Rest
abstract: Judith Shulevitz shares the wisdom of the Sabbath and its offering to a modern world that struggles to unplug.
lead_paragraph: Do we know how to truly rest? Who would we be if we did?

headline: Frank James Pleads Guilty to Terrorism in Brooklyn Subway Attack
abstract: The defendant, who unleashed a barrage of gunfire on the subway last April, faces a possible life sentence.
lead_paragraph: Charged with shooting 10 people last April in one of the worst attacks in recent years on the New York subway, Frank R. James shuffled slowly into federal court in Brooklyn on Tuesday afternoon, escorted by three federal marshals.

headline: ‘Entire Body Is Shaking’: Why Americans With Chronic Pain Are Dying
abstract: American medicine and law enforcement continue to fight the last opioid war.
lead_paragraph: Anne Fuqua keeps a list of suicide deaths. She’s chronicled hundreds of cases of chronic pain sufferers who have killed themselves after losing access to opioid medication since 2014. Recently, she almost became an entry.

headline: George Santos Came to Washington. It Was Awkward.
abstract: On the first day of the 118th Congress, the representative-elect, a Republican who has made false claims about his background, education and finances, brought his saga to Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hounded by reporters whom he labored to avoid and shunned by members of his own party, George Santos, Republican representative-elect of New York, spent his first day in Congress as an outcast.

headline: One Indelible Scene: A Donkey’s Escape in ‘EO’
abstract: The animal, reared in a circus, enters into a forest and a world of wild animals. For the first and only time in the movie, he is free.
lead_paragraph: About a third into his story, the hero of “EO” — a small gray donkey — trots into a forest. It’s foreign territory for this charming beast, who once performed in a circus and is accustomed to human companionship. It’s also an important destination for EO, who’s named for the braying sounds he sometimes makes and who is on an astonishing and revelatory odyssey, a voyage that says much about both this one plaintive animal and our deeply unkind world.

headline: What Is the Right Balance of Strength Training to Cardio?
abstract: We spoke to exercise experts to find the ideal regimen.
lead_paragraph: Q: How much cardiovascular exercise versus strength training should I do each week?

headline: Why Japan’s Sudden Shift on Bond Purchases Dealt a Global Jolt
abstract: The world has relied on ultralow interest rates in Japan. What will happen if they rise?
lead_paragraph: Japan is the world’s largest creditor. At the end of 2021, it held roughly $3.2 trillion in foreign assets, 30 percent more than No. 2 Germany. As of October, it owned over a trillion dollars of U.S. government debt, more than China. Japanese banks are the world’s largest cross-border lenders, with nearly $4.8 trillion in claims in other countries.

headline: Decorating a Room? Don’t Forget the Ceiling.
abstract: Most people give it a coat of white paint and then forget all about it. That’s a missed opportunity.
lead_paragraph: When you’re decorating a room, it’s easy to obsess over what’s covering the floor and the walls. But what about the ceiling?

headline: Paralyzed by Gun Violence, They Seek Solace From Other Survivors
abstract: Gunfire in America has left a growing number of people with long-term disabilities. In one city, a support group that includes people who spent time in the same trauma ward offers a way to cope.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, N.Y. — Three years after a former boyfriend kicked down her door, fired a gun at her nine times and left her paralyzed, Porche Powell steeled herself for a virtual visit to the hospital ward where she had spent long weeks in recovery.

headline: The Pelosi Era Comes to a Close
abstract: The first woman to become speaker leaves a legacy that will be difficult for her successors to equal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a popular Democratic president in the White House and big Democratic majorities in Congress, an emboldened Speaker Nancy Pelosi in 2009 pushed through a major climate change measure despite warnings of a political backlash.

headline: Blood, Guts and Dinner
abstract: Skinning wood pigeon? Cutting up rabbit? At a course designed to teach butchery and foraging, a writer feels closer to the primal experience of cooking — and eating. It’s a sensation more travelers are looking for.
lead_paragraph: In the Before Times, a classic whip-up-three-courses-in-a-pastoral-location type of cooking class was enough.

headline: Is a Dam in Rural Portugal a Key to Our Alternative Energy Future?
abstract: When the Portuguese electric power grid needs more electricity, a large multinational power company releases millions of gallons of water from a dammed reservoir.
lead_paragraph: When Portugal’s electrical system needs a boost, a signal activates a power plant buried deep in a hillside in the country’s scrubby, pine-covered north. Inside the man-made cavern, valves, nine feet in diameter, suddenly open, allowing water draining from a reservoir four miles away to begin streaming through four massive turbines.

headline: Japan’s Business Owners Can’t Find Successors. This Man Is Giving His Away.
abstract: An owner’s struggle in Japan’s northern dairy region illuminates one of the potentially devastating economic impacts of an aging society.
lead_paragraph: Hidekazu Yokoyama has spent three decades building a thriving logistics business on Japan’s snowy northern island of Hokkaido, an area that provides much of the country’s milk.

headline: ‘The Unheard Symphony of the Planet’
abstract: Using a tiny device called a Raspberry Shake, people around the world are tuning in to the earth’s vibrations.
lead_paragraph: Everything felt still while Marc Cesaire, a high school earth science teacher, watched a livestream of the Rolling Loud hip-hop festival at Citi Field from his apartment a few miles away in Queens, N.Y.

headline: Deadly strike on Russians in Ukraine exposes Moscow’s military failings.
abstract: In one of their deadliest attacks yet on Russian forces, Ukrainians used American-made rockets to kill dozens — and perhaps hundreds — of Moscow’s troops in a New Year’s Day strike behind the lines, prompting outraged Russian war hawks to accuse their military of lethal incompetence.
lead_paragraph: In one of their deadliest attacks yet on Russian forces, Ukrainians used American-made rockets to kill dozens — and perhaps hundreds — of Moscow’s troops in a New Year’s Day strike behind the lines, prompting outraged Russian war hawks to accuse their military of lethal incompetence.

headline: A Crisis of Kevin McCarthy’s Own Making
abstract: Why is there still a bitter fight over who will lead the House Republicans?
lead_paragraph: This episode contains strong language.

headline: Democracy Fights Back
abstract: Last year’s democratic wins could have big implications.
lead_paragraph: Imagine if the U.S. and its allies had reacted less aggressively to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Without Western weapons to bolster its defenses, Ukraine could have fallen. Without Western sanctions, Russia might have felt little economic pressure. Such inaction would have sent a message: Western powers won’t stand up for other democracies.

headline: China Denounces Covid Testing Rules Imposed on Its Travelers
abstract: A government spokeswoman said Beijing would consider reciprocal measures against countries that have sought to limit travelers arriving from China.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese government on Tuesday denounced Covid testing requirements imposed by other countries on travelers arriving from China as unscientific or “excessive,” and threatened to take countermeasures.

headline: How Sam Bankman-Fried Negotiated His Way Out of Jail
abstract: Intense legal wrangling led to the disgraced crypto mogul paying virtually nothing to live with his parents ahead of his upcoming trial. He returns to court on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Andrew here. Happy New Year and welcome back to DealBook. We’re looking forward to a big 2023.

headline: Ken Block, Rally Driver and YouTube Stuntman, Dies at 55
abstract: The acclaimed driver, best known for his “Gymkhana” videos, was killed in a snowmobile accident.
lead_paragraph: Ken Block, a sports marketing executive who took the wheel for himself and became an acclaimed pro rally driver and YouTube stuntman, died on Monday in a snowmobile accident. He was 55.

headline: Top French Film Awards Bar Nominees Investigated on Sexual Violence Charges
abstract: The César Academy’s decision is its latest effort to improve its image after years marked by abuse scandals.
