headline: U.F.C. and Partners Reluctant to Speak On Dana White Slapping His Wife
abstract: White, the president of the U.F.C., slapped his wife during an argument at a nightclub on Jan. 1. Since then, he has faced almost no consequences.
lead_paragraph: Three days after TMZ published a video of Dana White, the president of the Ultimate Fighting Championship, slapping his wife at a nightclub, neither the U.F.C. nor its most important partners are signaling that any meaningful consequences are coming for White.

headline: N.F.L. Cancels Bills-Bengals Game
abstract: The league announced that it would not resume the Monday night matchup that was postponed after Buffalo safety Damar Hamlin collapsed on the field in Cincinnati.
lead_paragraph: The game between the Buffalo Bills and the Cincinnati Bengals that was suspended Monday night after the Bills’ Damar Hamlin collapsed on the field will not be completed, the N.F.L. announced Thursday. N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell called the decision to cancel the game “difficult, but necessary” under the “extraordinary circumstances.”

headline: Major Crimes Rose 22 Percent in New York City, Even as Shootings Fell
abstract: Homicides fell last year to their lowest level since 2019, before the pandemic, but other categories of crime, including robbery and burglary, drove the overall increase compared with 2021.
lead_paragraph: Surges in robbery, burglary and other crimes drove a 22 percent increase in overall major crime in New York City last year compared with the year prior, despite a significant drop in shootings and murders.

headline: Day 5: The Importance of Work Friends
abstract: People who are close to their colleagues are happier and more productive.
lead_paragraph: This is Day 5 of Well’s 7-day Happiness Challenge. To start at the beginning, click here.

headline: Michigan State Football Player Who Hit Rival Pleads Guilty to Misdemeanors
abstract: On Oct. 29, Khary Crump, a cornerback for the Spartans, swung his helmet and hit an opposing player inside Michigan Stadium.
lead_paragraph: A Michigan State football player who had been facing a felony charge for striking an opposing player with his helmet during a skirmish inside the stadium’s tunnel last season pleaded guilty on Thursday to misdemeanors, his lawyer said.

headline: Pet Dogs and Cats
abstract: Erica Hsiung Wojcik opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Variety: Building Blocks
abstract: Will Shortz provides the materials for three intricate structures.
lead_paragraph: BUILDING BLOCKS — This puzzle is an interesting and unusual challenge to a solver’s vocabulary and powers of deduction. Although it is visually intuitive, working through it takes some creativity.

headline: Democrats Face Obstacles in Plan to Reorder Presidential Primary Calendar
abstract: The party is radically reshuffling the early-state order, but Georgia and New Hampshire present challenges.
lead_paragraph: Democratic efforts to overhaul which states hold the first presidential primaries entered a new and uncertain phase this week, with hurdles to President Biden’s preferred order coming into focus even as several states signaled their abilities to host early contests, a key step in radically reshaping the calendar.

headline: Finding Love Through the Art of Combat
abstract: Meg He felt an immediate connection with Margot Ciccarelli during a private jiu-jitsu lesson more than three years ago.
lead_paragraph: Before it was ever put into words, the connection, between Meg He and Margot Ciccarelli was apparent from their movements.

headline: A Web Between Her Body and Mine
abstract: For decades we connected nearly every day. One terrible moment changed all that.
lead_paragraph: The nurse had to unwrap the bandages that were holding the skin grafts in place in order for Miriam to use the bathroom. I had just arrived at the hospital — the first nonfamily visitor since the accident — and my timing was such that I got to see my best friend naked for the first time in our many years together.

headline: A Train Mix-Up Leads to an Unexpected Connection
abstract: Elizabeth Gregory and Charles Aoki bonded while waiting on the platform for almost an hour for the wrong train.
lead_paragraph: Charles Nelson Aoki likes to joke that on the first night he hung out with Elizabeth Grace Gregory in April 2017, he “technically kidnapped her.”

headline: Pajamas and Wet Hair Led to Love at First Sight
abstract: When Erik Ostberg spotted Grey O’Reilly on a couch, he said, “I loved everything about what I saw.”
lead_paragraph: The first time Erik William Ostberg saw Grey Alexandra O’Reilly she was sitting on a couch in her pajamas, feet curled under her, hair still wet from a recent shower. And, as might be expected of a woman who grew up in Ireland, she was sipping a cup of tea.

headline: Across Continents, Two Doctors Find Romance
abstract: Dr. Femi Kuti and Dr. Ugochi Nwosu met in the Bay Area but soon entered a relationship that stretched from Lagos, Nigeria, to the United States.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Oluwafemi Akinwale Kuti Jr. was only visiting California for a few months — but what he found was a long-term love.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Era of 2 Popes Is Laid to Rest, If Not Its Rifts
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Jan. 6, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I am in pain as if I had lost my own father. As a Pole, I loved John Paul II, obviously, but Benedict was my spiritual guide, my moral compass.”

headline: Corrections: Jan. 6, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Jan. 6, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s promises to restore Britain’s health system and economy misstated the name of the country’s health care system. It is the National Health Service, not the National Health System. The error was repeated in a summary.

headline: Trump Is Sued in Death of Capitol Police Officer After Jan. 6
abstract: The suit in the death of Brian D. Sicknick seeks millions in damages from the former president, whom it paints as responsible for the violence that day, and two Capitol rioters.
lead_paragraph: Jan. 6: This article was updated with a response from a spokesperson for former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Responses to Russia’s ordering of a cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin, the Russian leader, ordered a unilateral cease-fire for Russian troops from midday today to the end of tomorrow to observe the Orthodox Christmas, according to the Kremlin. Ukrainian officials dismissed the move as a “banal trick” and a “propaganda gesture,” pointing out that Russia had bombarded civilians on Christmas Eve and New Year’s Eve.

headline: A Rat Killer Has Some Advice for Mayor Adams
abstract: Solving the problem of the infestation around the mayor’s Brooklyn property is not necessarily simple, an expert in rodenticide says.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Mayor Eric Adams has a residential rat problem. We’ll hear what someone who has spent more than 40 years in the pest-control business would advise the mayor to do.

headline: Word of the Day: precept
abstract: This word has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word precept has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 19 in “You’re Never Too Old for a Miniskirt” by Ruth La Ferla:

headline: Was Abraham Lincoln a Social Media Influencer?
abstract: Our 16th president, an early adopter of his era’s newest technology, has a lot in common with today’s Instagram and TikTok stars.
lead_paragraph: Abraham Lincoln loved kittens and smelled of wood smoke; he recited Shakespeare and told dirty jokes; he used “compromise and cunning and occasional cruelty,” as Adam Gopnik once put it, to achieve great things. Now, with the arrival of Leonard S. Marcus’s meticulously researched “Mr. Lincoln Sits for His Portrait,” we can add yet another facet to our 16th president’s complicated character: media manipulator.

headline: The Dreyfus Affair Revisited
abstract: On the 125th anniversary of “J’Accuse,” a picture book for older kids places the lives of Alfred Dreyfus and Émile Zola side by side.
lead_paragraph: The Dreyfus Affair never ceases to fascinate, yet its twists and turns often make it hard to grasp. The outline seems clear: At the turn of the 20th century, a Jewish officer in the French Army was falsely convicted of passing military secrets to the Germans and imprisoned on Devil’s Island, off the coast of South America. France was divided over whether he was guilty or innocent, one side being largely monarchist and Catholic, the other liberal and Republican (in the French sense). The dramatic climax came when France’s great novelist Émile Zola — 125 years ago, on Jan. 13, 1898 — published an article headlined “J’Accuse,” in the form of an open letter to the president, claiming that not only was Alfred Dreyfus innocent but the reason he had been found guilty was that he was a Jew and there had been a high-level conspiracy to frame him. Zola was accused of libel, but rather than let him face probable imprisonment his friends put him on a train to England, where he sat glumly eating boiled potatoes while lamenting the hostility he had faced personally and the state of France’s democracy.

headline: Late Night Finds More Laughs in Kevin McCarthy’s Third Day of Failure
abstract: Jimmy Kimmel says he “can’t wait for Lin-Manuel Miranda to make a musical out of it.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Waving
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of — or use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by the illustration.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Two Years Later, Prosecutions of Jan. 6 Rioters Continue to Grow
abstract: The Justice Department’s investigation of the Capitol attack, already the largest it has ever conducted, has resulted in 900 arrests, with the potential for scores or hundreds more to come.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The investigation into the storming of the Capitol is, by any measure, the biggest criminal inquiry in the Justice Department’s 153-year history.

headline: Even a Soft Landing for the Economy May Be Uneven
abstract: Small businesses and lower-income families could feel pinched in the months ahead whether or not a recession is avoided this year.
lead_paragraph: One of the defining economic stories of the past year was the complex debate over whether the U.S. economy was going into a recession or merely descending, with some altitude sickness, from a peak in growth after pandemic lows.

headline: Battered and Strained by War, Ukraine’s Economy Adapts to Survive
abstract: After 10 months of Russian destruction, Ukraine’s economy shrank by 30 percent. But companies have packed up and moved, switched products and found support abroad.
lead_paragraph: Piles of corn and wheat are stuck in silos, as Russia’s invasion stifles critical exports. Metal-producing factories in Ukraine’s bombed-out east have ceased operating. And through nearly a year of war, over a third of Ukraine’s spending is being directed at beating back the enemy.

headline: Can Australia Escape a Recession?
abstract: “Whether it’s a technical recession or not, we certainly are going to be in for difficult times,” one economist said.
lead_paragraph: In September 2020, as the effects of the coronavirus pandemic hit all over the world, Australia dipped briefly into a recession — then bounced straight back out again the following year.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, January 6, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a roundup of what's closing on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a roundup of what's closing on Broadway.

headline: On the Scene: Celebrating Three Kings Day
abstract: In Mexico, friends, families and colleagues get together on Jan. 6, Three Kings Day, to share rosca de reyes and hot chocolate or atole, a Mexican beverage.
lead_paragraph: In Mexico, friends, families and colleagues get together on Jan. 6, Three Kings Day, to share rosca de reyes and hot chocolate or atole, a Mexican beverage.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: This week's titles include sweeping accounts covering the histories of games, clothes and humanity, Jonathan Evison's latest novel and more.
lead_paragraph: This week's titles include sweeping accounts covering the histories of games, clothes and humanity, Jonathan Evison's latest novel and more.

headline: Must We Gentrify the Rest Stop?
abstract: McDonald’s is gone, and the Manhattanization of the New York State Thruway has begun. Prepare to Instagram your pit stop.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, the New York State Thruway Authority conducted a survey of more than 2,600 drivers to take measure of the customer experience at the service areas lining the 570 miles of road that make up one of the largest toll highways in the country, stretching from the edge of the Bronx up past Buffalo. Whether participants were traveling for work or for pleasure, they had needs that apparently were going unfulfilled.

headline: Kevin McCarthy Now Has a Place in the History Books
abstract: In 20 years, will people understand what this House speaker fight was really about?
lead_paragraph: This essay has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: Speaker Quest Reveals McCarthy’s Tenuous Grip on an Unruly Majority
abstract: As the Republican leader has made concessions to the far right, he has effectively agreed to give them carte blanche to disrupt the workings of the House — and to hold him hostage to their demands.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Kevin McCarthy’s historically long slog to become speaker of the House has made one thing abundantly clear: The United States should brace for the likelihood of a Congress in perpetual disarray for the next two years.

headline: How Does a Family Change After Losing a Child?
abstract: In her new novel, “Small World,” Laura Zigman explores the long shadows cast by grief.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Group Text, a monthly column for readers and book clubs about the novels, memoirs and story collections that make you want to talk, ask questions and dwell in another world for a little bit longer.

headline: ‘M3GAN’ Makes Us Ask (Again): Who’s Afraid of Dancing Robots?
abstract: In the movie “M3GAN,” a robot doll’s sinister virtuosity plays on the mixture of amusement and deep unease that dancing robots often provoke.
lead_paragraph: M3GAN isn’t a born mover. The robot doll at the center of the film “M3GAN” starts out stiff-limbed and jerky, prone to sharp, birdlike tilts of the head — C3PO, if he were styled by the toymaker Madame Alexander.

headline: McCarthy Wins Speakership on 15th Vote After Concessions to Hard Right
abstract: An agreement with ultraconservative Republicans delivered a breakthrough for the California Republican, but he still had to claw his way to the post during a dramatic post-midnight session.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Kevin McCarthy of California won election early Saturday as House speaker in a historic five-day, 15-ballot floor fight, after giving major concessions to right-wing holdouts and weathering a dramatic late-night setback that underscored the limits of his power over the new Republican majority.

headline: TikTok’s Spying Scandal and ChatGPT’s Challenge to Google
abstract: TikTok skeptics now have a smoking gun.
lead_paragraph: Calls to ban TikTok or force its sell-off from its parent company ByteDance are gaining momentum, especially after reports of ByteDance’s surveillance of several U.S. journalists. And could Microsoft’s investment in OpenAI mark the end of Google’s search monopoly?

headline: ‘There’s Nothing for Me Here,’ My Mother Hears Again
abstract: The occupation ended, but the aftereffects of the long American war are still ravaging Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Last September, 13 months after the Taliban takeover, my family and I flew into Kabul one morning as many of our relatives were on the cusp of fleeing the city. We hoped to see them before they parted.

headline: Help! A Check-In Agent’s Mistake Made Me Miss an Antarctic Cruise and I’m Out $17,000.
abstract: An American Airlines error kept a traveler from getting to her cruise’s departure, but the carrier wouldn’t take financial responsibility and her trip insurance refused to pay. Then our columnist stepped in.
lead_paragraph: I was set to take what for me was the “trip of a lifetime,” a $17,000 Antarctic cruise with Australia-based Aurora Expeditions. But when I tried to check in for my flight from Nashville to Santiago, Chile (via Miami), the check-in agent insisted that entering Chile required two forms I had never heard of, even though I had researched the requirements carefully. I missed my flight, and the cruise. When I complained, American Airlines quickly refunded the (nonrefundable) flight, but Aurora would not give me credit for a future cruise and my travel insurer, Trip Mate, denied my claim. I’d like American to acknowledge in writing that they made a mistake and use that to ask Aurora to reconsider and to file an appeal to Trip Mate. Can you help? Deborah, Franklin, Tenn.

headline: New York City’s Pre-K System Was a Model. Now Employees Say It’s a Mess.
abstract: Problems in the city’s early childhood divisions run deep and could threaten the quality of free preschool, according to current and former staff members.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The Mediterranean Diet Really Is That Good for You. Here’s Why.
abstract: It has become the bedrock of virtuous eating. Experts answer common questions about how it leads to better health.
lead_paragraph: In the 1950s, researchers from across the globe embarked on a sweeping and ambitious study. For decades, they scrutinized the diets and lifestyles of thousands of middle-aged men living in the United States, Europe and Japan and then examined how those characteristics affected their risks of developing cardiovascular disease.

headline: Damar Hamlin Has Breathing Tube Removed and Is Talking
abstract: The Buffalo Bills said Hamlin “continues to progress remarkably” and his neurological function was intact.
lead_paragraph: Bills safety Damar Hamlin had his breathing tube removed overnight and has been able to talk with his family, doctors and teammates, the Buffalo Bills said Friday morning.

headline: I Looked Behind the Curtain of American History, and This Is What I Found
abstract: The tension between myth and reality does not undermine the U.S. It defines it.
lead_paragraph: In the realm of folklore and ancient traditions, myths are tales forever retold for their wisdom and underlying truths. Their impossibility is part of their appeal; few would pause to debunk the physics of Icarus’s wings before warning against flying too close to the sun.

headline: When One Wedding Requires Four Outfits, Try Renting
abstract: A new generation of businesses is trying to crack the code of South Asian rental attire.
lead_paragraph: When the wedding invitation arrived in the spring of 2021, Sonya Patel, an entrepreneur who runs a small spice business in Cleveland, was in a bind.

headline: I Am the Last Barrier Between My Sister and New York City
abstract: My sister lost her job, her home, her life as she’d known it. And it could have been even worse.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks before Mayor Eric Adams announced that New York would begin a big push to involuntarily hospitalize severely mentally ill homeless people even if they posed no risk of harm to others, my sister was involuntarily admitted to a psychiatric unit in a city hospital. My sister is not homeless; she had been living in a studio apartment in Queens. But she has a serious mental illness and in November a neighbor called 911 after seeing her on the street carrying a chef’s knife.

headline: A Skeptical Take on the A.I. Revolution
abstract: The A.I. expert Gary Marcus asks: What if ChatGPT isn’t as intelligent as it seems?
lead_paragraph: The year 2022 was jam-packed with advances in artificial intelligence, from the release of image generators like DALL-E 2 and text generators like Cicero to a flurry of developments in the self-driving car industry. And then, on November 30, OpenAI released ChatGPT, arguably the smartest, funniest, most humanlike chatbot to date.

headline: Stranded by Southwest and Stuck With Unexpected Costs
abstract: The airline’s customers incurred thousands in expenses as they scrambled to find alternate ways to get home.
lead_paragraph: Olivia Laskowski was in Nashville and expecting to fly home to New York on Dec. 27 when she received a text message from Southwest Airlines the night before that her flight was canceled. Four days and more than $600 later, Ms. Laskowski and her Siamese cat, Pretzel, were finally back home in Brooklyn.

headline: Financial Planning for Retirement: It’s More Accessible, but Be Careful
abstract: Financial planning and advice is no longer just for the wealthy. It can be especially important when planning for your later years.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been writing and researching articles on finance and money for most of my career, and covering retirement for the past 15 years. But my wife and I haven’t picked a stock or mutual fund for our own retirement accounts since the late 1990s, or written our own retirement plan. For that, we rely on a financial planner.

headline: Pope Benedict Wasn’t Conservative. He Was Something Much More Surprising.
abstract: The heart of his message lay in what he said not to Catholics but to atheists.
lead_paragraph: “The words of a dead man,” W.H. Auden wrote in his elegy for a fellow poet, “are modified in the guts of the living.” In the case of Pope Benedict XVI, whose requiem Mass was celebrated on Thursday, this process of transformation began long before his death.

headline: Wild Weather Swings Are Robbing California of Its Trees
abstract: Pounding rainstorms following an epic drought leave thousands of broken trees that batter roads, levees and neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — The coast redwood crashed through the roof and into Nicole Valentine’s bedroom while she was away at a party, trying to ignore the powerful storms that were hammering Northern California with fierce winds and rain. On the phone, her neighbor was almost incoherent.

headline: China’s Covid Surge Threatens Villages as Lunar New Year Approaches
abstract: Millions are expected to travel home this month, spreading Covid to rural communities where health care services are woefully underdeveloped.
lead_paragraph: The infections in Dadi Village, a corn farming community tucked between verdant hills in China’s remote southwest, started in early December when a handful of young people returned from jobs in big cities.

headline: Southwest’s Meltdown Could Cost It Up to $825 Million
abstract: The airline has not said how soon it will upgrade the systems that contributed to mass flight cancellations, or how much that will cost.
lead_paragraph: The meltdown that forced Southwest Airlines to cancel more than 16,700 holiday flights could cost the carrier between $725 million and $825 million, the airline said in a filing on Friday. The total represents about as much as the airline earned in the first nine months of last year.

headline: Audubon Terrace Is Extending an Olive Branch to Its Neighborhood
abstract: Once accused of ignoring the largely Latino residents of Washington Heights, the Hispanic Society will take the lead in a new charm offensive.
lead_paragraph: If you are heading down Upper Broadway in Washington Heights, past the smoke shop and the eyebrow-threading salon and Chipotle, and you look to the right at 156th Street, you’ll see a cloister of imposing cultural buildings largely cut off from the neighborhood.

headline: She Is Africa’s First Heat Officer. Can She Make Her City Livable?
abstract: Eugenia Kargbo remembers when Sierra Leone’s capital was greener and cooler, and is now trying to help the city combat rising temperatures.
lead_paragraph: Before Sierra Leone’s capital of Freetown exploded into a sprawling metropolis — eating up wooded hills and encroaching on the Atlantic — Eugenia Kargbo loved it for the pristine beaches and lush forests that once enveloped the city, and for its green landscape.

headline: Want to Understand L.G.B.T.Q. Life in America? Go to Alabama.
abstract: I went to Alabama to understand what our country’s anti-gay backlash looks like on the ground — and what it really means to fight back.
lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — It was an unusually chilly Thursday night in December, and a drag queen named Miss Majesty Divine was putting the final touches on her show makeup. She was about to go onstage for her regular gig at a basement tiki bar, one of the last performances before Christmas.

headline: The People Executed or Sentenced to Death in Iran’s Protest Crackdown
abstract: An updated look at the Iranians who have been hanged, and those on death row, as the government tries to crush a monthslong uprising.
lead_paragraph: They include a doctor, a rapper, a karate champion, a barber and an actor, sons, grandsons and fathers. They are among the people Iran has hastily sentenced to death in its campaign to quash the monthslong uprising against the Islamic Republic.

headline: Markets Rise as Investors Like the Look of Hiring and Wage Trends
abstract: Traders are betting that a slowdown in job growth and wage gains could reduce the pressure on prices and make the Federal Reserve less aggressive in raising interest rates.
lead_paragraph: For investors and policymakers alike, bad news may be good news when it comes to the job market.

headline: U.S. Added 223,000 Jobs in December, a Slight Easing in Pace
abstract: The Federal Reserve’s moves to cool the economy with higher interest rates seem to be taking gentle hold. Wage growth lost momentum.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy produced jobs at a slower but still comfortable rate at the end of 2022, as higher interest rates and changing consumer habits downshifted the labor market without bringing it to a halt.

headline: Eurozone Inflation Eases on Lower Energy Prices
abstract: The rate of price increases in countries using the euro slowed to 9.2 percent in December, down from 10.1 percent a month earlier.
lead_paragraph: Lower energy prices helped to push inflation in Europe lower last month, the European Commission reported on Friday, but many prices are still rising at a brisk pace and policymakers have given little indication that they plan to halt planned interest rate increases.

headline: Consider the Burying Beetle. (Or Else.)
abstract: The story behind an ambitious new global agreement to protect biodiversity.
lead_paragraph: The current level of biodiversity loss is extraordinary in human history: The global rate of species extinction is at least tens to hundreds of times higher than the average over the past 10 million years. Insects like the American burying beetle are in real trouble.

headline: The Lying Congressman
abstract: George Santos is stretching the tolerance for lies in U.S. politics.
lead_paragraph: We’ve become accustomed in American politics to a certain level of truth stretching. Politicians contort facts to justify their plans. Some polish the rough edges of their résumés or inflate military credentials, hoping no one notices. Notoriously, Donald Trump’s falsehood-filled presidency ended with a massive lie about the 2020 election.

headline: Here Are the 10 Biggest U.S. Lottery Jackpots Ever
abstract: Changes to Powerball and Mega Millions have led to more large jackpots in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Huge jackpots have become increasingly common in the multistate Mega Millions and Powerball lottery drawings, because of changes to the games over the years and higher ticket prices.

headline: Read U.S.Central Command’s Investigation Into Botched Aug. 29, 2021 Kabul Drone Strike
abstract: The investigation was completed a week and a half after the strike and was never released, but The New York Times obtained 66 partially redacted pages of it through a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit against Central Command. The Pentagon would later acknowledge that the strike was a “tragic mistake” that killed 10 civilians.
lead_paragraph: The investigation was completed a week and a half after the strike and was never released, but The New York Times obtained 66 partially redacted pages of it through a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit against Central Command. The Pentagon would later acknowledge that the strike was a “tragic mistake” that killed 10 civilians.

headline: Military Investigation Reveals How the U.S. Botched a Drone Strike in Kabul
abstract: Documents obtained through a lawsuit reveal how biases led to the deadly August 2021 blunder, and that officials made misleading statements concealing their assessment of civilian casualties.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the chaotic final days of the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan in August 2021, U.S. military analysts observed a white Toyota Corolla stop at what they believed was an Islamic State compound.

headline: Hawaii Volcano Kilauea Erupts Again After Weekslong Pause
abstract: While Kilauea’s lava was contained to a crater, nearby Mauna Loa, the world’s largest active volcano, was not erupting, officials said.
lead_paragraph: One of the world’s most active volcanoes, Kilauea in Hawaii, has resumed erupting after nearly a monthlong pause in activity, scientists said.

headline: Why Bed Bath & Beyond Is Weighing Bankruptcy
abstract: Dreary holiday season sales failed to help solve the struggling retailer’s financial woes, leaving the company with few options.
lead_paragraph: In 2021, Bed Bath & Beyond joined the list of meme stocks whose share prices surged amid sudden interest from online retail investors. But the home furnishings retailer’s future is uncertain after a disappointing holiday sales season failed to help solve its worsening financial woes.

headline: What Memorable Things Did You Learn in 2022?
abstract: Tell us the most fascinating facts you discovered in school, in The New York Times, online or anywhere else.
lead_paragraph: What new information did you learn last year that stands out most? A fact from a science or music class? A curiosity from the news, your social media feed or your own experiences? A surprising statistic from the world of sports or perhaps an intriguing story from a history textbook?

headline: Streaming Changed TV. Is TV Changing Streaming Back?
abstract: A decade of bingeing has transformed storytelling and viewing habits. But we may be starting to hit that transformation’s limits.
lead_paragraph: This is not a review of “Kaleidoscope.” One reason for this is that the Netflix heist series, which arrived on Sunday, is not especially noteworthy, except for one gimmick. The other reason has to do with the nature of that gimmick.

headline: Daniel Barenboim, Titan of Conducting, to Step Down in Berlin
abstract: The 80-year-old conductor, citing poor health, said he would resign as general music director of the Berlin State Opera after three decades.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Barenboim, a towering conductor and pianist who as general music director of the Berlin State Opera over the past three decades built an artistic empire without rival and helped define German culture in the aftermath of reunification, will resign his post this month because of health problems, the opera house announced on Friday.

headline: California Is In for a Continuing Parade of Storms
abstract: A Friday respite is expected to be quickly followed by more downpours.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On Thursday morning, three men used a handsaw to slice a toppled tree blocking the front of their apartment building. City workers had placed cones around the tree but didn’t remove it, so neighborhood residents took matters into their own hands.

headline: In ‘Mayfair Witches,’ Alexandra Daddario Takes a Dark Turn
abstract: After earning an Emmy nomination for her performance in “The White Lotus,” Daddario is taking on her first lead TV role, in AMC’s latest Anne Rice adaptation.
lead_paragraph: Despite much evidence to the contrary, Alexandra Daddario still does not consider herself a famous person.

headline: For Freelancers, New Federal Help in Saving for Retirement
abstract: The Secure 2.0 Act provides for direct government contributions to retirement accounts for low- and moderate-income workers, though that won’t start until 2027.
lead_paragraph: Gig economy workers lag behind those with traditional jobs in saving for retirement, but parts of a new federal law can help them catch up.

headline: Movie Trailers Keep Tweaking Well-Known Songs. The Tactic Is Working.
abstract: Composers are increasingly in demand for trailerization — reworking existing tracks by artists including Kate Bush, Nirvana and Kendrick Lamar to maximize their impact in film and TV previews.
lead_paragraph: David James Rosen’s work has been streamed on YouTube hundreds of millions of times. He’s played a crucial role in some of pop culture’s biggest recent moments. But few people outside of the space where the entertainment and marketing industries overlap know his name.

headline: Ukraine says recent pledges show that key weapons are no longer ‘taboo’ for its allies.
abstract: The foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, welcomed pledges this week from France, Germany and the United States of military aid that his government had been seeking for months.
lead_paragraph: At the start of the war, they were considered too big an ask. But the armored fighting vehicles committed to Ukraine this week — the latest in a slow-rolling wave of once off-limits weapons that have now been promised to Kyiv by Western countries — show that the tide has turned, Ukraine’s foreign minister said on Friday.

headline: ‘Consciousness’ in Robots Was Once Taboo. Now It’s the Last Word.
abstract: The pursuit of artificial awareness may be humankind’s next moonshot. But it comes with a host of difficult questions.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The Year of Bad Bunny
abstract: With a blockbuster LP and a smash tour, the genre-melding superstar set a new bar for himself, and expanded the possibilities for Spanish-language pop worldwide.
lead_paragraph: Saying that 2022 was the year of Bad Bunny somehow doesn’t quite do his success justice. His LP “Un Verano Sin Ti” was the most streamed album of the year, breaking several records along the way. He was the year’s top grossing touring act — including two sold-out shows at Yankee Stadium. “Un Verano Sin Ti” is the first release performed entirely in Spanish to be nominated for album of the year at the Grammys.

headline: The leader of Belarus visits a military base where Russian forces are stationed.
abstract: Concerns have mounted in recent weeks that Moscow could try to draw Belarus, Ukraine’s northern neighbor, more directly into the war.
lead_paragraph: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus on Friday visited a military base in his country where Russia and Belarus have been conducting joint exercises, adding to creeping fears that Moscow could use Belarus as a launchpad for a new ground offensive into Ukraine.

headline: In ‘Black Panther: Wakanda Forever,’ One Scene Celebrates and Commemorates
abstract: Grieving Chadwick Boseman’s death, the “Black Panther” creative team transferred fragments of their sorrow onto a signature funeral sequence.
lead_paragraph: Roughly 400 costumed cast members and some 400 crew members. Dozens of makeup artists and 100 wigs. In “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever,” the production team was tasked with memorializing not only the country’s fearless leader King T’Challa, but also the actor Chadwick Boseman, who shook up the Marvel Cinematic Universe as Black Panther.

headline: These Would Be Our Oscar Nominations
abstract: Four editors and one critic share their wish lists for best picture, best actress and best actor.
lead_paragraph: In addition to the Academy Award nominees our chief film critics Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott would name, five other movie-loving New York Times staffers weighed in with their selections for three of the big prizes: best picture, best actress and best actor. (Except for the featured pick, the slates are in alphabetical order, with 10 entries for best picture and five for the acting categories, as in the official nominations.)

headline: Biden Administration Moves to Tighten Limits on Deadly Air Pollution
abstract: A new rule would, for the first time in a decade, reduce emissions of soot that disproportionately harm communities of color.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Friday proposed to tighten limits on fine particulate matter, a deadly air pollutant that includes soot.

headline: Crawford Wants to Fight Spence. Jaron Ennis May Get to Face Him First.
abstract: Ennis, who is undefeated heading into a fight on Saturday, has designs on getting bouts with the welterweight titleholders. And he has the inside track.
lead_paragraph: The welterweight boxing contender Jaron Ennis has 29 wins, 27 knockouts and one simple request: to face an opponent who can withstand his punches.

headline: The Plastic Problem
abstract: It’s warming the planet and driving biodiversity loss. This year will be key to negotiating a global treaty to curb its impact.
lead_paragraph: Plastic is truly ubiquitous. It’s in our clothes, our phones, our sunscreen. But also, increasingly, in marine food chains and immense, floating garbage patches in the oceans.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Gary Marcus
abstract: The Jan. 6, 2023 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Gary Marcus. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: The Norwegian hobbyists finding hundreds of Bronze Age carvings. Also in this edition: a bolder Michelle Williams, and Iggy Pop’s staying power.
lead_paragraph: The Norwegian hobbyists finding hundreds of Bronze Age carvings. Also in this edition: a bolder Michelle Williams, and Iggy Pop’s staying power.

headline: Lit Trivia: Can You Identify the Books Written by These Women of Comedy?
abstract: You’ve seen them on television — now test yourself on the literary efforts of these multitalented performers.
lead_paragraph: You’ve seen them on television — now test yourself on the literary efforts of these multitalented performers.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Make the Sonora-style enchiladas from the Los Angeles restaurant El Cholo, or a lemony pasta with brown-butter almonds.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The family-run Los Angeles restaurant El Cholo turns 100 this year. To mark the occasion, our colleague Kevin McKenna wrote a profile of the place and pulled out of its kitchen a recipe for the Sonora-style enchiladas (above) that have been on the menu since the very beginning.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks feature a time-collapsing camera, culinary cultists and a hole to hell.
lead_paragraph: The new year is only days old, but this deeply affecting film is already a contender for my favorite scary movie of 2023. It’s a triumph of low-fi horror and a knockout narrative feature debut from the writer-director Paul Owens, a documentarian.

headline: 7 Songs We Nearly Missed in 2022
abstract: Hear tracks by Flo, Becky G and Karol G, Monster and Big Flock and more.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Márcio Freire, Renowned Brazilian Surfer, Dies in Portugal’s Nazaré
abstract: Mr. Freire began surfing at an early age and starred in a 2016 documentary on the sport. He was 47.
lead_paragraph: The famed Brazilian surfer Márcio Freire died while surfing in the town of Nazaré on Portugal’s central coast, an area renowned in the sport for its record-breaking giant waves, Portugal’s National Maritime Authority said on Friday.

headline: 10 Key Revelations in the Idaho Murder Case
abstract: Court records unsealed this week provided vital and unsettling new details about the night that four University of Idaho students were killed.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Idaho — After weeks of unease over the murders of four University of Idaho students in a house near campus, the authorities this week released their most detailed account yet of the investigation that led them to arrest a criminology student from a nearby university.

headline: Widening Highways Doesn’t Fix Traffic. So Why Do We Keep Doing It?
abstract: With billions of dollars available to improve transportation infrastructure, states have a chance to try new strategies for addressing congestion. But some habits are hard to break.
lead_paragraph: Interstate 710 in Los Angeles is, like the city itself, famous for its traffic. Freight trucks traveling between the city and the port of Long Beach, along with commuters, clog the highway. The trucks idle in the congestion, contributing to poor air quality in surrounding neighborhoods that are home to over one million people.

headline: Nate Thayer, Bold Reporter Who Interviewed Pol Pot, Dies at 62
abstract: The “mad genius” journalist scored an exclusive interview with the genocidal Cambodian leader and covered his show trial, another worldwide scoop.
lead_paragraph: Nate Thayer, a risk-taking, publicity-drawing journalist whose career was capped by an exclusive jungle interview in Cambodia with Pol Pot, the leader of one of the worst convulsions of mass killing of the last century, has died at his home in East Falmouth, Mass. He was 62.

headline: Why Does the House Keep Repeating the Same Vote Over and Over?
abstract: Until the House chooses a speaker, it is legally unable to do anything else. As long as it is in session, it has to vote for a speaker. If the vote fails, it has to vote again. And again.
lead_paragraph: Across 11 rounds of voting for House speaker, a distinct pattern has emerged.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The hosts returned from the holiday break to plenty of drama on Capitol Hill including the George Santos controversy and the battle to choose a speaker in the House of Representatives.
lead_paragraph: The hosts returned from the holiday break to plenty of drama on Capitol Hill including the George Santos controversy and the battle to choose a speaker in the House of Representatives.

headline: Review: A Philharmonic Contender Returns to the Podium
abstract: With a change of the guard imminent at the New York Philharmonic, Santtu-Matias Rouvali is the only guest conductor leading two programs this season.
lead_paragraph: A changing of the guard on the world’s great orchestral podiums was in the air on Friday. Daniel Barenboim, 80, the longtime music director of the Berlin State Opera, had just announced he would step down at the end of the month because of his declining health.

headline: Review: ‘Are We Not Drawn Onward to New Era’ Stages a Disaster in Reverse
abstract: The Under the Radar festival kicks off with an allegory about climate destruction by the Belgian provocateurs Ontroerend Goed.
lead_paragraph: Stop me if you’ve heard this one before: A woman. A man. A tree. An apple. So begins “Are We Not Drawn Onward to New Era,” a performance piece by the Belgian provocateurs Ontroerend Goed, presented by the Brooklyn Academy of Music in association with the Public Theater’s Under the Radar festival. In the show’s first minutes, an apple is plucked and eaten, a paradise destroyed. Then the story changes.

headline: As the N.B.A. Gets ‘Loose,’ 50-Point Games Are Surging
abstract: Donovan Mitchell’s 71 points in a game this week was the top mark since 2006, but a rise in offense (and a lack of defense) has made high-scoring games a routine affair.
lead_paragraph: We don't know who will do it, and we don’t know exactly when it will happen. But we do know that somebody sometime soon will score 50 points in an N.B.A. game. And then it will happen again. And again and again and again.

headline: Ken Balcomb, 82, Dies; Revealed the Hidden World of Killer Whales
abstract: His annual orca survey helped transform the animals’ image from soulless predators to compassionate creatures worth protecting.
lead_paragraph: Ken Balcomb, whose meticulous decades-long effort to track a population of killer whales in the Pacific Northwest did much to transform the marine mammals’ image from soulless predators to compassionate creatures worth protecting, died on Dec. 15 at a ranch house on the Elwha River, west of Seattle. He was 82.

headline: When’s the Next Meteor Shower? Check Your Calendar.
abstract: The Science desk’s Space and Astronomy calendar started as a novel way to deliver the news and engage with readers on a different platform.
lead_paragraph: The seed that would sprout into the New York Times Space and Astronomy Calendar was planted back in 2014 — because of “The Simpsons.”

headline: This 3-Course Meal Can’t Get Much Easier
abstract: David Tanis offers a carrot-leek soup, baked fish with mushrooms and just a tiny bit of sweetness to finish after the holidays’ excesses.
lead_paragraph: It’s trite, but it’s true: After the excesses of the holiday season, January is the time to venture into more moderate territory. It’s just as well, but it needn’t feel restrictive. And something festive isn’t out of the question, either.

headline: Tensions with Virgin Islands Governor Over Epstein Led to Attorney General’s Firing
abstract: Denise George, who led a three-year investigation into the activities of Jeffrey Epstein, was fired recently.
lead_paragraph: The former attorney general for the Virgin Islands, who recently secured a $105 million settlement from the estate of Jeffrey Epstein, was recently fired following months of friction between her and the U.S. territory’s governor over the handling of the investigation into the disgraced financier, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: The Recipes Our Kids Love
abstract: These are the dishes our children happily eat over and over.
lead_paragraph: You might assume that the children of New York Times food editors and writers have adventurous palates. Surely, you might think, a person who spends so much time cooking and eating would raise a fearless eater who happily devours composed salads for school lunch. But, dear reader, you’d be wrong. Most of our kids are just as picky as anyone else’s.

headline: The Frick Acquires Its First Renaissance Portrait of a Woman
abstract: A 16th-century painting, by the Italian Renaissance master Giovanni Battista Moroni, will go on display at the Frick Madison on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: From a gilded frame, a red-haired woman eyes the viewer warily. Her gaze is steely, direct and somewhat confrontational.

headline: In the House, There Are No Representatives. Yet.
abstract: The chamber’s 434 members cannot be sworn in until a speaker is chosen.
lead_paragraph: For four consecutive days, as Congress plods through its most protracted election for House speaker since 1859, the House of Representatives has existed more as a theoretical concept — an aspirational ideal — than an actual lawmaking body.

headline: Dick Savitt Dies at 95; Won Australian and Wimbledon Tennis Titles in 1951
abstract: He was the second American to win both Grand Slam tournaments in the same year, and he was ranked among the world’s top 10 players four times.
lead_paragraph: Dick Savitt, the tennis Hall of Famer who won the men’s singles championships at the 1951 Australian and Wimbledon Grand Slam tournaments but dropped out of full-time play a year later while at the height of his game, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.

headline: Former U.S.C. Official Sentenced to Six Months for Role in College Admissions Scandal
abstract: Donna Heinel, as the gatekeeper for athletic recruits, played a key role in the sweeping college admissions scandal.
lead_paragraph: Donna Heinel, a former administrator and gatekeeper for athletic recruits at the University of Southern California, was sentenced Friday to six months in prison for her central role in the sweeping college admissions scandal, pushing through phony athletic recruits whose families could afford to make large gifts to the university.

headline: At City Ballet, Alexei Ratmansky Can Let His Imagination Run Wild
abstract: When the choreographer joins the company as artist in residence, the winners will be the dancers. And ballet.
lead_paragraph: When it was announced in December that the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky would be parting ways from American Ballet Theater as its artist in residence after 13 years, my first reaction was regret followed swiftly by hope. Would New York City Ballet, where his choreographic imagination has the fortitude and space to run breathtakingly free, lure him across the Lincoln Center plaza?

headline: The U.S. announces a $3 billion package of military aid to Ukraine, including armored fighting vehicles.
abstract: Karine Jean-Pierre, the White House press secretary, said the administration would also send $682 million to countries on NATO’s eastern flank.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration announced a new $3 billion package of military assistance for Ukraine that will include Bradley Fighting Vehicles, which officials said would be especially helpful to Ukrainian units fighting Russian forces in the Donbas region of the country’s east.

headline: F.D.A. Approves New Treatment for Early Alzheimer’s
abstract: The drug, Leqembi, may modestly slow cognitive decline in early stages of the disease but carries some safety risks. Still, data suggests it is more promising than the small number of other available treatments.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved a new Alzheimer’s drug that may modestly slow the pace of cognitive decline early in the disease, but also carries risks of swelling and bleeding in the brain.

headline: Love Letter: Stranger Than ‘Sweetie’
abstract: Tell us about your weirdest terms of endearment.
lead_paragraph: When I was 5, my cousin started calling me “Mibu.” My siblings and other cousins followed suit. And then my aunts, uncles and parents did, too.

headline: Kenyan Gay Rights Activist Is Killed
abstract: Edwin Chiloba’s body was dumped on the roadside by a moving vehicle in the country’s west. Police have arrested his friend and are pursuing two others in the case.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — A gay activist and fashion designer was murdered and his body found stuffed inside a metal box in Kenya, the police said on Friday, in another episode that raised questions about dangers and discrimination faced by gay people across the East African nation.

headline: Mother of Uvalde Gunman Arrested Over Threats to Kill a Man
abstract: The police said Adriana Martinez Reyes, who told them the teenager behind the school shooting in Uvalde, Texas, was her son, threatened to harm a man during an altercation.
lead_paragraph: The Oklahoma City police arrested on Wednesday the mother of the teenager responsible for the mass shooting at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, and charged her with threatening a man.

headline: How to (Correctly) Plunge a Toilet
abstract: There is a better way.
lead_paragraph: There is a better way.

headline: ‘The Vow’ Is Gripping TV That Doesn’t Solve Its Central Mysteries
abstract: Keith Raniere, Nxivm and the riddle of charisma.
lead_paragraph: Over Christmas, my wife and I finished watching Season 2 of “The Vow,” an HBO documentary about the unraveling of the Nxivm organization — better known to tabloid readers as the “sex slave cult,” after its inner circle, whose members were branded and participated in self-described master-slave relationships — and the trial of its leader, Keith Raniere. It’s a striking piece of filmmaking and a deeply frustrating exercise: A mystery story that offers copious evidence, endless evidence, evidence enough to make Hercule Poirot envious, without coming close to answering the key questions raised by its fascinating subject.

headline: Tales of Families and the Great Depression
abstract: Readers share their stories of resilience, community and suffering.
lead_paragraph: Many readers responded to my newsletter last Friday about my great-grandfather’s life during the Depression in Vermont. I heard from neighbors, relatives and readers as far away as Australia. While some wrote glowingly about the resilience and camaraderie fostered by the Depression, others focused on the suffering. Here are edited excerpts from some of your emails.

headline: Looking for Elbow Room, Louvre Limits Daily Visitors to 30,000
abstract: With attendance surging back, the museum wants to offer “a moment of pleasure”  — and relieve that Mona Lisa problem.
lead_paragraph: It has become an unpleasant gladiatorial rite of passage for tourists to Paris: Trying to view the Mona Lisa, the pensive diva encased in bulletproof glass, through a heaving throng of arms, heads and raised iPhones at the sprawling Louvre Museum.

headline: What Ukraine Teaches Us About Power
abstract: Acting tough doesn’t make you strong, even militarily.
lead_paragraph: Credit where credit is due: Make America Great Again was a brilliant slogan, precisely because nobody knew what it meant. Was it about bringing back jobs in manufacturing? Was it about restoring straight, white, Christian men to what some of them thought was their natural position of social dominance? MAGA became all-purpose code for reversing whatever was bugging you about 21st-century America.

headline: Federal Panel Rules South Carolina Congressional District Is Illegal Gerrymander
abstract: A three-judge federal panel unanimously ruled that South Carolina’s redrawn First Congressional District illegally removed 62 percent of the Black voters in Charleston County.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — South Carolina’s First Congressional District is an unconstitutional racial gerrymander, and its boundaries must be redrawn before future elections are held, a panel of three federal judges unanimously ruled on Friday.

headline: Art McNally, N.F.L.’s ‘Father of Instant Replay,’ Dies at 97
abstract: The first field official in the Pro Football Hall of Fame, he helped bring technology into the sport and kept his cool even in the face of angry coaches and players.
lead_paragraph: Art McNally, the first on-field National Football League official to be inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame, died on Sunday in Yardley, Pa. He was 97.

headline: S.E.C. Inquiry Into Former Senator’s Stock Sales Is Closed Without Charges
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission ended its investigation into former Senator Richard Burr, three years after he sold more than $1.6 million in stocks following Covid-19 briefings.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission has closed an investigation into former Senator Richard M. Burr that examined whether a series of stock sales he made in early 2020 after being briefed on the threat of Covid-19 were improper, Mr. Burr and his lawyer said on Friday.

headline: How to Watch Prince Harry’s Interviews About ‘Spare’
abstract: A number of specials are planned to promote the book, which has captured worldwide interest.
lead_paragraph: Prince Harry’s upcoming memoir, “Spare,” has captured a global audience, with leaks and high-profile interviews helping to heighten interest ahead of its release on Jan. 10. Clips shared in advance suggest the book is a tell-all in which he speaks frankly about tense relationships with his family, his time in the military and more.

headline: The Charity and the Supreme Court
abstract: The Supreme Court Historical Society and the justices. Also: Politicians’ tax returns; fighting hunger; a Soviet legacy; international films.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fed Officials Ask How to Better Understand Inflation After Surprises
abstract: Federal Reserve officials, including Lisa Cook, a board member, are wrestling with how to think about price increases after 18 months of rapid change.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Federal Reserve officials kicked off 2023 by addressing a thorny question that is poised to bedevil the central bank throughout the year: How should central bankers understand inflation after 18 months of repeatedly misjudging it?

headline: Blackstone Loses Rent Dispute at Manhattan’s Biggest Apartment Complex
abstract: The ruling was the latest development in the turbulent history of Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village, the setting of many of New York City’s most high-profile housing battles.
lead_paragraph: Tenants living in Manhattan’s largest apartment complex, Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village, won a battle to keep their rents insulated from potentially sharp increases, after a judge ruled this week against their landlord, the Wall Street private equity firm Blackstone.

headline: Walgreens Executive Says Shoplifting Threat Was Overstated
abstract: In a call with investors on Thursday, the chief financial officer of Walgreens, James Kehoe, said “maybe we cried too much last year” over theft.
lead_paragraph: A Walgreens executive said this week that the company, which cited “organized” shoplifting as a reason to close five stores in San Francisco in October 2021, might have overstated the effect of theft on its business.

headline: U.S. Open Winner Carlos Alcaraz to Miss Australian Open With Injury
abstract: Alcaraz, 19, the world No. 1, said he had injured his right leg during training.
lead_paragraph: The year’s first major tennis tournament suffered a major blow on Friday when Carlos Alcaraz, the precocious men’s world No. 1 from Spain, announced that he was withdrawing from the Australian Open with a right leg injury.

headline: Attacks Continue in Ukraine Despite Russia’s Supposed Cease-Fire
abstract: Ukraine never accepted Russia’s unilateral Christmas truce, dismissing it as a hollow ploy, and Russian shelling was as intense as ever in a hotly contested city.
lead_paragraph: BAKHMUT, Ukraine — There was no truce in Bakhmut on Friday. Russian artillery shells kept streaking overhead and thudding into Ukrainian-held territory through the afternoon and evening, just as they had for months, despite a supposed 36-hour cease-fire declared by Russia.

headline: Jennifer Shah, ‘Real Housewives’ Star, Sentenced in Fraud Scheme
abstract: Ms. Shah, who appeared on “The Real Housewives of Salt Lake City,” was sentenced to more than six years in prison for her involvement in a telemarketing scheme, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Shah, who gained fame as a cast member on the reality television show “The Real Housewives of Salt Lake City,” was sentenced on Friday to six and a half years in prison for her involvement in a telemarketing scheme that defrauded thousands of victims, prosecutors said.

headline: New Armored Vehicles Will Help Ukraine Take the Fight to Russia
abstract: The Western allies’ provision of infantry fighting vehicles signals their support for new offensives in coming months, analysts said.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — They will soon be covered in mud, riddled with shrapnel damage and under fire on Ukraine’s battlefields. But the three new types of armored vehicles offered to Ukraine this week signal that the Western allies are gearing up for another bloody year as the war enters a new phase of Ukrainian offensives against dug-in Russian forces.

headline: Shootings Reported at Homes and Offices of 5 New Mexico Democrats
abstract: No one was injured in the shootings, which occurred in Albuquerque between Dec. 4 and Thursday. The authorities are investigating whether they were related and politically motivated.
lead_paragraph: Federal and local authorities in New Mexico are investigating whether several shootings since early December at the offices or homes of five elected Democratic leaders were connected and possibly politically motivated, officials said.

headline: After Election Problems in Houston, Republicans Seek to Overturn Results
abstract: A growing number of contests to elections in Texas’ Harris County are a broad attempt to cast doubt on an Election Day that officials concede had problems.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Jon Rosenthal has seen some close races, but his re-election to the Texas State House in November, in a Houston district redrawn to be a virtual lock for Democrats, was not one of them. Mr. Rosenthal won by 15 points.

headline: Ukraine Gets ‘Tank Killers’
abstract: France, Germany and the U.S. step up their support with new weaponry.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Michael Snow, Prolific and Playful Artistic Polymath, Is Dead at 94
abstract: He was a painter, a musician, a photographer and a sculptor. But he was best known for experimental (and often contentious) films like “Wavelength.”
lead_paragraph: Michael Snow, a Canadian painter, jazz pianist, photographer, sculptor and filmmaker best known for “Wavelength” — a humble, relentless, more or less continuous zoom shot that traverses a Lower Manhattan loft into a photograph pasted on its far wall — died on Thursday in Toronto. He was 94.

headline: C-SPAN and cable news get a boost from the House speaker spectacle.
abstract: C-SPAN, the low-fi cable network beloved by the Congressional cognoscenti, has gotten a major boost in attention for its coverage of the House floor, now the site of a political battle for the ages.
lead_paragraph: The drama of this week’s House speaker vote resembles something out of “Waiting For Godot.” Turns out Americans are tuning in for the political theater.

headline: Prince Harry Claims in Memoir to Have Killed 25 in Afghanistan
abstract: After British news outlets revealed details from his memoir about his military service, Afghan officials and some in the British military expressed criticism.
lead_paragraph: Former British military leaders and the Afghan government criticized an apparent claim from Prince Harry’s upcoming memoir that he killed 25 Taliban fighters during his tours as a soldier in Afghanistan.

headline: Judge Scolds Trump Legal Team and Lets James’s Lawsuit Proceed
abstract: A New York judge declined to dismiss the state attorney general’s suit against the former president and called his lawyers’ filing frivolous.
lead_paragraph: A New York judge declined on Friday to throw out the state attorney general’s civil fraud case against former President Donald J. Trump, increasing the likelihood that he will face a trial this fall.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: 6-Year-Old Shoots Teacher at Virginia Elementary School, Police Say
abstract: A teacher at Richneck Elementary School in Newport News has “life-threatening injuries” after being shot by one of her students, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A 6-year-old first-grader at an elementary school in Newport News, Va., shot a teacher on Friday afternoon during an altercation in a classroom, the authorities said, leaving her with “life-threatening” injuries and renewing calls for greater gun restrictions.

headline: Lawmaker’s Victory May Cost Him Coveted Manhattan Apartment
abstract: Democratic Assembly leaders in New York decided not to try to expel a Republican, Lester Chang, over residency questions, but his rent-stabilized apartment may now be at risk.
lead_paragraph: For days, Democrats in the New York State Assembly had been considering whether to expel a Republican assemblyman because of evidence suggesting he lived in Manhattan, not in the South Brooklyn district he was recently elected to represent.

headline: Far-Right Critics Vex McCarthy in His Bakersfield District, Too
abstract: The Republican divisions facing Representative Kevin McCarthy played out not only on the House floor but also in his hometown, a red area of blue California.
lead_paragraph: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — Representative Kevin McCarthy’s past runs deep in this Central Valley town, far from the glamour and money of his state’s metropolises to the north and south. Bakersfield is where he was born and raised, went to college and ran his first business selling sandwiches out of the back of his uncle’s yogurt shop on Stine Road.

headline: Uber Doesn’t Have to Raise New York City Drivers’ Pay, Judge Rules
abstract: The judge sympathized with drivers for Uber and other ride-hail companies but said that the Taxi and Limousine Commission had not supported its case for the raise.
lead_paragraph: A New York State judge on Friday blocked regulators from raising the pay of ride-hail drivers, saying that the Taxi and Limousine Commission had not sufficiently justified the increase.

headline: Biden Honors ‘Extraordinary Americans’ Who Defended Democracy on Jan. 6
abstract: President Biden marked the second anniversary of the Jan. 6 attack by awarding the Presidential Citizens Medal to 14 people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Friday honored 14 people who stood against election denialism in 2020 and fought the violent mob at the Capitol two years ago, telling them in a White House ceremony that history “will remember your names, remember your courage, remember your bravery.”

headline: Biden Moves to End Doughnut Lures and Other Bear Hunting Tactics in Alaska
abstract: A new rule proposed by the administration would also bar hunters from invading wolf dens to kill pups.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Park Service is moving to prohibit hunters on some public lands in Alaska from baiting black bears with doughnuts and using spotlights to shoot hibernating bears and cubs in their dens, techniques allowed by the Trump administration but considered inhumane by conservationists.

headline: I’m One of the Last Holdouts Against Kevin McCarthy — and I Won’t Back Down
abstract: We already know what a House under his leadership looks like.
lead_paragraph: Back in the summer, a group of conservatives put together a proposal with extensive changes to the rules and processes that govern how Republicans run the House of Representatives. For example, we wanted regular, rank-and-file members to have more power to amend bills on the House floor. We wanted at least three days to read and consider bills before we were asked to vote on them. And we wanted to limit the scope of bills to a single subject, so we wouldn’t be asked to vote on legislative “Christmas trees” passed on a tight deadline. We made those demands because the people we represent have told us time and again that Washington is broken, and we knew they wanted to see a change in the status quo.

headline: Idaho Supreme Court Upholds Abortion Bans
abstract: The justices found that the state’s Constitution does not include a right to the procedure, bringing an end to a monthslong legal battle.
lead_paragraph: Idaho’s Supreme Court upheld the state’s prohibition on abortion in a ruling Thursday night that said the State Constitution does not include a right to the procedure.

headline: The Toll of Capturing El Chapo’s Son: 10 Soldiers, 19 Cartel Members Dead
abstract: After troops arrested a son of the notorious drug lord known as El Chapo, cartel gunmen tried to free him, resulting in a series of gun battles and thousands of troops called into the fight.
lead_paragraph: Ten soldiers and 19 drug cartel members were killed and dozens of people were wounded in a series of gun battles surrounding the capture of the son of the notorious drug kingpin known as El Chapo, Mexican officials said on Friday.

headline: Republicans Can’t Decide Whether to Woo or Condemn Young Voters
abstract: As Democrats keep winning millennials and Gen Z, Republicans are still debating how to get them back.
lead_paragraph: For months before the 2022 midterm elections, Democrats fretted that younger voters might fall into old habits and stay home. The analysis is still a little hazy, but as more data comes in, it looks as if enough young people showed up in many key states to play a decisive role.

headline: Hamlin’s Cardiac Arrest Highlights Danger Across Sports
abstract: The collapse of Damar Hamlin of the Buffalo Bills has brought attention to sudden cardiac arrest and the need for the proper medical care and equipment from youth leagues to the professional ranks.
lead_paragraph: Chris Pronger’s eyes rolled back as he lost consciousness and athletic trainers tried to remove his helmet. It was May 10, 1998, and Pronger, then 23 and a defenseman for the St. Louis Blues, had collapsed after he was struck in the chest by a slap shot from Dmitri Mironov of the Detroit Red Wings.

headline: Facing Deadline, Dodgers Cut Ties With Trevor Bauer
abstract: The team is still required to pay Bauer $22.5 million for 2023 even after stating he will not play for them. The pitcher was found to have violated M.L.B.’s domestic violence policy.
lead_paragraph: Trevor Bauer’s tumultuous time in Los Angeles is finished. Two weeks after an arbitrator ended Bauer’s suspension for violating Major League Baseball’s domestic violence policy, effectively reinstating him, the Dodgers issued a statement saying he would “no longer be a part of this organization.”

headline: McCarthy, All Carrots and No Sticks, Grinned His Way to the Speakership
abstract: The Republican leader’s sheer willingness to endure vote after vote against him — even as he offered a slew of concessions — delivered him the top post.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For days as hard-right lawmakers voted again and again to block him from becoming speaker, Representative Kevin McCarthy of California sat on the House floor with a grin plastered to his face.

headline: A Confluence of Forces: Anti-Kevin McCarthy and Pro-2020 Election Lies
abstract: Some of the same Republicans who were former President Donald J. Trump’s lieutenants in seeking to overturn the 2020 election led the charge against Representative Kevin McCarthy as speaker.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They helped lead the efforts to keep former President Donald J. Trump in power after he lost the 2020 election. They refused to certify that President Biden was the rightful winner. They spread lies that helped ignite a mob of Trump supporters to storm the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: What Are Your Reading Goals for 2023?
abstract: Maybe there’s an author you’ve always wanted to read. Or maybe this is the year you actually finish “The Power Broker.” Tell us about it.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a book lover, chances are good you’re thinking about the next thing you can’t wait to read. For some people, a new year is great time to set a reading goal, whether it’s a specific number of books they want to tackle, a genre they want to explore or something else.

headline: Here’s How to Achieve Tech Nirvana in 2023
abstract: In a live conversation, we offered tips for readers looking to optimize their digital lives this year.
lead_paragraph: Social media and new communication platforms may have been lifelines during the pandemic, but have they gobbled up too much of your time? Do you have more streaming subscriptions than you could ever use? Along with aspirations for more exercise or a better diet, it might be time to reset your tech life.

headline: Having Been Informed
abstract: Adam Aaronson’s puzzle takes us down a winding path.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Today’s constructor, Adam Aaronson, calls this puzzle — his eighth Saturday grid — “weird” in his notes more than once. I thought of many other descriptors while scrabbling my way through each corner, particularly in the southwestern region, a veritable word desert for my poor, thirsty brain.

headline: Day 6: Don’t Cancel Those Plans
abstract: If you think you’ll be happier staying home, you’re wrong.
lead_paragraph: This is Day 6 of Well’s 7-day Happiness Challenge. To start at the beginning, click here.

headline: Ant Group Says Its Founder, Jack Ma, Will Relinquish Control
abstract: Ant Group, the fintech sister company of the e-commerce behemoth Alibaba, is one of China’s most influential companies.
lead_paragraph: One of China’s most influential financial tech companies, Ant Group, said on Saturday that the billionaire entrepreneur, Jack Ma, planned to relinquish control of the company.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Bleak Sign of Storms’ Power: Undersides of Thousands of Trees
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Jan. 7, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “We’re moving from extreme drought to extreme flood. What that means is, a lot of our trees are stressed.”

headline: Corrections: Jan. 7, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 7, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to influence the House speaker fight described incorrectly Republicans’ performance in congressional elections in recent years. In the 2018 elections, Republicans lost control of the House, not the Senate. And they lost control of the Senate after the 2020 election cycle, not just the White House.

headline: After Dramatic 14th Vote, Trump Calls Holdouts Who Refused to Back McCarthy
abstract: The former president made crucially timed calls to Representative Matt Gaetz and others who sunk McCarthy’s 14th effort to be elected House speaker.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump made a crucially timed call to Representative Matt Gaetz on Friday night after the Florida congressman voted “present” and sunk Kevin McCarthy’s 14th effort to be elected House speaker.

headline: The Moment When Tempers Really Got Out of Control on the House Floor
abstract: Tensions flared when Representative Matt Gaetz sunk Kevin McCarthy’s 14th effort to be elected speaker of the House.
lead_paragraph: Even by the heated standards of the tensions that flared among House Republicans during their four-day push to elect a speaker, what happened on the House floor around 11 p.m. on Friday stood out.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘Alexa, Why Do We Keep Buying You?’
abstract: With questions swirling about the utility of voice assistants, we asked readers how they use one of the most popular, Amazon’s Alexa. Here’s what they answered.
lead_paragraph: When Amazon released Alexa in 2014, the company had big dreams for the technology. The voice assistant, the company suggested, could succeed smartphones as the next essential consumer interface.

headline: The Rollout of Prince Harry’s Book Is Chaotic. Sales Are Still Surging.
abstract: A litany of leaks and interview clips before the book’s publication has made the process hard for the publisher to control, but has also driven early interest.
lead_paragraph: The details streaming from leaks and interview teasers in advance of Prince Harry’s memoir, “Spare,” have been sensational, even explosive. News organizations around the world have covered them breathlessly.

headline: For Ironman Triathlon Finishers, His Words Were as Precious as a Medal
abstract: Mike Reilly thrilled weary finishers of Ironman triathlons with the affirming phrase they longed to hear: “You are an Ironman.”
lead_paragraph: Endurance athletes are known to visualize the finish line of a race as a means of motivation. But Ironman athletes — those who sign up to complete a triathlon consisting of 2.4 miles of swimming, 112 miles of bicycling and 26.2 miles of running — may spend more time thinking about what they’ll hear at that finish line.

headline: Suspect in Bike Path Killing Faces First Death Penalty Trial Under Biden
abstract: Though President Biden campaigned against capital punishment, Attorney General Merrick Garland is charting his own course in pursuing the death penalty in the trial of Sayfullo Saipov.
lead_paragraph: On Halloween 2017, Sayfullo Saipov plowed a rented pickup truck down Manhattan’s crowded West Side bicycle path, smashing into pedestrians and cyclists, killing eight people and injuring more than a dozen, the authorities said.

headline: A New Area of A.I. Booms, Even Amid the Tech Gloom
abstract: An investment frenzy over “generative artificial intelligence” has gripped Silicon Valley, as tools that generate text, images and sounds in response to short prompts seize the imagination.
lead_paragraph: Five weeks ago, OpenAI, a San Francisco artificial intelligence lab, released ChatGPT, a chatbot that answers questions in clear, concise prose. The A.I.-powered tool immediately caused a sensation, with more than a million people using it to create everything from poetry to high school term papers to rewrites of Queen songs.

headline: Podcast Overload
abstract: How I kicked the “Red Scare” habit.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of the pandemic my wife and I moved to Manhattan from Brooklyn. There would be less space for Gerda, our husky, but no more 45-minute car commutes and no more road rage. I would walk everywhere. And I would take Gerda with me.

headline: The Engineers Are Bloggers Now
abstract: In a perpetually tricky market for tech talent, large companies are turning to an in-house resource to get the word out.
lead_paragraph: In 2021, Cristian Velazquez helped Uber fix an important software issue. First, he and his teammates diagnosed a data processing flaw that could’ve stopped the app from working correctly. Then they developed a way to clear memory more efficiently, saving the company time and money.
