lead_paragraph: Over short periods, financial markets can be treacherous. So I usually recommend spreading your risks with low-cost investments in the entire stock and bond markets, and hanging in for decades.

headline: Why Must We Go About Our Lives With an Eye on the Nearest Exit?
abstract: An “armed society” may or may not be a “polite society,” but it is far from being a democratic one.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, in Atlanta, 22-year-old Rico Marley was arrested in a Publix supermarket. He was wearing body armor and carrying six loaded weapons, including a semiautomatic rifle and a 12-gauge shotgun. Prosecutors, as my newsroom colleague Richard Fausset reports in a recent story, charged Marley with 11 felonies, including “six counts of possession of a weapon ‘during commission of or attempt to commit certain felonies.’”

headline: 17 Foods You Should Buy When They’re on Sale
abstract: And inflation-friendly recipes for how to make the most of them once you have them.
lead_paragraph: Ten-dollar cartons of eggs. Seven-dollar gallons of milk. Two-dollar apples. Everyone — even Cardi B — is feeling the pain of jaw-droppingly high food costs driven by inflation and a flurry of other factors. It’s scary to see your grocery bill skyrocket, but while no one can predict what’s going to happen to food prices in the coming year, stocking up on certain ingredients when you spot them at a lower price can help you save significantly. We talked to a few budget experts and several New York Times editors and writers about what items they buy and how they make the most of them.

headline: Will New York City’s Soccer Stadium Cost Taxpayers $0 or $516 Million?
abstract: An independent budget analysis suggests that the city will be losing $516 million in tax revenue from its deal to place a new soccer stadium in Queens.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s first professional soccer stadium supposedly carries no financial burden to New York City taxpayers — an assertion Mayor Eric Adams made repeatedly during a de facto victory tour this fall, after he announced the deal.

headline: Pamela Anderson Doesn’t Need Your Redemption. She’s Just Fine.
abstract: She was the universal sex symbol. But there is more to her story, and she’s finally telling it herself.
lead_paragraph: LADYSMITH, British Columbia — I am sitting across from Pamela Anderson, at her kitchen table, trying to explain to her that I have an app on my phone that will make me look like Pamela Anderson.

headline: Could Black Flight Change a Model of Integration?
abstract: American suburbs have long faced the issue of white families leaving as more residents of color move in. But in Shaker Heights, Ohio, Black families, upset about changes in the schools, are trickling to nearby suburbs.
lead_paragraph: Selena Boyer grew up in Shaker Heights, a leafy Cleveland suburb known nationally for its magnificent historic homes, its diverse population and its high-ranking schools. Since the 1950s, when a group of neighbors banded together to voluntarily integrate Shaker Heights, the community has prided itself on supplanting America’s racial politics with its own successful race relations.

headline: Sex, Death, Affairs: Everything People Would Rather Talk About Than Money
abstract: The merits of talking candidly about salary are widely acknowledged. Actually doing it is more complicated.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: She Witnessed Mao’s Worst Excesses. Now She Has a Warning for the World.
abstract: At 93, the memoirist Yuan-tsung Chen hopes that her recollections of China’s tumultuous past will help the country confront its historical wrongs — and avoid repeating them.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Yuan-tsung Chen, an author, leaned forward in an oversize velvet chair to tell the story of the man so hungry that he ate himself.

headline: African and Invisible: The Other New York Migrant Crisis
abstract: Like many who have crossed the border from Latin America, they arrived in New York after a desperate journey. But these men have few options in the city, often relying on one man in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: You wouldn’t know from the outside of Imam Omar Niass’s house, but the tidy brick building on a residential block in the Bronx is filled to capacity. Every night, nearly 70 men, newly arrived African migrants, sleep squashed together on the floor in an airless basement, a tangle of arms and feet and fitful dreams.

headline: ‘Burying Us Alive’: Afghan Women Devastated by Suspension of Aid Under Taliban Law
abstract: Since the Taliban administration banned women from aid work, many groups have suspended their operations in the country and warned of permanently shutting down if the ban remains.
lead_paragraph: For years before the Taliban seized power and the economy collapsed, Jamila and her four children had clung to the edge of survival. After her husband died trying to cross the Iranian border, she and her children moved to a camp for displaced people in northwestern Afghanistan and relied on aid organizations.

headline: In Miami, Food Shopping Can Start in the Parking Lot
abstract: Vendors turn their car trunks into mobile cafeterias or markets, stationed outside stores, selling produce, meat, seafood and more.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to visit the butcher counter to find the roast pork loin and Spanish hams that Alberto Ruiz and his father, Minervo, sell every week in Hialeah, Fla. Just look for the open trunk of their sedan.

headline: Turning Trash Into Poetry
abstract: Ser Serpas, a young artist known for kinetic arrangements of discarded furniture, opens up about her expressive way of processing the used world.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Compared with the junk she’s found in other cities, “Parisian trash is sturdy,” Ser Serpas said. She speaks from experience — at 27, the itinerant artist and poet is admired in European and North American art circles for precariously poised arrangements of urban discards found near the venues where they’re shown. They become site-specific descriptions of a place, written in its own delaminating school desks and tarnished bathtubs.

headline: In a Drought, California Is Watching Water Wash Out to Sea
abstract: Heavy storms have flooded parts of California, but the state has been unable to capture billions of gallons of water that are flowing unchecked into the ocean. Los Angeles is embarking on an ambitious new program to change that.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A century ago, Los Angeles built what is still widely considered one of the most sophisticated urban flood control systems in the world, designed to hold back waters from massive Pacific storms like the ones that have recently slammed the state.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, January 13, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 27 People on the Streets of New York Talk About How Much Money They Make
abstract: We asked nearly 400 people to tell us how much they earn. Here are two dozen who actually spoke to us.
lead_paragraph: Do your co-workers know how much money you earn? Do your friends? Does your family? Salary transparency is a hot topic — new laws have recently gone into effect around the country requiring employers to disclose salary ranges as a way to tackle pay inequities.

headline: ChatGPT Transforms a Classroom and Is ‘M3GAN’ Real?
abstract: Also, why teenagers are buying old digital cameras.
lead_paragraph: A high school teacher on how the new chatbot from OpenAI is transforming her classroom — for the better. And, “M3GAN” may be closer than you think.

headline: Officials Blame Negligence for Deadly Seoul Crowd Crush
abstract: Investigators want 23 people indicted but cleared senior authorities of fault in the Halloween tragedy. Victims’ families disputed the inquiry’s findings.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — South Korean officials on Friday concluded their investigation of the Halloween crowd crush that killed nearly 160 people in Seoul, blaming the police and other government agencies​ for fail​ing to take precautionary measures to avoid such a disaster and for bungling rescue operations.

headline: The Presidents and the Classified Documents
abstract: How the cases of President Biden and former President Donald Trump compare.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is scrutinizing how both former President Donald J. Trump and President Biden came to have classified records after they left office.

headline: Battling the Border Surge
abstract: The Biden administration’s border policy relies on Mexico for crucial help.
lead_paragraph: The extraordinary surge in migration across the Americas has become the single most dominant issue in the relationship between the United States and Mexico. U.S. authorities stopped migrants 2.8 million times at its southern border in the 12 months ending in September — breaking the previous record set a year earlier.

headline: Día 4: Escribe un panegírico en vida
abstract: Las personas felices expresan su gratitud a los demás.
lead_paragraph: Esta es la cuarta entrega del Reto de la felicidad en siete días de la sección Well. Para empezar este reto puedes visitar el siguiente enlace.

headline: Barry Diller Explores Sale of The Daily Beast
abstract: The tech mogul’s company has hired Whisper Advisors, an advisory firm, to find potential buyers for the digital publication.
lead_paragraph: The tech mogul Barry Diller was one of the first billionaires to experiment with digital journalism in the 2000s, teaming up with the longtime editor Tina Brown to start The Daily Beast, a scrappy tabloid for the budding online era.

headline: Did Aliens Land on Earth in 1945? A Defense Bill Seeks Answers.
abstract: The Defense Department’s annual spending bill requires it to review U.F.O. sightings dating to 1945, the year some believe an object from space crashed in the New Mexico desert.
lead_paragraph: For the casual student of U.F.O. history, the modern idea of life beyond our planet usually dates to 1947, when a top-secret U.S. military balloon crashed in the desert near Roswell, N.M. The wreckage prompted decades of conspiracy theories and gave rise to the idea that Roswell was the site of an alien crash landing.

headline: The S.E.C.’s Crypto Crackdown Intensifies
abstract: The agency has charged the crypto trading firms Genesis Global Capital and Gemini with operating an illegal lending service that lost customers millions.
lead_paragraph: Washington’s legal crackdown on crypto is intensifying, with the S.E.C. accusing some of the biggest names in the sector of operating an illegal lending service that racked up huge losses for customers.

headline: Review: Paul Mescal Electrifies in a Revelatory ‘Streetcar’
abstract: In London, the Irish actor stars as Stanley Kowalski in a deeply empathic version of Tennessee Williams’s 1947 play, “A Streetcar Named Desire.”
lead_paragraph: Paul Mescal’s fast-ascending screen career has taken a detour to the London stage, where he is playing Stanley Kowalski in “A Streetcar Named Desire.” This deeply empathic version of Tennessee Williams’s defining 1947 play is scheduled for a limited run at North London’s Almeida Theater through Feb. 4.

headline: Big Banks Set Aside Billions as They Brace for a Downturn
abstract: The country’s largest lenders increased their reserves to protect against deteriorating economic conditions this year, after reporting resilient profits for the end of last year.
lead_paragraph: America’s biggest banks issued warnings on Friday of economic malaise on the horizon, even as some reported better-than-expected profits.

headline: Tesla Cuts Prices Sharply as It Moves to Bolster Demand
abstract: The price reductions in the United States will make more of the company’s electric vehicles eligible for a federal tax credit.
lead_paragraph: Tesla has cut prices on most of its electric cars in the United States and Europe by as much as 20 percent in a bid to spur slackening demand.

headline: A Dinner Party With Soap-Shaped Chocolate Bars for Dessert
abstract: The designer Rafael Prieto turned a casual meal hosted in his New York apartment into a memorable occasion with a few unexpected touches.
lead_paragraph: The designer Rafael Prieto is not the sort to treat work and the rest of his life as two distinct realms. “It’s all, in a way, a pleasure,” he says, adding, “they mix well.” A few years ago, he decided to make a loft in a 19th-century building in Manhattan’s TriBeCa neighborhood both his home and office, so it’s out of that space that he runs Savvy Studio, the agency he co-founded in 2011 that offers branding and graphic and interior design — it’s responsible for the look of Mast Books in the East Village and much of the Maidstone Hotel in East Hampton — as well as various side projects. One, called Casa Bosques, is a multipronged endeavor driven by Prieto’s personal passions that encompasses a line of artisanal chocolate. “I tend to poke around because there are always little tidbits — chocolates, a prototype of a lamp, paper samples,” his longtime friend the artist Laila Gohar says of the apartment, where Prieto also entertains.

headline: A Conversation With Sam Liccardo, Who Led San Jose for Eight Years
abstract: Liccardo, 52, has just stepped down as mayor of California’s third-largest city.
lead_paragraph: As the new year began, California’s third-biggest city got a new mayor.

headline: Defining Nonbinary Work Wear and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Trump’s Company Gets Maximum Punishment for Evading Taxes
abstract: The Trump Organization must pay $1.6 million for giving executive off-the-books benefits and pay.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s family real estate business was ordered on Friday to pay a $1.6 million criminal penalty for its conviction on felony tax fraud and other charges, a stinging rebuke and the maximum possible punishment.

headline: JPMorgan Sets Aside Money for Bad Debts as ‘Mild Recession’ Looms
abstract: The bank, the biggest in the United States, reported a large profit in its latest quarter, but said it was girding for a downturn later in the year.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase is starting the year with a warning.

headline: Bed Bath & Beyond in Talks to Sell Assets
abstract: The beleaguered retailer, which has warned of a possible bankruptcy, is said to be in discussions with suitors about selling pieces of its business, including its Buy Buy Baby stores.
lead_paragraph: Bed Bath & Beyond, the struggling home goods retailer, is in talks with the private equity firm Sycamore Partners to sell assets, including its Buy Buy Baby stores, as part of a possible bankruptcy process, people familiar with the matter said. The retailer is also in talks with other suitors about possible transactions.

headline: Biden and Kishida Vow to Bolster U.S.-Japan Alliance as China’s Power Grows
abstract: The two leaders discussed tensions with China, North Korea and Russia and plans for deterrence in Asia with U.S. troops and missiles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden and Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan vowed Friday to work together to transform Japan into a potent military power to help counterbalance China and to bolster the alliance between the two nations so that it becomes the linchpin for their security interests in Asia.

headline: Small Wonder: 2 Picture Books About Immigrant Assimilation
abstract: Many immigrants travel to new lands in hopes of a better life, but once they arrive they often feel small.
lead_paragraph: Just shy of 5-foot-2, I’ve thought of myself as small all my life. Smallness permeated my world in other, less tangible ways as well. I listened as my Chinese immigrant parents apologized for their accents and modest English vocabularies. I watched as racism limited their opportunities and diminished their accomplishments. Early on, I learned that self-deprecation rendered me less threatening and more acceptable to the dominant culture. It’s a difficult habit to break. Two new picture books show that the ways in which immigrants and people of color make themselves small — or are forced to minimize themselves — are myriad.

headline: Title Search: Can You Find the 21 Fantasy Books Hidden in This Story?
abstract: Test your questing skills with this puzzle that conceals the names of several classic and award-winning novels within a short text passage.
lead_paragraph: Test your questing skills with this puzzle that conceals the names of several classic and award-winning novels within a short text passage.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Make Bryan Washington’s new miso pecan banana bread recipe your own.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Bryan Washington has a love letter to banana bread in The New York Times Magazine this week and, with it, a lovely new recipe for miso pecan banana bread (above) that I think every one of us should make this weekend.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a Latvian satire about World War II, a family portrait by an Indian documentarian, an Oedipal thriller from Mexico and more.
lead_paragraph: Set during World War II, “The Sign Painter” tells a dark, real-life history with bracing irony and fairy-tale whimsy. Ansis, a sign painter in rural Latvia, lives through three regime changes in the span of a decade, each reflected in the hues he’s asked to color official buildings and signs with: green is favored by the dictatorship of Karlis Ulmanis, red by the Soviet occupation, and black by the Nazi invasion that follows.

headline: Even a Little Alcohol Can Harm Your Health
abstract: Recent research makes it clear that any amount of drinking can be detrimental. Here’s why you may want to cut down on your consumption beyond Dry January.
lead_paragraph: Sorry to be a buzz-kill, but that nightly glass or two of wine is not improving your health.

headline: How Much is Too Much?
abstract: You may want to extend that Dry January: Even moderate drinking can impact your long-term health, experts say. Here’s what you need to know about alcohol’s effect on your body.
lead_paragraph: You may want to extend that Dry January: Even moderate drinking can impact your long-term health, experts say. Here’s what you need to know about alcohol’s effect on your body.

headline: Your New York City Dining Questions, Answered
abstract: This week, I’m answering reader questions submitted to the Where to Eat: New York City newsletter.
lead_paragraph: This week, I’m answering reader questions submitted to the Where to Eat: New York City newsletter.

headline: Remains of Florida Woman Missing Since Hurricane Ian Are Found
abstract: The woman, Ilonka Knes, 82, was among the 146 people in Florida who died in the September storm, the state’s deadliest since 1935.
lead_paragraph: Update: The remains of the last person in Lee County who had been missing since Hurricane Ian have been found.

headline: A Faked Kidnapping and Cocaine: A Montana Mine’s Descent Into Chaos
abstract: The Signal Peak Mine was embroiled in a web of criminal activity. Now, environmental groups want to shut it down.
lead_paragraph: Just before 2 a.m. on April 18, 2018, Amy Price, the wife of the coal executive Larry Price Jr., called the police in Bluefield, Va., to report her husband missing. Police scoured Bluefield, a town of less than 10,000 people nestled in the Blue Ridge Mountains, and soon discovered Mr. Price’s white Mercedes at a deserted parking lot.

headline: How Western Goods Reach Russia: A Long Line of Trucks Through Georgia
abstract: With Western sanctions barring many imports, a lot of what Russia needs now travels a slow, crowded truck route through the Caucasus Mountains from Georgia.
lead_paragraph: KAZBEGI CHECKPOINT, Georgia — Each day, a caravan of trucks stretches for miles along a mountain highway in Georgia, near the border with Russia. Each day, the line seems to get longer.

headline: The State of Kate
abstract: Catherine, Princess of Wales, seems to live in a state of perpetual waiting. What does that do to a woman?
lead_paragraph: Prince Harry’s blockbuster memoir, “Spare,” has dragged the royal family back into international focus with details at once banal and intriguing. Kate Middleton, as she is still sometimes known to those of us who remember her before her royal marriage, figures in the memoir and the Netflix documentary “Harry & Meghan” as a sketch of steely disapproval and emotional coolness.

headline: About That Gas Stove
abstract: ‘Should I get rid of my gas stove’ isn’t the only question to ask. It may not even be the right one.
lead_paragraph: My grandmother in India cooked for many years with coal, then with a tank of liquid petroleum gas. As a child in California, I lived in an apartment with an electric stove, then in a house with a gas connection. In London, last summer, I stayed in an apartment with an induction stove that glowed red in an instant. In Kenya a few years before that, I spent hours talking to women cooking dinner in smoky kitchens, over charcoal.

headline: Constantine II, the Last King of Greece, Dies at 82
abstract: An Olympic medalist, he was popular when he took the throne in 1964. But his efforts to intervene in Greek politics led to a coup and his ouster.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Constantine II, the last king of Greece, who ruled for just three years during a turbulent period in the country’s modern history that culminated in the abolition of the monarchy, died on Tuesday in a hospital here. He was 82.

headline: Lisa Marie Presley, a Life in Pictures
abstract: The daughter of Elvis was famous from the moment she was born.
lead_paragraph: Celebrity, tabloid fodder, would-be rock star, nepo baby — who went on to have her own movie star, nepo baby (Riley Keough) — Lisa Marie Presley packed so much of our collective cultural id into her tiny frame over her 54 years that it was hard to know who she was beneath it all. She had the sleepy eyes of her father, Elvis, and the delicate bone structure of her mother, Priscilla, and was famous from the moment she was born: part of the story of the damage and joy the spotlight can wreak and how it can trickle down over generations. She struggled to define her own identity even as she embraced her birthright (and various equally headline-grabbing men, including Michael Jackson and Nicolas Cage), landing on the cover of Vogue in 1996 with a story entitled “Daddy’s Girl.” Inside, Steven Meisel captured her trying on different selves, literally, to see how they might fit — including one shot of her grinning in a khaki Prada camp shirt and tie, cropped black hair in a rockabilly bouffant, channeling her father during his army days when he was still a fresh-faced twentysomething riding the crest of his talent. In the end, she was heir not just to his looks and estate, but the myth too.

headline: Everything But the Girl’s Long-Awaited Return, and 12 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Miley Cyrus, Vagabon, Lonnie Holley featuring Michael Stipe and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: ‘Avatar’: The Way of the Restroom
abstract: The movie’s three-hour-plus run time, which includes scene after scene of churning seas, is a recipe for repeated bathroom breaks.
lead_paragraph: Alex Brizard deliberately did not buy a beverage when he went to see a 9:30 a.m. showing of “Avatar: The Way of Water” this month. It did not matter: He still had to run to the bathroom three times over the course of the movie’s three hours and 12 minutes.

headline: Should an Oil Executive Oversee Climate Talks? The U.A.E. Thinks So.
abstract: Sultan Al Jaber, who heads the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, was chosen by the United Arab Emirates to head the upcoming COP28 summit, drawing criticism from green groups.
lead_paragraph: A decision by the United Arab Emirates to select the head of its national oil company, one of the world’s largest, to oversee U.N. climate talks in Dubai this year has drawn ire from environmental groups across the world.

headline: Review: A Guest Conductor Reveals the Philharmonic’s Potential
abstract: Santtu-Matias Rouvali, a contender for the orchestra’s podium, shined in “The Rite of Spring” — the piece Jaap van Zweden began his tenure there with.
lead_paragraph: When Jaap van Zweden led his first concert as the New York Philharmonic’s music director, in September 2018, he ended the evening with Stravinsky’s “The Rite of Spring.” Instead of an auspicious climax it was a red flag, a sign of many more performances like it to come: paradoxically rushed and ponderous; stridently martial; so obsessed with detail, there was little sense of a cohesive whole.

headline: Can’t We Protect Classified Papers Better?
abstract: Investigations into two presidents’ handling of secret documents. Also: Hunter Biden and Prince Harry; the debt limit; psychiatric care; editing; libraries.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Easy, Festive Dishes for Chinese New Year at Home
abstract: Wontons may be an everyday affair, but that’s all the more reason to celebrate with them, Genevieve Ko writes.
lead_paragraph: The last time my parents, siblings and I traveled together to Hong Kong — in 1997, to witness the handover from Britain back to China — my dad took us to the part of Kowloon where he grew up. At one point, he slipped down an alley, alone, to visit his favorite childhood wonton stand and returned with a contentment I coveted.

headline: U.S. Will Hit Debt Limit on Thursday, Yellen Tells Congress
abstract: The Treasury Department expects to begin taking “extraordinary measures” to continue paying the government’s obligations before what is expected to be a big fight to raise the borrowing cap.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen warned on Friday that she would have to begin employing “extraordinary measures” on Thursday to continue paying the nation’s bills if lawmakers did not act to raise the statutory debt limit and that her powers to delay a default could be exhausted by early June.

headline: Kevin Spacey Pleads Not Guilty to 7 Charges of Sexual Misconduct in U.K.
abstract: The Oscar-winning actor had already pleaded not guilty in July to five other counts of sexual misconduct. He is currently out on bail.
lead_paragraph: The Oscar-winning actor Kevin Spacey pleaded not guilty in a hearing at a London court on Friday to seven more charges of sexual misconduct, the BBC and other British news outlets reported.

headline: Russia Found ‘No Fault’ for Figure Skater in Doping Violation
abstract: Kamila Valieva, whose positive test came to light during the Olympics, received a light penalty, drawing a sharp rebuke from the World Anti-Doping Agency.
lead_paragraph: The Russian Anti-Doping Agency has found that the figure-skating star Kamila Valieva bore “no fault or negligence” for her doping violation before the Beijing Olympics, the World Anti-Doping Agency said in a statement that sharply rebuked Russia’s handling of the case involving one of the country’s top athletes.

headline: Fans Mourn Lisa Marie Presley, Daughter of the King, at Graceland
abstract: At the stone wall outside Elvis Presley’s estate, his only child was remembered as a kind of rock star royalty.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — Some wrote messages on the stone wall in front of Graceland, the storied Memphis mansion that housed Elvis Presley’s studded jumpsuits and his private plane, the Lisa Marie, customized with gold bathroom fixtures. Others left flowers.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Show with Katharina Pistor
abstract: The Jan. 13, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Rogé Karma and featuring Katharina Pistor. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Love Letter: A Former Monk’s Dating Advice
abstract: Plus: The role that texting plays in new relationships.
lead_paragraph: After Jay Shetty left his life as a monk at a Hindu ashram, he began dating again. Driven by insecurity, he quickly found himself falling into detrimental, old dating habits.

headline: How to Shop for Warm, Waterproof Boots
abstract: It's important that they're tall enough.
lead_paragraph: It's important that they're tall enough.

headline: What I’m Excited to Cook This Year
abstract: Melissa Clark’s green curry salmon with coconut rice is at the top of my weeknight list.
lead_paragraph: Hello you, and happy new year. This is my first dispatch of 2023, and I’m excited to cook. I was away for the holidays, so I entered January refreshed in this regard, delighted to be in my own kitchen and swiping through recipes like I’m on a dating app. (There’s also the fact that it’s January, the best time of year to just stay home.)

headline: Miguel Gutierrez Awarded New York Live Arts Residency
abstract: The choreographer will receive a commission for a new production and two years of full-time salary and health care benefits.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Miguel Gutierrez is the next recipient of New York Live Arts’ biennial residency award, the organization announced on Friday. The award, the Randjelovic/Stryker Resident Commissioned Artist, is notable for the breadth of its creative and financial support, which includes a fully produced production and office space, as well as two years of full-time salary and health care benefits.

headline: Sweden Says It Has Uncovered a Rare Earth Bonanza
abstract: A state-owned mining company announced it had found Europe’s largest deposit of the vital minerals used in electric vehicles and other green technology.
lead_paragraph: A Swedish mining company said this week that it had found Europe’s largest known deposit of coveted rare earth metals, critical to many green technologies including electric vehicles, in a far northern part of the country within the Arctic Circle.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The late-night hosts had their hands full this week with Kevin McCarthy finally getting sworn in as House speaker, Prince Harry’s new memoir, and the batches of classified documents found in locations linked to President Biden.
lead_paragraph: The late-night hosts had their hands full this week with Kevin McCarthy finally getting sworn in as House speaker, Prince Harry’s new memoir, and the batches of classified documents found in locations linked to President Biden.

headline: ‘We Just Couldn’t Keep Up With the Volume’
abstract: Southwest Airlines’ chief executive, Bob Jordan, said frigid temperatures and mistakes by the company caused its meltdown around Christmas.
lead_paragraph: In the days leading up to Christmas, the chief executive of Southwest Airlines, Bob Jordan, thought the company would quickly recover from the frigid weather that forced thousands of flight cancellations nationwide. But that changed by Dec. 25 when it became clear that the airline’s problems were spiraling out of control.

headline: Investors Are Walking a Tightrope as Stocks Rise for a Second Week
abstract: Signs of slowing inflation are competing with downbeat company forecasts as earnings season begins.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street notched a second week of gains on Friday, a cautious rally that’s come as investors anticipate an easing in the Federal Reserve’s inflation fight, but have to balance that against the prospect that interest rates could remain high for some time.

headline: Review: Songs That Defy the ‘Quotidian Nature of Evil’
abstract: The composer Shawn Okpebholo has created a song cycle that imagines the inner lives of fugitives from American slavery.
lead_paragraph: “Songs in Flight,” a new cycle by the composer Shawn Okpebholo, with texts chosen by Tsitsi Ella Jaji, a poet and associate professor at Duke University, had its premiere at the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium on Thursday. With an opening set by the singer-songwriter Rhiannon Giddens, the concert found uncommon power in the humble format of folk and art songs.

headline: At Juventus, a Strange Season Takes Another Turn
abstract: A rough start to the season has been forgotten in Italy amid an executive housecleaning and a brief glimpse at the top of the league table.
lead_paragraph: UPDATE: Juventus was docked 15 points in the Italian league standings on Jan. 20 as punishment for “financial irregularities” in the transfer market. The club said it would appeal.

headline: Another Public, Painful Loss for Priscilla Presley
abstract: Priscilla Presley appeared with her daughter, Lisa Marie Presley, at the Golden Globes on Tuesday, just days before her death.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, Priscilla Presley and her daughter, Lisa Marie Presley, sat side by side at their table at the Golden Globes and watched with emotion as Austin Butler won an award for his portrayal of Elvis in the Baz Luhrmann film of the same name.

headline: Picking Through Rubble After Tornadoes Tear Through Southeast
abstract: In Georgia and Alabama, rescuers were searching for victims and survivors on Friday as communities tried to assess the destruction. At least nine have died from the storms.
lead_paragraph: MARBURY, Ala. — William Lambert could see the funnel forming outside his front door. As the tornado descended on his home in central Alabama, he ran into a bathroom with his son while his wife crowded into a closet with their three grandchildren.

headline: Who Are the Proud Boys on Trial for Seditious Conspiracy?
abstract: The five defendants are members of one of the nation’s best-known far-right groups and are accused of helping to lead the assault on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
lead_paragraph: One of the country’s most prominent far-right extremist groups, the Proud Boys have embraced a violent version of patriarchal nationalism since forming in 2016 and aligning themselves with former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: ‘House Party’ Review: A Rager Gone South
abstract: Directed by Calmatic, “House Party” reboots the 1990 Kid ’n Play cult comedy with the help of LeBron James.
lead_paragraph: The dilemma of the modern-day movie reboot, particularly in Hollywood’s current I.P. gold-rush era, might be called the “super size me” problem. If you’re going to redo it, why not go bigger, make it more star-studded, and add a little meta wink? After all, what is actually being reconfigured is, for better or worse, not necessarily the soul or story of the original, but the cultural commodity it has become.

headline: Greek Court Drops Espionage Charges Against Aid Workers
abstract: The 24 defendants had been charged with misdemeanors over their work with migrants, but they still face more serious charges.
lead_paragraph: A Greek court dropped charges of espionage against two dozen aid workers on Friday, ending a trial that was widely criticized by human rights organizations and that illustrated the hard line some European countries are taking over migration.

headline: Goldman’s Pitch to the Little Guy Turns Costly, as Struggles Mount
abstract: Goldman Sachs will take a big hit from its ill-fated move into consumer banking, even as its other businesses weaken amid an economic slowdown.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is paying for its misbegotten foray into consumer banking.

headline: Saks Fifth Avenue Wants to Add a Casino Atop Its Flagship Store
abstract: Hudson’s Bay Company, the owner of the department store, unveiled plans for a casino in Midtown Manhattan, joining the race for one of three full-fledged gambling licenses in the city.
lead_paragraph: The race to build New York’s first full-service casino is going upscale.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: New releases this week include Joshua Prager’s "The Family Roe," a collection of essays by Zora Neale Hurston and more.
lead_paragraph: New releases this week include Joshua Prager’s "The Family Roe," a collection of essays by Zora Neale Hurston and more.

headline: Leader of Biden’s Covid Vaccine Effort Is Stepping Down
abstract: Dr. David A. Kessler took over Operation Warp Speed when President Biden entered office, and his departure signals the end of the program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Dr. David A. Kessler, who for the past two years has been the behind-the-scenes force driving a vast federal effort to develop and distribute coronavirus vaccines and treatments, is leaving the Biden administration — another sign that the pandemic is no longer front and center for the White House.

headline: The Power of Instant Pudding Mix
abstract: Your favorite dessert may have a not-so-secret ingredient.
lead_paragraph: The pistachio Bundt cake at Claud has a secret.

headline: Presidents and Their Prosecutors
abstract: Since the dark days of Watergate, every president but one has faced a special prosecutor scrutinizing them or their associates. President Biden now joins the club.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two years ago, President Biden joined the world’s most exclusive club. This week, he joined a less exalted club — but, in the modern era, one almost as large.

headline: Russell Pearce, Fiery Foe of Illegal Immigration, Dies at 75
abstract: As an Arizona state senator, he sponsored what came to be known as the “show me your papers” law, requiring the police to demand documentation from those they detained.
lead_paragraph: Russell Pearce, the Arizona state senator who fathered the nation’s most unforgiving legal sanctions on illegal immigrants — including what came to be known as the “show me your papers” law — only to have some of the legislation revoked and find himself removed from office, died on Jan. 5 at his home in Mesa, Ariz. He was 75.

headline: Lumberyard Performing Arts Center in Hudson Valley to Be Sold
abstract: The American Dance Institute, which operates the center, said the pandemic and shifting priorities of donors had led it to rethink its mission.
lead_paragraph: Lumberyard, a state-of-the-art performing arts center in Catskill, N.Y., that since 2018 has attracted renowned artists and dancers from New York City and beyond, will be sold as its parent organization, the American Dance Institute, rethinks its mission, the institute announced on Friday.

headline: Will Euthanasia Be Secular or Sacred?
abstract: Two ways of looking at assisted suicide.
lead_paragraph: Last month, I wrote a harsh column about the Canadian euthanasia system, which has expanded rapidly over the past few years, with over 10,000 people ending their lives under its auspices in 2021. This week, I want to recommend two very different analyses of the Canadian experience.

headline: The Not-So-Great News About Lower Inflation
abstract: The fact that consumer prices fell isn’t entirely a good thing for the Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: The news that consumer prices fell in December from November — yes, monthly inflation was negative — was not as wonderful for the Federal Reserve as you might expect. Fed officials are trying to persuade the financial markets and the public that the fight against high inflation is far from over, and this data point doesn’t help make its case.

headline: At Under the Radar, Stories Unfold via Sexts, Tweets and Puppeteers
abstract: The Public Theater’s experimental theater festival is back in person for the first time since 2020. Here, our critics review a handful of the works on display.
lead_paragraph: The art of talking dirty has withered of late. Or so Rachel Mars sets out to demonstrate in “Your Sexts Are Shit: Older Better Letters,” her filthy, funny yet eventually cloying performance piece dressed in the incongruous drag of a lecture.

headline: Wonking Out: It’s Getting Harder to Be a Pessimist on Inflation
abstract: Some of us on “Team Transitory” were too optimistic, but now others are making the opposite mistake.
lead_paragraph: Thursday’s report on consumer prices was really good news. I mean, really, really good news. The overall Consumer Price Index actually fell slightly for the month of December. We can and should downplay that number, because it was driven in part by special factors like a plunge in gasoline prices and because monthly data are noisy. But even when you try to filter out the noise by excluding more volatile prices and looking at averages over several months, you get a picture of rapidly slowing inflation.

headline: Sweatpants on Trial: How Thom Browne Beat Adidas in Court
abstract: Could a trademark lawsuit over stripes change how we think about athletic wear?
lead_paragraph: There is no limit to where a fashion brand will hold a fashion show, it seems: a church, a decommissioned warship, an abandoned subway station, a stock exchange, the Great Wall of China, the Giza pyramids. Extremity begets exposure, and very little is sacred.

headline: When Did We All Become Pop Culture Detectives?
abstract: Harvesting Easter eggs is now integral to our consumption of entertainment. But there’s a fine line between perceptiveness and paranoia.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Review: From an Eco Art Village, a Dance About Community
abstract: Vertigo Dance Company’s “Pardes” is handsomely constructed if occasionally contrived.
lead_paragraph: The title of Vertigo Dance Company’s newest touring work, “Pardes,” is the Hebrew word for orchard, or garden of trees, from the Persian pairidaeza. Say it out loud, and its etymological connection to “paradise” is clear.

headline: Robbie Knievel, a Motorcycle Daredevil Like His Father, Dies at 60
abstract: He followed his father, Evel Knievel, into the high-flying world of motorcycle stunts, jumping the Grand Canyon and the fountains at Caesars Palace.
lead_paragraph: Robbie Knievel, a daredevil performer who soared into the sky on motorcycles, pulling off a series of spectacular airborne stunts like his father, Evel Knievel, died on Friday at his home in Reno, Nev. He was 60.

headline: A Hilltop Hideaway in the Scottish Highlands
abstract: Plus: an art collector’s villa in Tangier, a wellness resort in Kaua’i and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to T Wanderlust, a new travel newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Twice a month, we’ll recommend global destinations and hotels worth visiting. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every other Friday, along with our T List newsletter each Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Clouded Leopard Found at Dallas Zoo After ‘Suspicious’ Tear in Enclosure
abstract: Nova, a 25-pound clouded leopard, was found on the zoo grounds after a daylong search. Officials said she had been missing after an intentional tear was made in the mesh of her enclosure.
lead_paragraph: The Dallas Zoo said on Friday afternoon that a clouded leopard that had been missing all day had been recovered after officials said they found a “suspicious” tear in the animal’s enclosure.

headline: Casey Hayden, a Force for Civil Rights and Feminism, Dies at 85
abstract: While working for the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee in the early 1960s, she helped write two memos that spurred the modern women’s movement.
lead_paragraph: Casey Hayden, an important organizer for the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee during its push for civil rights in the early 1960s and the co-author of two papers that called out sexism within that organization and in society in general — documents that are credited with helping to inspire second-wave feminism — died on Jan. 4 at her home in Tucson, Ariz. She was 85.

headline: Hannes Keller, Swiss Deep-Sea Diving Pioneer, Is Dead at 88
abstract: His 1,020-foot descent to the Pacific Ocean floor in a diving bell in 1962 made headlines and set a record. But it had disastrous consequences.
lead_paragraph: Hannes Keller, a Swiss mathematician and inspired amateur explorer, planned his audacious deep ocean dive for more than a year. In December 1962, he intended to descend deeper than anyone before him: 1,000 feet down, off Santa Catalina Island, near Los Angeles, in a diving bell called the Atlantis.

headline: A Small, Disputed Victory
abstract: Russia claims control of Soledar but analysts see little impact on the course of the war.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: How Classified Information Is Handled
abstract: Presidents have established and developed the classification system through a series of executive orders around World War II and the early Cold War.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The special counsel investigations involving classified documents that improperly accompanied former President Donald J. Trump and President Biden when they left office have heightened interest in how the government handles sensitive materials.

headline: Justice Dept. Cracks Down on Firearm Accessories in Bid to Bolster Gun Safety
abstract: A final rule will require gun owners to apply for a permit within 120 days to use the accessories known as stabilizing braces.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration said on Friday that it would crack down on the sale of firearm accessories used to convert short-barreled semiautomatic weapons into long rifles, part of a stepped-up effort to address mass shootings.

headline: School Searched 6-Year-Old’s Backpack Before Newport News Shooting, Officials Say
abstract: No weapon was found during the search, according to the school district. The 6-year-old boy is accused of later shooting his teacher.
lead_paragraph: On the day that a first-grade teacher was shot in her classroom last week, a school employee, acting on a tip, searched the backpack of a 6-year-old boy to check for a gun, according to district officials in Newport News, Va.

headline: Barclays Center Drops a New Ticket Vendor for Its Old One: Ticketmaster
abstract: The Brooklyn venue replaced Ticketmaster, the industry leader, in 2021 in favor of SeatGeek, a competitor. It is not clear why it changed direction again.
lead_paragraph: In 2021, Barclays Center in Brooklyn made a surprising announcement about its business: After nearly a decade with Ticketmaster, the industry leader, as its ticketing vendor, the arena was switching to SeatGeek, an aggressive upstart.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Russia’s Claim to Seize a Ukrainian Town Exposes Rifts Among Forces
abstract: After Russia’s Defense Ministry said its troops had taken Soledar, a leader of the Wagner mercenary group accused the military of stealing credit. Ukraine said its forces were still fighting there.
lead_paragraph: A Russian claim of victory on Friday in a town in eastern Ukraine exposed a growing rift in Moscow’s war effort, as the Russian military and a private mercenary group contradicted each other publicly about who should get credit for the gains.

headline: Biden Will Deliver State of the Union Address on Feb. 7
abstract: President Biden’s speech will be his first appearance before a House led by Republicans who are unlikely to cooperate with his agenda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden will deliver his second State of the Union speech on Feb. 7, a nationwide address that comes even as he faces an improving economy, an aggressive House controlled by Republicans and a special counsel investigation into the possible mishandling of classified information.

headline: Peter Grose, Veteran Foreign Correspondent, Dies at 88
abstract: His career with The New York Times took him to Saigon and Moscow. He drew on that experience later to write several well-received books.
lead_paragraph: Peter Grose, one of the last of a generation of foreign correspondents who cut their teeth covering the Vietnam War — an experience that he drew on later for assignments in Moscow and Jerusalem, and later still as the author of several well-received books about American history, died on Dec. 31 in Minneapolis. He was 88.

headline: Writer’s Lawsuit Accusing Trump of Rape Can Proceed, Judge Rules
abstract: In allowing E. Jean Carroll’s lawsuit to move forward, Judge Lewis Kaplan upheld the legality of New York’s Adult Survivors Act.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday rejected former President Donald J. Trump’s effort to dismiss a lawsuit in which the writer E. Jean Carroll accuses Mr. Trump of raping her in a dressing room at a Fifth Avenue department store in the mid-1990s.

headline: Santos’s Lies Were Known to Some Well-Connected Republicans
abstract: George Santos inspired no shortage of suspicion during his 2022 campaign, including in the upper echelons of his own party, yet many Republicans looked the other way.
lead_paragraph: In late 2021, as he prepared to make a second run for a suburban New York City House seat, George Santos gave permission for his campaign to commission a routine background study on him.

headline: ‘We Will Die for Brazil’: How a Far-Right Mob Tried to Oust Lula
abstract: The storming of Brazil’s capital failed to overthrow the elected government. But an examination of the attack reveals how extremism is threatening Latin America’s largest democracy.
lead_paragraph: As the bus made its way from Brazil’s agricultural heartland to the capital, Andrea Barth pulled out her phone to ask fellow passengers, one by one, what they intended to do once they arrived.

headline: No Increased Stroke Risk Linked to Pfizer’s Covid Boosters, Federal Officials Say
abstract: An uptick hinted at in surveillance data was a mirage, the officials said.
lead_paragraph: Fears that the Covid booster shots made by Pfizer-BioNTech may increase the risk of strokes in people aged 65 and older were not borne out by an intensive scientific investigation, federal officials said on Friday.

headline: Biden Administration Faces Resistance to Plan to Sell F-16s to Turkey
abstract: The State Department has contacted Congress about major arms deals for Turkey and Greece, but a prominent senator is strongly opposed to the Ankara sale.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration has informed Congress that it wants to discuss proposed major arms sales for Turkey and Greece, according to two U.S. officials, but it already faces resistance on Capitol Hill to Ankara’s request for new and upgraded F-16 fighter jets.

headline: Fentanyl Helps Push Overdose Deaths to Record Level in New York City
abstract: The city’s health commissioner said fatalities appeared to still be surging despite measures meant to keep addicted people alive.
lead_paragraph: The first time Reneé Jones overdosed on drugs last year, she was at her daughter’s Bronx apartment and had gotten up to get one of her seven grandchildren a cup of water. The next thing she knew, a paramedic was jolting her back to life with a defibrillator.

headline: Bolsonaro Faces Investigation for Inspiring Brazil’s Capital Riot
abstract: Brazil’s Supreme Court said it would investigate Jair Bolsonaro, the country’s former president, for inspiring the mob that stormed the nation’s halls of power on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Brazil’s Supreme Court said it would investigate former president Jair Bolsonaro for inspiring the far-right mob that invaded and ransacked the country’s Congress, Supreme Court and presidential offices this week, a swift escalation in the probe that shows the former leader could soon face legal consequences for an extremist movement that he helped build.

headline: Go-Getter
abstract: David Karp’s Saturday grid is fresh and feisty.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is David Karp’s second Times puzzle, after his debut on a Friday last September. I needed several trips around this grid to solve it, which is appropriate because it has three symmetries: rotational, which is typical crossword geometry, but also left-right (vertical) and up-down (horizontal), less common attributes. In this case, the underpinnings of that complex arrangement are four excellent span entries; the two at 5- and 6-Down, in particular, had me chuffed.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 14, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 14, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the appointment of a special counsel to investigate the presence of classified documents in President Biden’s private office and home misspelled the surname of a former deputy White House counsel and Justice Department official. He is Timothy Flanigan, not Flanagan.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Portugal’s Big Bet on a Hydro Future
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 14, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “This is my pyramids.”

headline: To Keep Your Running Goals on Track, Run in a Group
abstract: Running with other people is not only more fun but can also provide accountability and support as you train. Virtual friends count, too.
lead_paragraph: My first experiences running were on my high school track team, but as an adult, I’ve become mostly a solo runner. That’s one advantage of running: You don’t need a team or a class. But it can help. Strava, an exercise-tracking app, released its Year In Sport report, and one data point caught my eye: Runners who had group activities in January 2022 recorded 78 percent more active time than those who ran solo.

headline: How N.F.L. Receivers Run Their Routes, Step by Step
abstract: In split seconds, their moves make all the difference. Justin Jefferson, Adam Thielen, Tyreek Hill, DeVonta Smith and CeeDee Lamb sat down with us to dissect the art of route running.
lead_paragraph: EAGAN, Minn. — The N.F.L. is a passing league, so quarterbacks’ names — rightfully — receive top billing.

headline: Iran Executes Former Defense Official, a Dual U.K. Citizen, on Spy Charges
abstract: Alireza Akbari, previously a senior military and defense official, had moved to Britain a decade ago. He had been detained since 2019.
lead_paragraph: Iran has executed Alireza Akbari, a former deputy defense minister and a dual British citizen, on charges of espionage for the British spy agency, the judiciary said early Saturday, in what appeared to be the first execution in decades of a high-profile Iranian official or dual citizen, and a move likely to raise tensions with the West.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: German Village at Center of a Fight Over Coal and Climate Is Cleared Out
abstract: For years, activists tried to save tiny Lützerath from being razed to make way for the expansion of an open-pit coal mine. This past week, the police moved them out.
lead_paragraph: LÜTZERATH, Germany — The fight for Lützerath was long, but the end, when it finally came, was quick.

headline: Someone in Maine Won the $1.35 Billion Mega Millions Jackpot
abstract: The lucky player has not yet been identified, and Maine allows winners to remain anonymous. Big jackpots are becoming more common in the multistate lotteries.
lead_paragraph: A single ticket-holder in Maine won an estimated $1.35 billion in the Mega Millions drawing on Friday night.

headline: Bret Easton Ellis Is Back to His Regularly Scheduled Programming
abstract: In his latest novel, “The Shards,” the author returns to his old tropes: gruesome murder, lonely teenagers and 1980s Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles, 1981 — the affluent Westside canyons. Kim Carnes’s “Bette Davis Eyes” is on the radio, “The Shining” has just come out in theaters and Wayfarer sunglasses adorn all the young faces. Bret, the 17-­year-old protagonist of Bret Easton Ellis’s sprawling new novel, “The Shards,” has been left alone at his parents’ house on Mulholland Drive for months at the start of his senior year. Bret is a budding writer. He is gay, and closeted.

headline: When the Ghost of the Chelsea Hotel Is You
abstract: A writer tries to adjust to the sleek new revamp of her haunted childhood home.
lead_paragraph: I was six when I saw my first angel — a beautiful man who roamed the halls naked save a cloth diaper and massive feather wings. He never spoke.

headline: Who Benefits When Salary Info Is Public?
abstract: It’s good for pay equity, and it can be good for managers, but it’s not so good for superstars.
lead_paragraph: This month, laws went into effect in California and Washington State that required companies to post salary ranges on job listings. Like similar rules in New York City and Colorado, lawmakers passed them on the premise that pay transparency helped reduce wage gaps.

headline: My Boss Told My Co-workers That I Had Covid. Isn’t That Illegal?
abstract: Federal guidelines require employees’ health information to be kept confidential. But employers also have an obligation to protect the workplace.
lead_paragraph: Q: I’m an employee in a New York City co-op building, and a member of the Local 32BJ union. Recently, one of my co-workers was out sick and some residents learned that he had Covid-19. I asked the superintendent how they knew, telling him that this was private information. Then a few weeks later, the same thing happened to me: I returned to work after having been out with Covid, and some tenants asked me about it. One told me that she learned from another employee that I had Covid. But I had only informed the super. I am concerned about why and how this information is spreading. What rights do I have to protect my medical privacy?

headline: Life and Much Death in the Amazon
abstract: In “Masters of the Lost Land,” Heriberto Araujo investigates a region where land and people are routinely sacrificed to greed and corruption.
lead_paragraph: In 1970, the military dictatorship that ruled Brazil launched one of the world’s most ambitious construction projects: the Trans Amazonian Highway, a 2,600-mile road across the Amazon River basin. It was “a necessary effort,” President Emílio Garrastazu Médici declared at the time, “to solve two problems: one of people without land … and another of land without people.”

headline: A Writer Collapses. As He Recovers, His Dispatches Captivate Readers.
abstract: Hanif Kureishi lost use of his arms and legs. In tweets dictated to family members, he narrates the drama, and muses about writing and art, love and patience. He’s also quite funny.
lead_paragraph: Just after Christmas, the writer Hanif Kureishi was taking a long walk in Rome, where he and his wife, Isabella D’Amico, were spending the holiday, when he suddenly collapsed onto the sidewalk. It is unclear why — perhaps he fainted, said his son Carlo Kureishi, or perhaps he suffered an epileptic fit — but he fell awkwardly, twisting his neck and grievously injuring the top of his spine.

headline: How Rachael Price, of Lake Street Dive, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: The singer, who is expecting her first child, spends hours strolling through Brooklyn and reading.
lead_paragraph: Rachael Price is the front woman of the rock band Lake Street Dive. She is also half of the duo Rachael & Vilray, a jazzier act with a 1930s and ’40s sound. This weekend, Ms. Price, along with the singer and guitarist Vilray, is releasing the duo’s second album, “I Love a Love Song!” They are scheduled to perform at Williamsburg Music Hall on Feb. 24.

headline: Happy New Year. Now Please Stay Home.
abstract: Sniffles, coughs and sneezes have become January’s familiar cacophony.
lead_paragraph: Julie Vadnal was visiting family in Michigan over Christmas when everyone “started to drop like flies,” she said. “The day we left, my mom had gotten a fever, and my sister had gotten a fever, and it was like, we have to get out of here.”

headline: Brooklyn’s Lifeguard Factory Is Open Again
abstract: A high school in Bushwick is coaxing teenagers into a long-neglected pool, turning nonswimmers into competitors — and possibly a summer job in a lifeguard chair.
lead_paragraph: The Bushwick Tigers huddled in a circle on their pool deck, put their hands in the center and roared.

headline: Lisa Marie Presley Was Rock ’n’ Roll Royalty. Graceland Was Her Castle.
abstract: Ms. Presley, who died suddenly on Thursday, had visited the estate four days earlier to celebrate what would have been her father’s 88th birthday.

headline: Bring Out Your Dead (Christmas Trees)
abstract: “New Yorkers know that, for these couple of weeks, we are running the best-smelling garbage trucks in the world,” a city official said.
lead_paragraph: During the holiday season, the smell of Christmas trees for sale in New York City lingers in the air.

headline: Hunting for Truffles Is a Perilous Pursuit, Especially for the Dogs Who Dig
abstract: Truffles are big business, and some are trying to take out the competition by poisoning the dogs that accompany those known as “truffle hunters.”
lead_paragraph: CAMERATA NUOVA — On a bright morning in the mountains above the sleepy central Italian town of Camerata Nuova, a small and curly coated dog named Bella raced among the birch trees. As her owner leaned on a long, harpoon-shaped spade and shouted encouragement, she darted toward a tree and dug under a frosted carpet of dead leaves.

headline: The War in Ukraine Upended Energy Markets. What Does That Mean for the Climate?
abstract: Almost a year after Russia launched its invasion, assessing the impact on the oil industry and greenhouse gas goals is not so simple.
lead_paragraph: As world leaders, chief executives and nonprofit leaders descend on Davos, Switzerland, for the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum next week, war will be raging about 1,000 miles away.

headline: Even With the Crowds, Davos Is a Winter Haven
abstract: Many tourist spots are shut down or blocked off during the World Economic Forum, yet there’s still plenty to do amid the clear air and mountain vistas.
lead_paragraph: It may be synonymous with the World Economic Forum’s annual gathering of world leaders, but Davos, Switzerland, is, first and foremost, a winter sports mecca.

headline: When Black Characters Double-Deal to Make Ends Meet, It’s Never Enough
abstract: In three Broadway plays this season, a quest for financial stability can’t undo the trauma of the past or dismantle the architecture that places a ceiling on Black futures.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: How to Ask for a Raise, Without Alienating Your Boss Along the Way
abstract: Tips from psychologists, managers and people who have successfully asked what can feel like a very difficult question.
lead_paragraph: Stu Smith still remembers how brazen the ask was. He owned a branding company with 10 employees at the time and brought one into his office to have a difficult conversation. The person’s side projects, outside of his full-time work, had started to drag on his performance.

headline: A Cherished Family Home Gets a Second Act
abstract: Michael Newell wanted to buy and renovate the house he and his siblings grew up in, and give it another purpose. Wedding bells are ringing!
lead_paragraph: For many years, a thought often crept into Michael Newell’s mind: “What if I bought my childhood home?” He wanted to keep the cherished house, but give it another purpose. Sometimes he shared that thought with his then-girlfriend, Marché Robinson. But it never went further than that.

headline: ‘Based on a True Story’ (Except the Parts That Aren’t)
abstract: The entertainment genre of historical drama is flourishing — and riddled with inaccuracies. The untrue parts are leading to more public spats and lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: The following stories are not based on real events. In fact, they’re completely made up — even though they’re meant to seem real.

headline: Ecuador Tried to Curb Drilling and Protect the Amazon. The Opposite Happened.
abstract: A novel idea to leave the country’s vast oil reserves in the ground fizzled for lack of international support. Now, struggling under painful debt, the government wants to expand drilling in the rainforest.
lead_paragraph: YASUNÍ NATIONAL PARK, Ecuador — In a swath of lush Amazon rainforest here, near some of the last Indigenous people on Earth living in isolation, workers recently finished building a new oil platform carved out of the wilderness.

headline: John Cale’s Musical Journey Knows No Limits
abstract: At 80, the musician who helped found the Velvet Underground before a prolific run as a producer and solo artist is releasing a new LP and mentoring new generations of avant-garde creators.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: As Russians Steal Ukraine’s Art, They Attack Its Identity, Too
abstract: Russian forces have looted tens of thousands of pieces, including avant-garde oil paintings and Scythian gold. Experts say it is the biggest art heist since the Nazis in World War II, intended to strip Ukraine of its cultural heritage.
lead_paragraph: KHERSON, Ukraine — One morning in late October, Russian forces blocked off a street in downtown Kherson and surrounded a graceful old building with dozens of soldiers.

headline: The Dessert-First Author Whose Books Defined Canada’s Treats
abstract: Jean Paré, the prolific, self-published cookbook writer, died last month in Alberta. Her unfussy recipes found an audience with millions of Canadians.
lead_paragraph: From a small Alberta farming town where she worked as a caterer, Jean Paré began a new career path as a cookbook author at the age of 54. And when the male-dominated industry of the day refused to print her first cookbook, dismissing the recipes as too sweet, she founded her own publishing company.

headline: Cinema Studies
abstract: Awards season has begun. It’s time to cram.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always been an awards season crammer, racing to see all the big category films before the Oscars ceremony. I’ll stay up late to stream a best picture contender, squeeze in a matinee between meetings. While the spectacle of awards shows can be embarrassing, a cringe-making combo of self-congratulation and self-effacement, the hype always gets me in the end.

headline: Medicare Begins to Rein In Drug Costs for Older Americans
abstract: Reforms embedded in the Inflation Reduction Act will bring savings to seniors this year. Already some lawmakers are aiming to repeal the changes.
lead_paragraph: Steve Lubin spent a lot last year on insulin to control his Type 2 diabetes.

headline: Día 5: la importancia de tener amigos en la oficina
abstract: Quienes tienen hacen amistades en el trabajo están más comprometidos con sus labores, según un estudio. También son más propensos a innovar y compartir ideas.
lead_paragraph: Esta es la quinta entrega del Reto de la felicidad en siete días de la sección Well. Para empezar este reto puedes visitar el siguiente enlace.

headline: Another storm is soaking California. Here’s what to know.
abstract: The state’s northern and central regions have sustained the most damage during weeks of endless storms that have left at least 19 dead.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — A fresh wave of storms inundated California again on Saturday, swelling rivers, downing power lines and imperiling travelers during yet another holiday weekend as a procession of atmospheric rivers continued to wallop the state.

headline: Just How Common Is Corporate Fraud?
abstract: A new study estimates that on average 10 percent of public companies commit securities fraud each year.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: China Reports Nearly 60,000 Covid-Linked Deaths Since Lifting Restrictions
abstract: The unexpected disclosure was made as the country faces mounting criticism for providing unreliable data on its latest coronavirus outbreak.
lead_paragraph: China said on Saturday that it had recorded nearly 60,000 fatalities linked to the coronavirus in the month since the country lifted its strict “zero Covid” policy, accelerating an outbreak that is believed to have infected millions of people. The disclosure was the first time China has provided an official measure of the Covid wave now sweeping the country, and represents a huge spike in the official death toll.

headline: Who Are the Real Babies in First Class?
abstract: The complaints about infants on airplanes say something about our culture of entitlement.
lead_paragraph: When you’ve been covering a topic for a while, you see the same story lines pop up over and over. On the parenting beat, the dilemma of babies crying on airplanes is evergreen and always divisive. In a few cases, harried parents have been so concerned about being shamed for the mundane act of taking a baby on a plane that they’ve resorted to handing out goody bags in the hopes of preemptively mollifying fellow passengers.

headline: Harry’s Fractured Fairy Tale
abstract: A millennial Hamlet haunted by Mummy’s vengeful ghost.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I am, faith and begorrah, no monarchist.

headline: The Trouble With Paradise
abstract: My search for the sublime led me to the last place I expected to find it.
lead_paragraph: One day in my 20s, several decades ago, I got on a plane in New York City and flew across the world. It was dark when I arrived in Bali, but when I awoke the next day, a young man with a beautiful smile brought me fresh mango and strong tea to enjoy on the terrace of my bungalow. All around, playing amid bright flowers, were little girls with the faces of angels. Within hours, midwinter gloom had been transformed, as if by magic, into tropical sunshine. I was paying two dollars a night for a cottage of my own with a golden beach 45 seconds away, down a fragrant, palm-shaded lane.

headline: Why Do Documents Marked Secret Keep Showing Up in Strange Places?
abstract: America’s system for protecting classified documents has spun out of control.
lead_paragraph: There is much we still do not know about President Biden’s stash of secret documents, but one thing is painfully obvious: The system for protecting secrets vital to national security has spun out of control. The question is why.

headline: A Deal to Help South Africa Is a Breakthrough for the World
abstract: A plan to promote the shift to renewable energy could lead to real progress on climate change.
lead_paragraph: South Africa generates 80 percent of its electricity by burning coal, more than any other industrialized nation. Some 200,000 people are directly employed by the coal mines, coal transports and coal-fired power plants that dot the flatlands east of Johannesburg, but the prosperity of the rest of the nation also rests on a foundation of black rock.

headline: How to Help Girls Enduring the Unendurable
abstract: Some unfinished business from #MeToo: the global scourge of rape.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — She is impossibly young to have endured what she did, and what still haunts her is the job of the man responsible: a police officer.

headline: What to Know About Gas Stove Alternatives
abstract: Cooking with gas isn’t the only way. Electric and induction cooking can offer some distinct advantages, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Gas stoves, long beloved by cooks, have begun to seem like kitchen pariahs in recent weeks.

headline: Here’s the California Weather Forecast Through the Long Weekend
abstract: Widespread heavy rain and snowfall return to California as another atmospheric river soaks the state.
lead_paragraph: The latest in a series of atmospheric rivers carrying heavy rainfall from the Pacific Ocean began to shower California on Friday, with a more intense surge of moisture expected late Saturday morning and into the afternoon hours.

headline: An Issue in the Abortion Debate: The Beginning of Human Life
abstract: Readers weigh in on a fraught question that touches on biology, politics, religion and philosophy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Dangerous Decline of the Historical Profession
abstract: Is this actually the end of history?
lead_paragraph: When I received my Ph.D. in history in 2013, I didn’t expect that within a decade fights over history — and historiography, even if few people use that word — would become front-page news. But over the last few years that is precisely what has happened: Just look at the recent debates over America’s legacy of slavery, what can be taught in public schools about the nation’s founders and even the definition of what constitutes fascism. The interpretation of the American past has not in recent memory been as public or as contentious as it is now.

headline: The Saturday morning attack on Kyiv appeared to best the air-raid warning system.
abstract: There was an unusual feature to the Saturday morning attack on Kyiv: It appeared to best the air-raid warning system.
lead_paragraph: There was an unusual feature to the Saturday morning attack on Kyiv: It appeared to best the air-raid warning system.

headline: Getting Inside California’s Wild Weather, 8 Miles Over the Pacific
abstract: A Times reporter and photographer rode along with a team gathering data on the colossal atmospheric rivers that have drenched the state.
lead_paragraph: ABOARD A GULFSTREAM IV, over the Pacific — The winter storms pounding California this month have often come into being thousands of miles to the west, in the moist air above the Pacific.

headline: Documents Inquiry Puts Spotlight on Biden’s Frenetic Last Days as Vice President
abstract: The special counsel will have to reconstruct how a small number of classified documents made it to Mr. Biden’s home in Delaware and a private office in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Those last days were a blur of phone calls, meetings, farewell events and visits to Ukraine and Switzerland. As he wrapped up his tenure as vice president in January 2017, Joseph R. Biden Jr. was packing in as much as he could.

headline: Rescuers rush to save people buried in rubble of a building destroyed by a Russian missile.
abstract: A 15-year-old girl was among the 14 people killed. The search for survivors continues.
lead_paragraph: A Russian strike tore into a nine-story apartment building in the city of Dnipro in central Ukraine, local officials said, killing at least 14 people, including a 15-year-old girl. Scores were injured.

headline: Martin Luther King Jr.’s Other Dreams
abstract: In 1967, he delivered a powerful sermon about the struggle for global peace.
lead_paragraph: The way most Americans talk about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., more than 50 years after his assassination, you might think that he gave exactly one speech — on Aug. 28, 1963, in Washington — and spoke exclusively about racial harmony and his oft-mentioned dream of integration.

headline: The Monterey Peninsula braces for possible flooding.
abstract: Officials fear that rising waters could cut off highway access and turn the scenic enclave into an island.
lead_paragraph: Monterey County, the scenic coastal area about 100 miles south of San Francisco that includes Big Sur and the famed golf courses of Pebble Beach, is bracing for flooding that could cut off access to and from the Monterey Peninsula, essentially turning it into an island. The towns of Carmel, Monterey and Pacific Grove are also at risk of being isolated from the rest of the county, local officials said, should floodwaters on critical roadways rise too high.

headline: Additional Documents Found at Biden’s Wilmington Home, White House Says
abstract: The revelation came as the White House defended its public statements about the extent of the documents that remained in Mr. Biden’s possession.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Five more pages containing classified information were found at President Biden’s Delaware home on Thursday, the White House said on Saturday, bringing the tally to six such pages uncovered this week.

headline: Eric Adams Heads to Mexican Border, as the Migrant Crisis Continues
abstract: The New York City mayor said the arrival of tens of thousands of asylum seekers could cost as much as $2 billion, putting pressure on the city’s budget.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams is traveling from New York City to El Paso on Saturday to visit the border amid a crisis in which thousands of migrants from Latin America have been bused to the north.

headline: Tatjana Patitz, a Star in the Supermodel Era, Dies at 56
abstract: With a few others, she epitomized glamour in the late 1980s and early ’90s — on the runway, in magazines and even in a much-viewed music video.
lead_paragraph: Tatjana Patitz, one of the supermodels who were omnipresent on fashion runways, magazine covers and television commercials in the late 1980s and ’90s, died on Wednesday. She was 56.

headline: Santos, as ‘Anthony Devolder,’ Pushed Transgender Voters to G.O.P. in 2019
abstract: A year before George Santos first ran for Congress, he appeared at an L.G.B.T.Q. event using one of his alternate identities.
lead_paragraph: Months before beginning his first, and unsuccessful, bid for Congress, George Santos appeared at an event that urged members of the L.G.B.T.Q. community to leave the Democratic Party and embrace Republicans and Donald J. Trump, who was president at the time.

headline: Ex-NATO General and Ex-Prime Minister to Face Off in Czech Republic’s Presidential Race
abstract: Both candidates, Petr Pavel and Andrej Babis, are expected to foster closer ties to the West.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — In an election more important for what it ends than what it will bring, the Czech Republic completed the first round of voting for a new president on Saturday, starting the eclipse of an eccentric, hard-drinking incumbent who often put himself at odds with the Czech government and European allies by reaching out to Russia and China.

headline: Will There Be a Biden Comeback?
abstract: A number of events would have to go the president’s way, and even then age is an issue.
lead_paragraph: Something unusual happened to Joe Biden this week. A reputable poll, from The Economist and YouGov, showed him with a positive job approval rating — even hitting 50 percent approval among registered voters, against 47 percent disapproving.

headline: George Kittle of the San Francisco 49ers was one of many residents without power.
