lead_paragraph: Chris Ford, who played guard for the Boston Celtics when they won the 1981 N.B.A. championship and later coached the team along with two others in the N.B.A., but who was perhaps best remembered for making the first 3-point shot in the league’s history, died on Tuesday. He was 74.

headline: Tech Layoffs Shock Young Workers. The Older People? Not So Much.
abstract: The industry’s recent job cuts have been an awakening for a generation of workers who have never experienced a cyclical crash.
lead_paragraph: When Lyft laid off 13 percent of its workers in November, Kelly Chang was shocked to find herself among the 700 people who lost their jobs at the San Francisco company.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The late-night hosts had plenty of news to discuss this week, including the United States reaching its debt limit and more revelations about George Santos.
lead_paragraph: The late-night hosts had plenty of news to discuss this week, including the United States reaching its debt limit and more revelations about George Santos.

headline: Church of England Will Bless Same-Sex Couples, but Won’t Marry Them
abstract: The policy shift comes after six years of consultations on the issue within the church, which also apologized for its treatment of L.G.B.T.Q. people.
lead_paragraph: The Church of England apologized for its past treatment of L.G.B.T.Q. people on Friday, but said it would continue its practice of not allowing same-sex marriages in church, a reflection of a delicate balancing act that has once again highlighted stark divisions in the nearly 500-year-old institution.

headline: Wonking Out: Give Me That Gold Time Religion
abstract: Are traditional pet rocks making a comeback?
lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, recently had a few things to say about cryptocurrency. Bitcoin, he declared, is a “hyped-up fraud”; it’s a “pet rock.”

headline: Pesto With a Citrusy Twist
abstract: A zesty Sicilian take on the favorite, from Ali Slagle, is a perfect accompaniment to fish or pasta.
lead_paragraph: Citrus season has now arrived, a jewel-toned gift to those of us who live somewhere that’s currently gray. Like many people, I gravitate toward stews and braises this time of year, the genre of home cooking that can best be described as “something in warm sauce.”

headline: ‘Fleishman Is in Trouble’ and the Angst of the Striving Upper Class
abstract: At the heart of meritocracy is marriage.
lead_paragraph: Every so often, someone on Twitter recirculates a purported budget created by the website Financial Samurai a few years back for a family of four in New York City making $500,000 and supposedly “scraping by” because the cost of upper-class city living is so high. The responses to this document are always entertaining, running the gamut from “eat the rich” outrage to invocations of memorable satire to the careful debunking of the just-scraping-by claim. (It turns out the family is putting away a bit of money annually, via 401(k) and mortgage payments.)

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Nicole Hemmer
abstract: The Jan. 20, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Nicole Hemmer. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Winning a BAFTA? Just One of Joanna Scanlan’s Career Surprises.
abstract: Last year, the British actress won for “After Love,” a melodrama she led after years of comedic roles and only getting her first acting job at 34.
lead_paragraph: Joanna Scanlan had been a full-time acting teacher at a university for six years when she had a mental breakdown. She was 31. Her doctor blamed a lack of professional fulfillment for the collapse and warned her about the long-term consequences of hindered aspirations.

headline: March for Life Kicks Off in Washington, Setting the Stage for New Ideas
abstract: The annual anti-abortion gathering to protest Roe v. Wade is the first since the Supreme Court overturned the right to abortion.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Thousands of anti-abortion activists convened on the National Mall on Friday for the March for Life, the rally held every January since 1974 to protest Roe v. Wade.

headline: 12 Easy Pastas That Are Ready in 30 Minutes (Really!)
abstract: Start an episode of “Abbott Elementary” while you cook, and dinner will be on the table by the time the credits roll.
lead_paragraph: Cozy but quick, these speedy pasta recipes are made with affordable ingredients you probably either have on hand or can easily procure with a quick trip to the grocery store. For convenience’s sake, they also all call for a full pound of pasta, but most can be easily halved.

headline: Review: Carnegie Hall Makes an Intimate Space More Intimate
abstract: Zankel Hall has been temporarily reconfigured so that audiences can sit in the round, beginning with an enjoyable performance by the group yMusic.
lead_paragraph: New York’s classical music powerhouses would like to get closer to you.

headline: N.Y.U. Langone Withdraws From Type 1 Diabetes Vaccine Trial in Adolescents
abstract: The B.C.G. vaccine, more than a century old, has shown some promise against diabetes. The university’s move left parents and outside investigators concerned.
lead_paragraph: Researchers at N.Y.U. Langone Health have pulled out of a trial investigating the use of an old tuberculosis vaccine to treat children with Type 1 diabetes only months after they began enrolling participants on Long Island.

headline: Elon Musk Said Davos Isn’t Fun. Well, Is It?
abstract: A not-so-scientific poll of attendees at the Super Bowl of global capitalism.
lead_paragraph: The concept of fun is weirdly hard to define, like love or obscenity. You kind of know it when you’re having it, and you definitely know when you’re not.

headline: Giants Defense Thrives on Blunt Feedback. And Sneaker Talk.
abstract: Don “Wink” Martindale’s frank honesty and aggressive play calling have turned around the Giants’ defense. Players say their bond with the assistant coach has helped, too.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In one of his first meetings with Giants players as their new defensive coordinator, Don “Wink” Martindale addressed each of them individually, in front of their teammates, and curtly told them what they needed to improve on.

headline: It Takes a (Book) Village
abstract: Book lovers and entrepreneurs have built a community centered on literature in upstate New York.
lead_paragraph: Eight independent bookstores line a two-block stretch of Main Street in the upstate New York village of Hobart, which has a population of roughly 400. Nestled in the northern Catskills a three-hour drive from Manhattan, Hobart became Hobart Book Village in 2005.

headline: Top Law Firm Advising FTX on Bankruptcy Can Keep Its Job, Judge Says
abstract: Sullivan & Cromwell was under attack for a potential conflict of interest tied to its work for the crypto exchange before the bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: Sullivan & Cromwell, the prestigious law firm handling the bankruptcy of FTX, found itself scrambling this week to fully disclose its previous legal work for the collapsed cryptocurrency exchange, as critics accused it of a conflict of interest.

headline: ‘The Immortal Jellyfish Girl’ Review: A 26th-Century Love Story
abstract: Featuring a lobster telephone and a robot boy with wings, this puppet romance set in a future post-ecological collapse succeeds on its own weird terms.
lead_paragraph: The first time Bug and Aurelia kiss is as romantic as can be, even if Bug has to get past his initial reaction. “That really hurts,” he says. “That stings so much!” Which is what you get when smooching a part-jellyfish humanoid.

headline: Gerrie Coetzee, 67, Afrikaner Boxing Champ Who Fought Apartheid, Dies
abstract: He won the World Boxing Association title in 1983, became a symbol of racial comity and showed a surprising gentleness in public.
lead_paragraph: Gerrie Coetzee, a South African heavyweight boxing champion who rejected the epithet “great white hope” and criticized apartheid, earning the respect of Nelson Mandela, died on Jan. 12 at his home in Bloubergstrand, a suburb of Cape Town. He was 67.

headline: The U.S. will name the Wagner mercenary group a transnational criminal organization.
abstract: The move, which goes into effect next week, expands the number of nations and institutions that can be prevented from doing business with Wagner.
lead_paragraph: The United States has decided to designate the Russian private military group Wagner as a significant transnational criminal organization, the White House said on Friday, a move that will expand the number of nations and institutions that can be prevented from doing business with the company.

headline: What America Should Do About Its Ballooning Debt
abstract: Congress should be talking about reducing spending, raising taxes and accelerating growth.
lead_paragraph: A lot of the news coverage of hitting the federal debt ceiling has been political: The motion to vacate! The discharge petition! The trillion-dollar platinum coin workaround!

headline: Ringleader of Sex Cult at Sarah Lawrence College Gets 60-Year Sentence
abstract: Lawrence Ray was convicted of extortion, sex trafficking, racketeering conspiracy and other charges.
lead_paragraph: When Lawrence V. Ray arrived on the campus of Sarah Lawrence College in 2010, he presented himself as a mentor to the young men and women who lived in a ‌dormitory there with his daughter.

headline: In ‘M3gan,’ a Detective’s Guilty Laugh Speaks Volumes About Him (and Us)
abstract: What’s so funny about his inappropriate response to a boy’s injury? The director pushed to keep the bizarre moment in the film, for good reason.
lead_paragraph: The strangest moment in “M3gan,” the hit horror-comedy about an android gone awry, is not a flamboyant robotic glance or an elaborately staged kill, but a guilty chuckle.

headline: Chet Holmgren Seeks a Silver Lining in a Lost Rookie Season
abstract: “I could let this be a blessing or a curse, you know?” Holmgren said. “So I got to figure out how to turn it into a blessing, how to make the most out of it.”
lead_paragraph: Chet Holmgren didn’t feel like he’d arrived in the N.B.A. after the Oklahoma City Thunder selected him with the No. 2 overall pick in the 2022 draft. And he didn’t feel like he’d arrived after starring in the Summer League, setting a record with six blocks in his debut. So in the late summer, instead of returning home to spend a few months with friends and family in Minneapolis or moving into his new home in Oklahoma City, Holmgren returned to Los Angeles, where he had trained before the draft.

headline: Two Teenagers Are Shot in the Bronx, One Fatally
abstract: The boys, 15 and 16, were leaving a youth organization in the Longwood neighborhood when the younger one was shot in the head and later pronounced dead.
lead_paragraph: Two teenage boys were shot in the Bronx on Thursday night, one fatally, the police said.

headline: Anti-Abortion Activists Gather for March for Life
abstract: Thousands of activists convened in Washington, for the first major anti-abortion gathering since the Supreme Court overturned the constitutional right to abortion last summer.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of activists convened in Washington, for the first major anti-abortion gathering since the Supreme Court overturned the constitutional right to abortion last summer.

headline: Did the Supreme Court’s Leak Investigation Let the Justices Off the Hook?
abstract: What may result from the report is increased suspicion of the justices themselves.
lead_paragraph: Update: This article has been updated to reflect a statement on Friday from the Supreme Court.

headline: David Crosby, a King of Twitter
abstract: The musician relished sharing opinions big and small, sparring with fans and dispelling myths, often in sharp, hilarious quips. The vibe on the platform changed, but he posted until the end.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, one day before the world learned of his death at 81, the musician David Crosby posted to Twitter over a dozen times.

headline: Three Montana Grizzly Bears Euthanized Last Fall Tested Positive for Avian Flu
abstract: The bears are believed to have contracted the virus from diseased birds, amid what a U.S.D.A. spokesman called the “largest foreign animal disease outbreak in U.S. history.”
lead_paragraph: Three young grizzly bears in Montana that were euthanized last fall later tested positive for the highly contagious avian influenza, the state’s Fish, Wildlife and Parks service announced this week, fueling fears that the virus that has killed millions of poultry in the last year is rapidly spreading to other animal groups.

headline: Vice, a Beleaguered Avatar of New Media, Hangs a ‘For Sale’ Sign
abstract: Vice, which has struggled to achieve profitability in recent years, has formed a special committee to find suitors.
lead_paragraph: After Vice Media secured a new round of financing in 2017 that valued the company at $5.7 billion, Shane Smith, one of its founders, teased the potential for “hockey stick” growth and a “sexy” stock market debut.

headline: What to Know About PFAS in Period Underwear
abstract: Thinx just settled a lawsuit alleging its products contain harmful chemical compounds, raising further questions about the safety of period products overall.
lead_paragraph: This week, the period underwear brand Thinx made public that it had reached a settlement in a 3-year-long class action lawsuit claiming its products contain harmful chemicals. The news of the settlement brought renewed focus on the chemical compounds at the center of the lawsuit — per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances, known as PFAS or “forever chemicals” — and highlighted the broader issue of toxic ingredients in period products as a whole.

headline: A Cold-Weather N.F.L. Warning: Don’t Get Burned Staying Warm
abstract: When the temperature drops at football games, out come the big jackets and the hand warmers. Sometimes, things can get too hot too fast.
lead_paragraph: As the divisional round of the N.F.L. playoffs begins on Saturday, the teams with the highly coveted home-field advantage will enjoy all the typical luxuries of playing at home, including sleeping in their own beds and the promise of loud fans cheering for them. The teams that play in colder climates — including Kansas City, Philadelphia and Buffalo — have another advantage: knowing not to stand near the sideline heaters for too long.

headline: A Farewell to Maya Moore, a Team Player Who Is Also One of a Kind
abstract: Moore, who has officially retired from the W.N.B.A., will be remembered for her brilliance on the court and her fight for justice away from it.
lead_paragraph: One of my clearest memories of Maya Moore has nothing to do with basketball, and nothing to do with her fight for justice.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: Twenty-seven New Yorkers shared how much they make. Also in this edition: dancing with the stairs, and truffle wars in Italy.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-seven New Yorkers shared how much they make. Also in this edition: dancing with the stairs, and truffle wars in Italy.

headline: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: The intelligence may be artificial, but the thrills are real in this month’s collection of sci-fi picks.
lead_paragraph: If ethical and emotional issues pertaining to artificial intelligence are your jam, this Netflix original is a must-see. And if you just want badass action with robots, brawls, devious scientists and grand futuristic landscapes, it’ll do the job, too. The South Korean director Yeon Sang-ho burst on the international scene in 2016 with the insta-classic zombie actioner “Train to Busan,” then he delivered more undead with the sprawling “Peninsula” (2020). Now Yeon is back with “Jung_E,” which considers A.I. with a degree of emotional sensitivity rare in a film that also deploys virtuosic whiz-bang fights.

headline: Despite Red Flags, G.O.P. Backed Candidate Now Charged in Shootings
abstract: “We could have picked apart this guy,” one Republican leader in New Mexico said of Solomon Peña, who is accused of organizing attacks on the homes of four Democratic officials.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — The former Republican candidate accused of targeting the homes of Democrats in drive-by shootings had routinely called for locking up 2020 election officials in Guantánamo Bay. He promoted conspiracy theories about solar power, feminism and “the demonic theories of the Globalist Elites.” He had been demoted twice by the U.S. Navy and served nearly seven years in prison for burglary.

headline: The Many Lessons of Kouign-Amann
abstract: I made this Breton-style cake at least half a dozen times to perfect it. Here’s what it taught me about grief.
lead_paragraph: On Avenue du Mont-Royal Est in the heart of Montreal’s Plateau neighborhood is a patisserie called Au Kouign-Amann, specializing in a classic version of the pastry that gives it the name.

headline: Supreme Court’s Inquiry Into Leak Included Interviews With Justices
abstract: But the justices were not asked to sign sworn affidavits, unlike law clerks and other employees, the court’s marshal said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s internal investigation into who leaked a draft of the opinion last year overturning the landmark decision that had established a constitutional right to abortion included talking to all nine justices, the marshal of the court said on Friday.

headline: All Night Long: Why Some Tennis Matches Never Seem to End
abstract: Andy Murray’s second-round match at the Australian Open didn’t end until after 4 a.m. As matches more often go into the early morning hours, some players say it is harming their physical and mental health.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — It was 4 o’clock on Friday morning at the Australian Open, and Andy Murray and Thanasi Kokkinakis were still playing tennis.

headline: Easing the Burden of Pregnancy for Black Women
abstract: Doulas provide nonmedical support during and after pregnancy — a benefit associated with affluent white women.  I recently reported on a nonprofit providing doulas and other services. Here’s how the group is aiding Black women in St. Louis.
lead_paragraph: Doulas provide nonmedical support during and after pregnancy — a benefit associated with affluent white women.  I recently reported on a nonprofit providing doulas and other services. Here’s how the group is aiding Black women in St. Louis.

headline: Man Charged in Death of Another at Manhattan Subway Station, Police Say
abstract: A  28-year-old man was charged with manslaughter after a second man fell to the subway tracks during an early-morning altercation, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A 28-year-old man was charged with manslaughter on Friday after an altercation with another man who fell onto the tracks at a Manhattan subway station and died, the police said.

headline: U.S. to Name Wagner Group a Transnational Criminal Organization
abstract: The move would freeze the company’s assets in the United States and ban Americans from providing money, goods or services to the Russian private military group.
lead_paragraph: The move would freeze the company’s assets in the United States and ban Americans from providing money, goods or services to the Russian private military group.

headline: Rishi Sunak Is Fined for Not Wearing a Seatbelt
abstract: The police in Lancashire, in northwest England, levied the fine after the British prime minister posted a video on Instagram that showed him riding in a car, unbuckled.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain acknowledged on Friday that he had been fined by the police for not wearing a seatbelt after he posted an Instagram video of himself riding in a car without one.

headline: Which Leaders Resign, Like Jacinda Ardern? Often, the System Decides.
abstract: In parliamentary systems like New Zealand’s, it is the norm for leaders to step down when doing so may serve their party’s electoral prospects. In other political systems, leaving office early is rare.
lead_paragraph: When Jacinda Ardern announced this week that she would step down as New Zealand’s prime minister, her decision caught the world by surprise. She called leading a country “the most privileged job anyone could ever have,” but said she would leave office by February.

headline: Dick Polich, Artists’ Ally in the Creation of Sculptures, Dies at 90
abstract: His cavernous Hudson Valley foundry helped Louise Bourgeois, Richard Serra, Jeff Koons and many others turn their large-scale visions into reality.
lead_paragraph: If you have ever spent time around one of the artist Louise Bourgeois’s 30-foot spiders, or glimpsed one of Tom Otterness’s roundish bronze dwarves that populate the subway station at 14th Street and Eighth Avenue in Manhattan, it might have occurred to you to wonder: Where do they come from?

headline: The Push for Tanks Falls Short
abstract: Germany has been reluctant to send its Leopards.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Elon Musk Says His Social Media Posts Did Not Drive Tesla’s Stock Price
abstract: The chief executive of Tesla testified in a federal civil trial about a 2018 plan to take the automaker private that fizzled out.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk testified on Friday that he was aware that he posted important information on his Twitter account about Tesla, the electric car company he runs. But he denied that his social media posts were responsible for swings in Tesla’s share price.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Allies Fail to Agree on Sending Tanks to Ukraine
abstract: Officials tried to play down the rift. But Germany is still insisting it will not be the country to take the first step alone, for fear of incurring Moscow’s wrath.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Western defense officials meeting in Germany said on Friday that they had failed to reach an agreement for sending battle tanks to Ukraine, in a setback to Kyiv’s hopes to quickly receive weapons that President Volodymyr Zelensky has called crucial to the next phase of the war.

headline: Chris Hipkins Poised to Replace Jacinda Ardern as New Zealand’s Leader
abstract: Mr. Hipkins, a household name in New Zealand for his role overseeing the country’s response to the pandemic, was nominated to succeed Jacinda Ardern as leader of the governing Labour Party.
lead_paragraph: Chris Hipkins, who has been serving as New Zealand’s education and policing minister, is set to become the country’s new prime minister next month after he was the only member of the governing Labour Party to be nominated for the party leadership post.

headline: Betty Lee Sung, Pioneering Scholar of Chinese in America, Dies at 98
abstract: U.S.-born, she lived for a time in China and then fled as Japan invaded. She later broke academic ground in New York in the study of the Asian American diaspora.
lead_paragraph: Betty Lee Sung, an American-born daughter of Chinese immigrants who was taken back to China by her parents during the Depression, escaped the invading Japanese as a teenager and then made her way back to the United States, where she pioneered research into the Asian diaspora, died on Thursday at her home in Silver Spring, Md. She was 98.

headline: A Navy SEAL who deserted in 2019 has been killed in Ukraine.
abstract: The man, Daniel W. Swift, was the latest American to be killed in Ukraine, where hundreds of international volunteers have gone to fight in Ukraine’s defense.
lead_paragraph: A former U.S. Navy SEAL who deserted in 2019 was killed in Ukraine this week, the Navy said in a brief statement on Friday.

headline: Have a Response to the Ethicist Column?
abstract: Share your thoughts with us about the most recent ethical quandary.
lead_paragraph: Did you agree with what the Ethicist had to say in his most recent column? Did you disagree? Do you have an insight about some aspect of the dilemma posed in the letter, or have something you would say to the letter writer yourself?

headline: Lights, Camera, Weapons Check? Actors Worry After Baldwin Charges.
abstract: The manslaughter charges Alec Baldwin faces after a fatal on-set shooting revived questions about who’s responsible for gun safety on film productions. “We are not actual cowboys,” an actor noted.
lead_paragraph: The news that Alec Baldwin is facing manslaughter charges for killing a cinematographer with a gun he had been told was safe had the actor Steven Pasquale thinking back to the filming of “Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem” more than a decade ago, when he and other actors were handed military-style rifles and told to start shooting.

headline: Dozens of Women and Girls Kidnapped by Extremists Are Freed in Burkina Faso
abstract: More than 60 people were abducted a week ago while searching for food in an area blockaded by insurgents. On Friday, the military said the captives had been released.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — More than 60 women and girls who had been abducted last week in the West African nation of Burkina Faso were freed on Friday, the national broadcaster said.

headline: Guatemala Targets Colombia’s Defense Minister in Crackdown on Anticorruption Forces
abstract: The defense minister had led an anticorruption task force in Guatemala for several years. The authorities also announced arrest warrants against former investigators for the group.
lead_paragraph: As the Guatemalan authorities intensify a methodical, yearslong crackdown on officials who were tasked with rooting out government corruption in the country, the government announced this week that it was investigating Colombia’s defense minister, who had led a United Nations-backed anticorruption body that was active in Guatemala until 2019.

headline: Illinois Passed a Sweeping Ban on High-Powered Guns. Now Come the Lawsuits.
abstract: Democrats say the new law, the most extensive firearm ban in the Midwest, will save lives, but gun rights supporters claim it is unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When Illinois legislators passed a far-reaching ban last week on selling certain high-powered guns and high-capacity magazines, the Democrats who run the state celebrated it as a lifesaving law that would help prevent mass violence. But on Friday, in the law’s first judicial test, a state judge in Effingham County temporarily blocked it from being enforced against hundreds of people and several gun dealers who sued.

headline: Police, Paramedics Accused in Elijah McClain Killing Plead Not Guilty
abstract: The 23-year-old Black man died three years ago after being placed in a chokehold and injected with a powerful sedative. The defendants will be tried in three separate trials.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The five police officers and paramedics accused of killing Elijah McClain, a young Black man who had been walking home when he was stopped by the police in Aurora, Colo., were formally arraigned in a Colorado district court on Friday, more than three years after his death.

headline: The NATO Alliance Is Holding Strong on Ukraine. But Fractures Are Emerging.
abstract: The allies differ on strategy for the coming year and the more immediate question of what Ukraine needs ahead of a major offensive in the spring.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The billions of dollars in new arms for Ukraine announced this month — including British tanks, American fighting vehicles and howitzers from Denmark and Sweden — are testament to President Vladimir V. Putin’s failure to split the NATO allies after nearly a year of war. But small yet significant fractures are getting too big to hide.

headline: Witness Says Inside Information Helped Fox Win World Cup Rights
abstract: A marketing executive testified that a top FIFA official provided secret bidding information that allowed his company to acquire valuable television rights.
lead_paragraph: When the news broke a dozen years ago that Fox had been awarded the U.S. broadcast rights for the 2018 and 2022 World Cups, many in television, and in soccer, were surprised. For decades, the sport’s showcase championship was the exclusive domain of ESPN, which had been instrumental in driving interest in the world’s most popular game in the world’s richest sports market.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 21, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 21, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An Inside The Times article on Friday about the hands of N.F.L. players misspelled the surname of a photographer. She is Chona Kasinger, not Chasinger.

headline: Top-Notch
abstract: David Distenfeld offers up a mental workout in his Saturday grid.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is David Distenfeld’s fifth construction for The New York Times since his first in 2021; all have been themeless. If you’re on the right wavelength, the one where you can recite scenes from “Pulp Fiction” by heart, you might fly through this one. If you spend more time with books than screens, you will probably have a tougher time. Either way, it’s a fun ride, with eight substantial debuts and some spots to stop for a good chuckle.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Facing Warring Gangs, a Desperate Mother Turns to a Bold Nun
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 21, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “When the boys in the gang tell them they love them, they run for their lives.”

headline: 5 Memphis Officers Fired Over Traffic Stop That Turned Deadly
abstract: Tyre Nichols was stopped for reckless driving in early January. He was hospitalized in critical condition after the arrest and died days later.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Five Memphis police officers were fired on Friday after the department found that they had used excessive force and failed to intervene or provide help during a traffic stop this month involving a 29-year-old Black man who died in a hospital three days later, officials said.

headline: Justice Department Investigating Troubled Infant Formula Plant
abstract: Abbott shut down production at the plant last year amid “shocking” sanitation lapses, touching off a disruptive infant supply formula shortage.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Department of Justice has opened an investigation into operations at the Abbott Nutrition infant formula plant in Michigan that shut down over sanitation problems early last year, causing a lengthy and widespread infant formula shortage.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Safe at Home in Dnipro, Until a Russian Missile Struck
abstract: Despite the ever-present danger of war, life in Ukraine proceeds almost normally at times. Then, suddenly, it all changes, as it did in Dnipro last weekend after a missile struck an apartment complex.
lead_paragraph: DNIPRO, Ukraine — A Russian missile as long as a city bus was nearing the end of a roughly 300-mile flight, its 2,000-pound warhead armed to detonate on impact.

headline: Is This Cooking Oil Actually Healthy?
abstract: Canola or olive? Coconut or avocado? Cooking oil comes in so many varieties, it can be difficult to figure out the best options for our health. Here’s what to know about this stovetop staple.
lead_paragraph: Canola or olive? Coconut or avocado? Cooking oil comes in so many varieties, it can be difficult to figure out the best options for our health. Here’s what to know about this stovetop staple.

headline: Most Abortion Bans Include Exceptions. In Practice, Few Are Granted.
abstract: Rape victims and patients with complicated pregnancies are confronting the limits of state abortion laws.
lead_paragraph: Rape victims and patients with complicated pregnancies are confronting the limits of state abortion laws.

headline: Aleksandar Hemon Sets a Gay Love Story Amid the Great War
abstract: In the postmodernist novel “The World and All That It Holds,” a Sephardi pharmacist falls in love with a Bosnian soldier as war breaks out in Sarajevo and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Love is not the engine of history, but it certainly makes for an indispensable source of auxiliary power in the historical novel. It’s there in “War and Peace,” more pronounced in “Doctor Zhivago” (further emphasized in David Lean’s film), and foregrounded in Charles Frazier’s “Cold Mountain,” where the travails of a pair of lovers serve to sweeten the pill of Civil War cruelty and treachery, though the aftertaste is bitter. The difference in Aleksandar Hemon’s “The World and All That It Holds” is that the lovers, Pinto and Osman, are both male, and the world convulsion that engulfs and separates them also brought them together in the first place. In this novel idyll and ordeal are not stable categories, but slide past each other.

headline: Luka Doncic Is Scoring More and Playing When He Doesn’t Have To
abstract: Even in pickup games, Doncic is showing a leap compared with last season, which ended with a disappointing exit in the Western Conference finals.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jared Dudley, an assistant coach for the Dallas Mavericks, put together a pickup game earlier this month when his team had an official day off.

headline: Closing the Book on Promises to Myself
abstract: This year’s resolution: No more worrying about all the volumes I know I’ll never read.
lead_paragraph: When Grandpa Moe died, it took months and several rented skips to clear out the piles of rotted paper and the millions of printed words left behind. About a thousand books were salvageable. A guy my grandfather had met somewhere came and picked these up, and made them into “Moe’s Bookmobile” — a sort of performance-art-piece-cum-public-service that was, we all felt, very much in Moe’s spirit.

headline: Layoffs at Tech Giants Reverse Small Part of Pandemic Hiring Spree
abstract: Some of the biggest tech companies have announced tens of thousands of job cuts. But even after the layoffs, their work forces are still behemoths.
lead_paragraph: For a stretch of the pandemic, tech companies couldn’t hire fast enough. Talent wars broke out in Silicon Valley, with firms vying for software engineers, often lavishing extravagant perks on their new and would-be hires. As profits soared, executives acted as if the party would never end.

headline: Their Children Are Their Retirement Plans
abstract: The offspring of many East Asian immigrants are raised to support their elders in their later years. That gives a segment of Americans challenges others don’t face.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, I texted my mother to let her know that I had paid her electric bill (as I do every month), and that it was $461 — significantly higher than usual. She texted back to explain that Southern California, where she and my father live, was going through a heat wave but she would be mindful, knowing that I was covering the cost.

headline: How a Group of Brooklyn Beatboxers Became Ambassadors to the World
abstract: The trip will mark the first time that the government officially recognizes the genre in its American Music Abroad program.
lead_paragraph: Members of the Beatbox House, a group of five vocal percussive artists from Brooklyn, will follow in the footsteps of American music legends Dizzy Gillespie and Louis Armstrong when they travel abroad later this month to serve as cultural ambassadors for the United States.

headline: No One Is Coming for Your Gas Stove Anytime Soon
abstract: Switching from gas to electric stoves is seen as good for the environment — which has inspired a conservative backlash. But New York City’s prewar buildings make upgrading to nobler electric appliances challenging.
lead_paragraph: The culinary revolution that swept through the country in the 1970s and ’80s created a new lot of status signifiers that extended from pâte and warm goat cheese salad — early entries on the menu at Chez Panisse in Berkeley — to industrial-grade kitchen appliances meant to signal that one’s interest in cooking was not provisional. Early adopters of the new orthodoxies bought bulky, high-powered Wolf ranges, crafted in stainless steel, from restaurant suppliers, until the company, recognizing an evolving luxury market, introduced a residential version that would go on to spend the next decades as shorthand for a moneyed cosmopolitan domesticity.

headline: How Charlie Javice Got JPMorgan to Pay $175 Million for … What Exactly?
abstract: A young founder promised to simplify the college financial aid process. It was a compelling pitch. Especially, as now seems likely, to those with little firsthand knowledge of financial aid.
lead_paragraph: When JPMorgan Chase paid $175 million to acquire a college financial planning company called Frank in September 2021, it heralded the “unique opportunity for deeper engagement” with the five million students Frank worked with at more than 6,000 American institutions of higher education.

headline: A Hit French Novel Tries to Explain Putin. Too Well, Some Critics Say.
abstract: A popular novel, “The Wizard of the Kremlin,” presents a sympathetic portrait of the Russian leader, critics say, raising concerns that it might influence national policy toward the Ukraine war.
lead_paragraph: There are “two things that Russians require from the state: internal order and external power.”

headline: Inside the Battle to Control, and Fix, Tennis
abstract: The sport’s hit Netflix series and rising collection of young stars has investors bullish on tennis, which is poised for a once-in-a-generation moment of disruption.
lead_paragraph: Walking the grounds of Melbourne Park, where the Australian Open is in full swing, one could easily believe that all is well and peaceful in professional tennis.

headline: How a Cookie Entrepreneur Spends Her Sundays
abstract: “I wish I could put being sober on a résumé because it’s my biggest achievement,” said Janie Deegan, who credits baking with helping her get there.
lead_paragraph: Janie Deegan said she was 25 and homeless when she got sober. Soon after, she discovered baking.

headline: One of the Most Influential Ambassadors in Washington Isn’t One
abstract: Taiwan’s representative, Bi-khim Hsiao, calls herself a “cat warrior” walking a delicate diplomatic line. China calls her a troublemaker who could trigger a war.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — She is among the most influential foreign ambassadors in Washington, but she’s technically not an ambassador. She works from a grand estate, but cannot live there. Simply flying her flag could cause a diplomatic incident.

headline: Redefining the ‘New’ in Lunar New Year
abstract: Some younger Asian Americans are creating their own holiday traditions, putting a spin on lessons they’ve learned.
lead_paragraph: Hands jostled around a large metal basin, plastic gloves crinkling as they massaged pounds of julienned radish, green onion and a spicy, fragrant paste of red pepper flakes, brined shrimp, ginger and garlic.

headline: In Omaha, a Streetcar Named Undesirable by Warren Buffett
abstract: America is in the middle of a streetcar boom. The billionaire would prefer that his hometown not get onboard.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — The letter to the editor of The Omaha World-Herald began politely, Midwesternly.

headline: Clothes for People Who Love Books
abstract: Rachel Comey’s collaboration with The New York Review of Books is the latest flirtation between the fashion and literary worlds.
lead_paragraph: Inside the packed Rachel Comey store on Crosby Street in SoHo on Thursday, the readings began about halfway through the evening. When the crowd applauded for the memoirist Vivian Gornick, who read from her book “Unfinished Business: Notes of a Chronic Re-Reader,” she made an observation about her somewhat unfamiliar audience: “So it’s not just clothes, it’s also books that turn you on.”

headline: Pushing Alcohol While Health Experts Say Risk-Free Drinking Is a Myth
abstract: New alcohol guidelines say that not drinking is the only way to cut risk, but government-owned stores aggressively promote liquor, beer and wine.
lead_paragraph: This week brought the release of drinking guidelines for Canadians that are a distinct break from past ones.

headline: Rian Johnson’s New Old Show
abstract: “Poker Face” debuts next week. Could the throwback, case-of-the-week format be a cure for streaming woes?
lead_paragraph: Before appointment viewing and must-see TV, before binge-watching and spoiler alerts, there were, in my early television memories, channels 3, 8 and 30. There were the helicopter propellers of “M*A*S*H” and the “Murder, She Wrote” typewriter, the “CHiPs” engines revving and Laverne and Shirley counting off: after-dinner cues that announced what we’d be watching that night.

headline: Pakistan Strengthens Already Harsh Laws Against Blasphemy
abstract: Insulting Islam or its founder is already a capital offense, but now those who insult people connected to the Prophet Muhammad could get prison time.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s blasphemy laws, which can already mean death for those deemed to have insulted Islam or the Prophet Muhammad, can now also be used to punish anyone convicted of insulting people who were connected to him.

headline: Who wants to live forever?
abstract: Countries and companies are facing an aging crisis, and experts say policymakers and business leaders need to rethink how they deal with older workers.
lead_paragraph: Today’s 5-year-olds have it even better than you think.

headline: Amid Mounting Frustration With Germany, Ukraine Holds Out Hope It Will Get Tanks
abstract: While Germany has not yet made a decision on whether to send Leopard 2s to Ukraine, a Kyiv official said his country’s soldiers would begin training on them.
lead_paragraph: Pressure grew on Germany on Saturday to authorize the transfer of Leopard 2 battle tanks to Ukraine, even as Ukrainian officials signaled that they believed it would be only a matter of time before the German-made tanks arrived.

headline: London Museum Removes ‘Irish Giant’ Skeleton From Display
abstract: The remains of Charles Byrne, a 7-foot-7 man who died in 1783, will no longer be on public view, an effort to address what one official at the Hunterian Museum called a historical wrong.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Charles Byrne never wanted to end up in a museum.

headline: It’s Time to Stop Asking if Women Can Have it All. We Can.
abstract: Jacinda Ardern, New Zealand’s prime minister, shreds a tired trope about working moms.
lead_paragraph: Jacinda Ardern, the 42-year-old prime minister of New Zealand, announced this week that she would step down by Feb. 7. Ardern, who is also the mother of a 4-year-old girl, said that after more than five years in office, she didn’t have the energy to continue in the role. “I know what this job takes,” she said, “and I know that I no longer have enough in the tank to do it justice. It is that simple” — cueing up a fresh round of discussion about whether women can really “have it all.”

headline: What Drunken Driving Taught Me
abstract: When the officers handcuffed me, my indignation knew no bounds, but things look different now.
lead_paragraph: I hadn’t been to a gay bar in ages. Between Covid and addictive “dating” apps for cruising inappropriately unavailable men, it seemed an almost quaint idea. But on the evening of New Year’s Day, the first Saturday in 2022 — which could have been the start of a much-needed dry January — San Diego didn’t have much else to offer a bored, divorced, nearly senior tourist from New York. So I drove my rental convertible to one unsatisfying bar and then to another more interesting one, a small leather dive called the San Diego Eagle.

headline: A Brutal New Phase of Putin’s Terrible War in Ukraine
abstract: The job at hand is to persuade Russia that a negotiated peace is the only option.
lead_paragraph: The war in Ukraine has entered a new, more deadly and fateful phase, and the one man who can stop it, Vladimir Putin, has shown no signs that he will do so.

headline: What We Know About How to Save Kids’ Lives
abstract: Somalia faces a catastrophic famine, but we can avert mass death if we act now.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Hunger and loss make up a kaleidoscope in Somalia, but one scene stands out in my visit: A mom, Fardosa Ahmed, confides shyly that she had eight children but lost four of them, and now she fears she may lose a fifth, her daughter Catiko, who is sick, weak and motionless.

headline: Nancy Pelosi, Liberated and Loving It
abstract: Madam Speaker is thrilled about what comes next: her grandkids and influence without the headaches of power.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It’s not a pretty sight when pols lose power. They wilt, they crumple, they cling to the vestiges, they mourn their vanished entourage and perks. How can their day in the sun be over? One minute they’re running the world and the next, they’re in the room where it doesn’t happen.

headline: Nathan Lane’s New Play Is Photography Brought Alive
abstract: Larry Sultan’s iconic photo book “Pictures from Home” is being staged on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: In 1982, on a visit to his parents in Los Angeles, the photographer Larry Sultan came across home movies of his childhood, among them those that show the aftermath of his family’s move west from Brooklyn, the city of his birth, to a land of lawns and beaches and road trips and new cars in perpetual 1950s Southern California sunshine.

headline: Fed Up With Today’s G.O.P.
abstract: Readers discuss how Bret Stephens and David Brooks feel estranged from the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What A. Philip Randolph Knew About Jobs and Freedom
abstract: Early in the civil rights movement, he was a fierce proponent of economic justice.
lead_paragraph: I keep a running list of ideas and observations that could be used for columns or essays, and this week, my original plan was to write about A. Philip Randolph, the labor leader and civil rights activist whose work in the 1930s, ’40s and ’50s was crucial to the growth and success of the civil rights movement. He had a starring role at the 1963 March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, which itself was the culmination of an effort Randolph had begun in 1941 with his fellow activist Bayard Rustin and other allies in the civil rights and labor movements.

headline: The Last Days of Hollywood’s Most Reviled Reporter
abstract: Was Nikki Finke a genius or a monster? Friends and colleagues try to make sense of the entertainment industry’s brashest chronicler.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of her life, Nikki Finke, the journalist who struck fear into the hearts of Hollywood power players, believed she was onto one last story.

headline: At Davos, European Distress Over a ‘Made in America’ Law
abstract: The U.S. Inflation Reduction Act stirred talk of a trade war, but also proposals for a similar E.U. initiative to stimulate green investment.
lead_paragraph: A cautious optimism ran among the Europeans gathered high up in the Swiss Alps for the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum this past week. There were hopes that the region might cast off the gloomiest economic forecasts and avoid a recession this winter, helped by lower natural gas prices.

headline: Inside the Supreme Court Inquiry: Seized Phones, Affidavits and Distrust
abstract: An investigation of the abortion opinion leak was meant to right the institution amid a slide in public confidence. Instead, employees say, it deepened suspicions and caused disillusionment.
lead_paragraph: Last spring and summer, employees of the Supreme Court were drawn into an investigation that turned into an uncomfortable awakening.

headline: Limping and Creaking, Djokovic Pulls Off a Win. Murray Goes Kicking and Screaming.
abstract: The aging stars were both playing hurt at the Australian Open. Only Djokovic managed to move on, beating Grigor Dimitrov in straight sets.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — It was a little after 7 p.m. in Melbourne on Friday night when Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray limped, hobbled and creaked onto their respective courts for their third-round showdowns.

headline: U.S. Extends Troop Deployment in Romania, at Ukraine War’s Doorstep
abstract: The buildup is part of President Biden’s commitment to increase American forces in Europe in response to the Russian invasion last February.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon will keep several thousand American troops in southeast Romania for at least nine more months, closer to the war in neighboring Ukraine than any other U.S. Army unit, officials said on Saturday.

headline: 25 Years Later, Looking for Lessons in the Clinton Scandal
abstract: Revelations about Bill Clinton’s sex-and-lies affair forever transformed Washington’s politics. Now, President Biden’s team seeks to fend off its own less-tawdry investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The story was as tawdry as they come: The president of the United States had been having sex with a former White House intern in the space off the Oval Office and now was being investigated for lying under oath and obstructing justice to cover it up.

headline: Ron Klain Expected to Step Down as Biden’s White House Chief of Staff
abstract: Mr. Klain’s departure would mark a rare moment of high-level turnover in an administration that has been remarkably stable through two years of crises and political battles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ron Klain, the White House chief of staff who has steered President Biden’s administration through two years of triumphs and setbacks, is expected to step down in coming weeks in the most significant changing of the guard since Mr. Biden took office two years ago.

headline: Three Active-Duty Marines Charged in Jan. 6 Attack
abstract: One of the Marines said that he was waiting for “the boogaloo,” or a second civil war, according to court records.
lead_paragraph: Three active-duty Marines assigned to intelligence-related jobs were charged this week with participating in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol, according to court records, which showed that one of the Marines said that he was waiting for a second civil war.

headline: Five Rules for an Aging World
abstract: Why demography may be shaping up to be a bigger risk to the world than climate change.
lead_paragraph: There are two kinds of people in the world: Those who believe the defining challenge of the 21st century will be climate change, and those who know that it will be the birth dearth, the population bust, the old age of the world.

headline: Gwen Knapp, Sportswriter Who Looked at the Big Picture, Dies at 61
abstract: She was well known in the San Francisco area for focusing on subjects like racism, sexism and drugs, in columns that sometimes angered sports stars.
lead_paragraph: Gwen Knapp, a prominent sports reporter and columnist at The Philadelphia Inquirer and The San Francisco Chronicle and most recently an editor on the sports desk of The New York Times, died on Friday in Manhattan. She was 61.

headline: At the Australian Open, American Men Advance en Masse
abstract: Sebastian Korda, Ben Shelton, J.J. Wolf and Tommy Paul all made the fourth round in singles. Not since 2004 have four men from the United States gone this far in Melbourne.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — There were 94,854 fans at the Australian Open on Saturday, setting a single-day attendance record.

headline: Canada Settles $2 Billion Suit Over ‘Cultural Genocide’ at Residential Schools
abstract: The class action, brought by 325 First Nations, said that residential schools, sanctioned by the government, eroded Indigenous cultures and languages.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Canada said on Saturday that it had agreed to pay 2.8 billion Canadian dollars, about $2 billion, to settle the latest in a series of lawsuits seeking reparations for the harm done to Indigenous people through a system of mandatory residential schools that a national commission called “cultural genocide.”

headline: Buckingham Palace Sets 3-Day Coronation Weekend for King Charles III
abstract: Among the highlights that the palace has announced are a star-studded concert at Windsor Castle, street parties and a national volunteering campaign. No word yet on whether Prince Harry will show up.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — King Charles III has signaled that he wants a streamlined coronation ceremony in May. But that doesn’t mean an economically straitened Britain won’t throw an extravagant party as it crowns its king, the first in seven decades.

headline: New York City to Open Migrant Shelter at Brooklyn Cruise Terminal
abstract: The shelter will temporarily accommodate about 1,000 single men until cruise season begins in the spring.
lead_paragraph: With New York City at “its breaking point,” Mayor Eric Adams announced on Saturday that the city would open a new emergency shelter at the Brooklyn Cruise Terminal to help accommodate the influx of migrants.

headline: With Ease
abstract: Garrett Chalfin makes a breezy Sunday debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: San Diego County to Pay $12 Million in Death of Man Hogtied by Sheriff’s Deputies
abstract: Lucky Phounsy, who died in April 2015, was shocked multiple times by a stun gun and beaten by sheriff’s deputies while suffering from a mental health crisis, according to his family’s lawyers.
lead_paragraph: After a seven-year legal battle, San Diego County is set to pay $12 million over the death of a man who was beaten, shocked with a stun gun and hogtied by a dozen sheriff’s deputies in 2015.

headline: Investigators Seize More Classified Documents From Biden’s Home
abstract: A team from the Justice Department conducted a 13-hour search of the president’s Wilmington residence on Friday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Investigators for the Justice Department on Friday seized more than a half-dozen documents, some of them classified, at President Biden’s residence in Wilmington, Del., after conducting a 13-hour search of the home, the president’s personal lawyer said Saturday evening.

headline: Wife Fatally Shot Terminally Ill Husband in Florida Hospital, Police Say
abstract: Ellen Gilland, 76, had made a pact with her 77-year-old husband and had planned to also fatally shoot herself, but, in the end, “she couldn’t go through with it,” the police said.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Gilland, a 77-year-old terminally ill man, made a pact with his wife about three weeks ago, the authorities said: If his failing health did not improve, he wanted his 76-year-old wife, Ellen Gilland, to kill him.

headline: Despite Mahomes Injury, Kansas City Holds Off Jacksonville
abstract: Quarterback Patrick Mahomes went down with a leg injury in the first half; after backup Chad Henne led a touchdown drive, Mahomes returned in the second to seal the game.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — A bruising running game, a smothering defense and a sterling cameo performance by a backup quarterback were enough on Saturday to send Kansas City to its fifth-straight appearance in the A.F.C. championship game.

headline: Florida Gives Reasons for Rejecting A.P. African American Studies Class
abstract: The state’s Department of Education cites examples of what it calls “the woke indoctrination” of students.
lead_paragraph: After rejecting an Advanced Placement course in African American studies for high school students, the Florida Department of Education offered an explanation of what it found objectionable in the curriculum — citing examples of what it calls “the woke indoctrination” of students that would violate state laws restricting how race can be taught in the classroom.

headline: China Cautiously Takes to the Road for Lunar New Year
abstract: With strict Covid restrictions lifted weeks ahead of the country’s most important holiday, millions, joyful yet anxious, could finally travel and reunite with family.
lead_paragraph: Sheng Chun had not visited his parents in their mountain village in southern China for more than three years because China’s “zero Covid” restrictions made travel difficult. Then the country abandoned its stringent pandemic rules, and he decided to take a long-anticipated road trip.

headline: Top Border Patrol Official Resigned Amid Allegations of Improper Conduct
abstract: Tony Barker, who had been at the Border Patrol for more than 20 years, is under internal investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the most senior officials at the U.S. Border Patrol quietly resigned in October amid an internal investigation into allegations of improper conduct with women, according to four people familiar with the matter.

headline: At the Australian Open, Elena Rybakina Is Rolling
abstract: Iga Swiatek could not find an answer to the power game of Rybakina, the 2022 Wimbledon champion who is seeded No. 22 in Melbourne.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — After starting this Australian Open in the hinterlands of Court 13, Elena Rybakina made it to center stage on Sunday for her fourth-round match with No. 1 Iga Swiatek.

headline: Giants’ Surprising Season Ends With a Dominant Eagles Win
abstract: The Giants, who had been expected to rebuild this season, couldn’t recover from Philadelphia’s explosive start in their divisional-round matchup.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — About 45 minutes before kickoff of a divisional-round playoff game that would have seemed impossible for the Giants in August, Coach Brian Daboll and General Manager Joe Schoen met on the sideline. The team’s co-owner, John Mara, soon joined.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 22, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 22, 2023.
lead_paragraph: The Strategies column last Sunday, on investing over a short time period, referred incorrectly to the number of years it would have taken for an investment to double based on the S&P 500’s rate of return over the past 25 years. It would have taken nine or 10 years, not six or seven.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In France, Real Angst About a Fictional Putin
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 22, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “The challenge of the book is to take the devil’s point of view.”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A Reporter’s Protection
abstract: To tell the story of deadly viruses, journalists must sometimes wear bulky, impermeable outfits to interview news subjects.
lead_paragraph: An entire display case in the Museum at The Times is devoted to the coronavirus pandemic. But a bright yellow protective suit also on exhibit is a reminder that public health catastrophes are familiar territory for New York Times journalists.

headline: ‘I Made a Wrong Turn and Wound Up on the Triborough Bridge’
abstract: A little help turning around, a day out with Mom and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: He Was Accused of Sowing Terror Overseas. He Was Caught by the N.Y.P.D.
abstract: Abdullah el-Faisal is the first person to face trial under state laws passed after Sept. 11. But he was not in the city when the offenses he is accused of took place.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department’s target was 1,500 miles away and across the sea.

headline: Fake Grass, Wood Frames and One Journalist’s Search for Answers
abstract: A Real Estate reporter traveled the country to find out why some of America’s residential buildings look startlingly alike.
lead_paragraph: To an untrained eye, the Real Estate desk at The Times covers homes. To regular readers of the section, however, it covers complex issues such as race, personal finance, local and national politics and others that ultimately converge at the subject of housing.

headline: How the U.S. Government Amassed $31 Trillion in Debt
abstract: Two decades of tax cuts, recession responses and bipartisan spending fueled more borrowing — contributing $25 trillion to the total and setting the stage for another federal showdown.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — America’s debt is now six times what it was at the start of the 21st century. It is the largest it has been, compared with the size of the U.S. economy, since World War II, and it’s projected to grow an average of about $1.3 trillion a year for the next decade.

headline: He Is Brazil’s Defender of Democracy. Is He Actually Good for Democracy?
abstract: Alexandre de Moraes, a Brazilian Supreme Court justice, was crucial to Brazil’s transfer of power. But his aggressive tactics are prompting debate: Can one go too far to fight the far right?
lead_paragraph: When Brazil’s highway police began holding up buses full of voters on Election Day, he ordered them to stop.

headline: Families Struggle as Pandemic Program Offering Free School Meals Ends
abstract: A federal benefit guaranteeing free school meals to millions more students has expired as food prices have risen. Many families are feeling the pinch.
lead_paragraph: Like other parents, April Vazquez, a school nutrition specialist in Sioux Falls, S.D., is cutting coupons, buying in bulk and forgoing outings and restaurant meals. Still, a hot lunch in the school cafeteria for her three children is now a treat she has to carefully plan in her budget.

headline: In a Nation That Nearly Wiped Out Cholera, the Disease Is Surging Back
abstract: Malawi, in southern Africa, had all but eradicated cholera, recording only two cases in 2021. But more than 900 people died of it over the past 11 months, and the government is scrambling to contain its spread.
lead_paragraph: Many patients arrive in wheelchairs, their legs too weak to support them. They cram into a stale hospital tent in Malawi’s capital, where some of the dozens of people not lucky enough to get a bed suffer on the dirt floor.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Mocks George Santos Over and Over Again
abstract: The episode was hosted by Aubrey Plaza, a former NBC page, who strolled down memory lane with the help of President Biden and Amy Poehler.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t a question of if or even when “Saturday Night Live” would get around to ridiculing Representative George Santos, the Republican congressman who has lied about wide swaths of his résumé, just a simple matter of which “S.N.L.” cast member would play him.

headline: Weeks After a Near-Tragedy, the Bills and Bengals Meet Again
abstract: The last time the teams played, Bills safety Damar Hamlin went into cardiac arrest on the field. He attended Sunday’s divisional round playoff game against the Bengals.
lead_paragraph: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. — Three weeks after going into cardiac arrest during a prime-time N.F.L. game, Buffalo Bills safety Damar Hamlin was in attendance Sunday for his team’s divisional round playoff game against the Cincinnati Bengals.

headline: Friends and Family Mourn Lisa Marie Presley at Graceland
abstract: In a memorial service on Sunday, the singer was praised for her perseverance in a life filled with loss.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — To members of the public, Lisa Marie Presley was best known as the daughter of one of the world’s biggest stars. To family and friends, she was a doting mother, a caring friend and a woman who persevered through a life that for all its glamour was punctuated too often by grief.

headline: The December Omnibus Bill’s Little Secret: It Was Also a Giant Health Bill
abstract: Congress passed legislation on mental health, drugs, pandemic preparedness, new Medicare benefits and Medicaid expansion — all before the arrival of the new House.
lead_paragraph: The giant spending bill passed by Congress last month kept the government open. But it also quietly rewrote huge areas of health policy: Hundreds of pages of legislation were devoted to new health care programs.

headline: How These Dog Walkers Make Over $100,000 a Year
abstract: It’s all those pandemic puppies.
lead_paragraph: Dressed in black leggings and a puffer jacket, Bethany Lane, 35, was walking down Bleecker Street in Manhattan last Friday afternoon with a pack of three goldendoodles and one bernedoodle named Tinkerbelle. They poked their noses into the Whalebone store to collect some treats, before trotting along the Hudson River Park and having their photos taken by several tourists.

headline: CPR and Defibrillators: What You Need to Know
abstract: Helping someone in cardiac arrest is not as daunting as it seems.
lead_paragraph: Before 1958, there was no such thing as CPR. If someone’s heart stopped because of cardiac arrest, that person fell to the ground, with no pulse, no breathing. And they were simply declared dead.

headline: Tsitsi Dangarembga Turns From Fiction to Polemic
abstract: The essays in “Black and Female” recount the Zimbabwean novelist and filmmaker’s life in the context of colonialism and its aftermaths.
lead_paragraph: The Zimbabwean novelist and filmmaker Tsitsi Dangarembga’s oeuvre has been defined by her unwillingness to render her characters — citizens of newly independent nations, wandering through the unmapped expanse of the post-colonial moment — as unknowing innocents or foundering victims. Tambudzai — the protagonist of Dangarembga’s 1988 debut, “Nervous Conditions,” its 2006 sequel, “The Book of Not,” and the excellent and acerbic “This Mournable Body” (2018) — wants to make a respectable life for herself amid the experiment of a now self-governing Zimbabwe. At every turn she is foiled, most often by the noxious combination of racism and capitalist accumulation, and the distorted relations it produces between the novels’ characters.

headline: Women’s March Holds Nationwide Rallies on 50th Anniversary of Roe
abstract: The annual march, which was started in 2017 as a reaction to the election of President Donald J. Trump, this year focused on abortion rights.
lead_paragraph: With signs declaring “Abortion Is Health Care” and chants about fighting back, activists in dozens of cities nationwide rallied in support of abortion rights on Sunday, the 50th anniversary of Roe v. Wade, the landmark decision that was overturned by the Supreme Court, eliminating the constitutional right to abortion.

headline: A New Way to Hand-Me-Down
abstract: To help reduce clothing waste, two mothers in San Antonio started a small business reselling used children’s clothes.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series examining Responsible Fashion, and innovative efforts to address issues facing the fashion industry.

headline: Paul Harding Captures the Quiet Side of Calamity
abstract: It took the author a decade, and some luck, to publish his Pulitzer Prize-winning novel “Tinkers.” He’s back with another devastating tale, “This Other Eden.”
lead_paragraph: In 1912, every resident of a mixed-race fishing community living on a small island called Malaga was evicted from their home by the state of Maine. The area is said to have been settled about a century earlier when, in 1794, a formerly enslaved Black man, Benjamin Darling, bought nearby Horse Island and made a home there with his wife. In the 1860s, their descendants branched to Malaga, which, over the years, grew into a population of dozens of people.

headline: Germany’s Reluctance on Tanks Stems From Its History and Its Politics
abstract: A post-Nazi aversion to war and a commitment to promoting peace through engagement combines with an old fixation on Russia and a deep aversion to leading militarily.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the defeat of Nazism, Germany has self-consciously devoted itself to promoting “peace” and integrating into a European and trans-Atlantic security order where consensus has been the byword.

headline: As Deepfakes Flourish, Countries Struggle With Response
abstract: Few governments have approved regulations, often because of free-speech concerns. New mandates from China could change the tone of the debate on digital forgeries.
lead_paragraph: Deepfake technology — software that allows people to swap faces, voices and other characteristics to create digital forgeries — has been used in recent years to make a synthetic substitute of Elon Musk that shilled a cryptocurrency scam, to digitally “undress” more than 100,000 women on Telegram and to steal millions of dollars from companies by mimicking their executives’ voices on the phone.

headline: China Needs Couples to Have More Babies: Can I.V.F. Help?
abstract: China is trying urgently to address its declining population. One idea is to subsidize assisted fertility procedures, which are often a last resort for couples and out of reach for many.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: When Students Change Gender Identity, and Parents Don’t Know
abstract: Educators are facing wrenching new tensions over whether they should tell parents when students socially transition at school.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Bradshaw found out that her 15-year-old identified as transgender at school after she glimpsed a homework assignment with an unfamiliar name scrawled at the top.

headline: The suspect shot and killed himself, the authorities said.
abstract: The attack took place in a city just east of Los Angeles that earlier in the day had hosted a festival celebrating the eve of the Lunar New Year.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was a party to celebrate the Lunar New Year, and dance students gathered at a beloved studio in the heart of Monterey Park, Calif., once marketed as a city of dreams for Chinese immigrants newly arrived in America.

headline: Inside the Hospital Where Damar Hamlin’s Life Was Saved
abstract: The trauma care of the Buffalo Bills player highlighted what is done to overcome cardiac arrest, a leading cause of death in the United States.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Damar Hamlin, the Buffalo Bills player whose heart stopped during a game in Cincinnati on Jan. 2, should not have survived, if statistics on cardiac arrests are any guide.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Could I Survive the “Quietest Place on Earth”?’
abstract: Legends tell of an echoless chamber in an old Minneapolis recording studio that drives visitors insane. One writer gives it a whirl.
lead_paragraph: In a room in a modest concrete building in a leafy Minneapolis neighborhood is silence exceeding the bounds of human perception. Technically an “anechoic chamber,” the room is the quietest place on the planet — according to some.

headline: Older Voters Know Exactly What’s at Stake, and They’ll Be Here for Quite a While
abstract: There were intriguing hints in the November elections of a gray countercurrent that helped damp the expected red wave.
lead_paragraph: Is it time to call the next election “the most important in American history”? Probably. It seems like it may involve a judgment on democracy itself. Americans with a lot of history will play a key role in determining its outcome.

headline: I Don’t Mind if You Say You Have ‘a Little O.C.D.’
abstract: Recognizing that neurodiversity exists helps humanize everyone.
lead_paragraph: I‌‌t’s become common for people to use diagnostic terms to describe themselves, saying that they are “sort of autistic” or “a bit bipolar” or “‌‌a little ‌O.C.D.”‌ Some say they are “addicted” to Twitter. Or they casually toss around trauma-therapy terms like being “triggered.”

headline: Early Abortion Looks Nothing Like What You’ve Been Told
abstract: We are primary care physicians who perform abortions. This fall, we published images of early pregnancy tissue. People were shocked by what they saw.
lead_paragraph: Jewel is a student in her early 20s who lives in Texas. When her doctor confirmed she was pregnant, Jewel felt panicked. She knew it wasn’t the right time for her to have a child, and that abortion was illegal in her state.

headline: Netanyahu Fires a Top Minister to Comply With a Supreme Court Ruling
abstract: Aryeh Deri, who has a conviction for tax fraud, was deemed unfit to serve in the government, leaving Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in a legal and political predicament.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Sunday dismissed a senior minister recently convicted of tax fraud to comply with a Supreme Court ruling that disqualified the minister from serving, shaking the right-wing government just weeks after it came to power.

headline: ‘The Wandering Earth II’ Review: It Wanders Too Far
abstract: The audacious sequel to Frant Gwo’s 2019 sci-fi blockbuster follows survivors working to avert planetary disaster, but it loses much of the glee of its predecessor.
lead_paragraph: Upon its release, “The Wandering Earth,” Frant Gwo’s 2019 film about a dystopia in which Earth is perilously pushed through space, was minted as China’s first substantial, domestic sci-fi blockbuster, with the box office returns to prove it.

headline: The Week in Business: The Debt Limit and Politics
abstract: Microsoft and Alphabet, the parent company of Google, both said they would cut thousands of jobs. And initial estimates of economic growth in the U.S. in the fourth quarter come out Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The United States hit its borrowing cap of $31.4 trillion on Thursday, setting the stage for a bitter fiscal fight in Congress over raising the limit. Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said the government would take “extraordinary measures,” at least until early June, to keep paying its bills. Democrats and the White House, as well as forecasters and economists, have warned that the nation risks a financial crisis and other dire economic scenarios if lawmakers do not raise the limit before the Treasury Department exhausts its ability to buy more time. But Republicans have said that they will not raise the borrowing limit again unless President Biden agrees to steep cuts in federal spending.

headline: Peru’s Deadly Protests
abstract: A failed coup attempt set off unrest that has immobilized the country.
lead_paragraph: First, a breaking news update: At least 10 people were killed in a shooting just east of Los Angeles. Read more details below, and follow The Times’s updates.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 23, 2023
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Is All That Clutter Pointless, or Comforting?
abstract: Readers discuss the pros and cons of clutter. Also: Finding a public bathroom in New York; casual work clothes; a contrast of poverty and wealth.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Recipes for Lunar New Year, a weeknight recipe for seared shrimp and more.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Happy Lunar New Year. I hope your Year of the Rabbit is full of beauty and bounty and peace. Also: longevity noodles, dumplings with chile crisp, wontons and more than 50 other dishes to help you observe the holiday.

headline: Russian Agents Suspected of Directing Far-Right Group to Mail Bombs in Spain
abstract: U.S. officials say the operation may be a signal by Russia that the country and its proxies could carry out more terrorist actions in Europe if nations continue supporting Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American and European officials believe that Russian military intelligence officers directed associates of a white supremacist militant group based in Russia to carry out a recent letter bomb campaign in Spain whose most prominent targets were the prime minister, the defense minister and foreign diplomats, according to U.S. officials.

headline: Review: At the Philharmonic, a Conductor Argues With Passion
abstract: Dalia Stasevska returned to the orchestra’s podium with a world premiere and subtly linked works by Tchaikovsky and Sibelius.
lead_paragraph: The opening of the New York Philharmonic’s concert on Friday took a step toward solving one problem while exposing another.

headline: With Star Players Sidelined, the Rest of UConn’s Roster Proves Itself
abstract: With guards Paige Bueckers and Azzi Fudd out with knee injuries, their teammates are gaining valuable playing time and keeping the Huskies winning.
lead_paragraph: STORRS, Conn. — Geno Auriemma has won 11 national championships as the head coach of the women’s basketball program at the University of Connecticut, and he believes he has what he needs to make it a dozen.

headline: Marion Meade, Biographer Behind Dorothy Parker Revival, Dies at 88
abstract: Her 1988 book put an Algonquin wit back in circulation. She also wrote about Eleanor of Aquitaine, the suffragist Victoria Woodhull and Woody Allen.
lead_paragraph: Marion Meade, who helped revive interest in Dorothy Parker, the celebrated writer and sardonic wit of the Algonquin Round Table, with her 1988 biography, died on Dec. 29 at her home in Manhattan. She was 88.

headline: Police Investigate ‘Suspicious’ Death of a Vulture at Dallas Zoo
abstract: The vulture died under what officials described as “unusual” circumstances. Last week, two animal enclosures were tampered with, allowing a clouded leopard to escape.
lead_paragraph: First, a clouded leopard at the Dallas Zoo went missing for several hours after “suspicious” tears had been found in its enclosure. Then, cuts were found in the fencing of a habitat of langur monkeys. Now, an endangered vulture has died at the zoo under what officials described as “unusual” circumstances.

headline: Biden to Tap Jeff Zients as His Next White House Chief of Staff
abstract: He will replace Ron Klain, who has run President Biden’s White House since the president took office two years ago.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden plans to name Jeffrey D. Zients, his former coronavirus response coordinator, as the next White House chief of staff heading into a critical new phase as he confronts a Republican House and is expected to kick off a re-election campaign, officials familiar with the decision said on Sunday.

headline: Review: In ‘Force of Nature,’ Natalia Osipova Is Absorbed in Memories
abstract: The Russian dancer brought her star-and-her-friends touring program to New York City Center on Saturday for a sold-out, one-night-only show.
lead_paragraph: Since the Russian ballerina Natalia Osipova first burst onto the international scene, nearly 20 years ago, people have been calling her a force of nature. Lately, that’s what she’s been calling herself. “Force of Nature” is the title of the touring program that she brought to New York City Center on Saturday for a sold-out, one-night-only show.

headline: Edward Pressman, Film Producer Who Bet on Unsung Talent, Dies at 79
